choices.text: IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate
Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation

questions.text: A 30-year-old female who was using IUCD for contraception presents in the emergency following two episodes of painless spotting per vagina preceded by amenorrhea for 8 weeks. She complained of lightheadedness and her blood pressure is 80/50 mmHg and the pulse rate is 138 beats/ minute, with a positive urine pregnancy test. What should be the management of this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate laparotomy

 

Explanation:

 

  • Immediate laparotomy is indicated as this is a scenario of a ruptured ectopic pregnancy
  • Ruptured ectopic pregnancy is the most likely diagnosis because of
    • Amenorrhoea + pain + bleeding (classic triad of ectopic)
    • She is in shock (hypotension and tachycardia) that is why ruptured ectopic is suspected)
    • IUCD: this is a risk factor for ectopic pregnancy
  • Immediate laparotomy and salpingectomy is required in this scenario

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV fluids followed by oral methotrexate: There is no role of Methotrexate in a rupture ectopic pregnancy. It only has a role in an unruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

Option C. Stabilizing the patient followed by suction evacuation: Suction and evacuation is not done in an ectopic pregnancy. It is done in an inevitable or incomplete abortion

 

Option D. Dilatation and curettage: Dilatation and curettage is done only if retained products of conception are there inside the uterus. Again no role in a ruptured ectopic pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

 

Immediate laparotomy is the indicated management for a ruptured ectopic pregnancy, which presents with amenorrhea, pain, bleeding, hypotension, and tachycardia.

 

Ref: Page 574, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Auspitz sign is seen in? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Psoriasis vulgaris

 

A defining characteristic of psoriasis is the Auspitz sign.

 

  • In psoriasis we can see silvery white, scaly lesions on the extensor aspect of the knee and elbow. The Auspitz sign can be used to make a clinical diagnosis of the condition.
  • Scratching (grattage) superficial silvery scales causes them to come off attached, as if one had done so on a wax candle (wax candle scales).
  • The Bulkeley membrane, a thin membrane, can then be seen.
  • When the Bulkeley membrane is removed, the Auspitz sign, a classic pinpoint bleeding, is revealed.
  • The Auspitz sign is the name for the traditional pin-point bleeding.

 

  • Pin point bleeding spots noted in the above image.

 

 

Mechanism of the Auspitz sign: It is brought on by elongated, dilated, tortuous vessels in the dermal papillae and supra papillary epidermal thinning.

 

Auspitz sign is neither sensitive nor specific for psoriasis.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Pustular psoriasis:

 

  • Characterized by white pustules (blisters of non-infectious pus) surrounded by red skin as shown in the below image.
  • The pustules are not infectious.
  • Can be localized (to hands and feet) or generalized (covering large areas of the body).

 

Option C. Pemphigus:

 

  • A group of rare autoimmune blistering disorders.
  • Flaccid bullae (soft, fluid-filled blisters) which easily rupture.
  • Positive Nikolsky's sign: The Nikolsky's sign is a clinical dermatological sign. It's considered positive when the application of slight tangential pressure or rubbing to the skin results in the exfoliation of the outermost layer, producing a erosion as shown in the below image.

 

  • Oral lesions are common.

 

Option D. Bullous pemphigoid:

 

  • Another autoimmune blistering disease.
  • Formation of tense bullae (firm, fluid-filled blisters).
  • Usually affects elderly patients.
  • Negative Nikolsky's sign: The skin does not slough off with lateral pressure.
  • Blisters are more robust compared to pemphigus.

 

 

In summary, while both psoriasis vulgaris and pustular psoriasis are forms of psoriasis, only psoriasis vulgaris is associated with the Auspitz sign.

 

The Auspitz sign is not typically observed in inverse psoriasis, erythrodermic psoriasis, pustular psoriasis and guttate psoriasis

 

Educational Objective:

 

Auspitz sign as a clinical feature of psoriasis vulgaris, which is characterized by pinpoint bleeding when scales from psoriatic plaques are removed.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 35 page no 35.9 35.10

ijdvl.com - Scaly signs in dermatology

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Similar looking lesions were present near the anal canal of his wife. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Condyloma acuminata

 

The most likely diagnosis is of condyloma acuminata.

 

  • Commonly known as genital warts, these are caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV).
  • They are soft, raised masses which may be single or multiple, small or large.
  • They can appear on the genitals, in or around the anus, or in the mouth.
  • Sexually transmitted, which aligns with the presentation in both the male and female partner.

 

HPV (Human papilloma virus) 6 & 11 (6 > 11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts (also known as condyloma acuminata).

 

  • Giant anogenital warts are known as Buschke Lowenstein tumour.
  • It is more common in males than in females.

 

Common sites:

 

  • In males: frenulum, corona, glans penis
  • In females: posterior fourchette
  • On histology Koilocytes are seen.

 

 

Imiquimod and podophyllotoxin are both the first-line drugs used in the treatment of genital warts.

 

Provider administered:

 

  • Podophyllin 25%
  • Trichloroacetic acid (TCA)
  • Cryotherapy

 

Both TCA & Cryotherapy are safe in pregnancy.

 

Patient administered:

 

  • Purified podophyllin called podophyllotoxin
  • Imiquimod Immunomodulator which acts as a agonist on toll like receptor 7 & 8

 

The treatment of actinic keratoses, superficial basal cell carcinoma, and genital warts with imiquimod cream via topical immunomodulation is approved.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Penile cancer:

 

  • It is a malignant growth found on the skin or in the tissues of the penis.
  • Early signs might include changes in color, skin thickening, or a build-up of tissue (similar to a mole).
  • Risk factors include HPV infection, smoking, phimosis, and chronic inflammation.
  • It's less likely to present as multiple warts and doesn't explain the wife's anal canal lesions in this case scenario.

 

Option C. Bowen disease:

 

  • It is a form of squamous cell carcinoma in situ, meaning it involves only the surface layers of the skin.
  • Appears as a persistent, slow-growing, scaly red patch.
  • While it can be found on the penis (Bowenoid papulosis), it doesn't typically appear as warts, and it would be less likely to explain similar lesions in the wife's anal canal.

 

Option D. Haemorrhoids:

 

  • Swollen blood vessels in the rectal area, which can be painful or bleed.
  • They do not appear on the penis.
  • Appearance is different than warts; they might look like bulging lumps around the anus.
  • The wife's anal canal lesions might look like hemorrhoids, but this wouldn't explain the husband's penile warts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Condyloma acuminata (genital warts) as soft, skin-colored, cauliflower-like lesions typically found on genital and perianal areas, associated with HPV infection, and often occurring in sexually active individuals.

 

References:

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume I Chapter 25 Page no 25.43, 25.56, 25.58

questions.text: In a patient being treated for eclampsia, the next dose of MgSO4 should be skipped if: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Knee jerks are sluggish

 

Explanation:

 

  • Loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTR) is a sign of magnesium toxicity. If knee jerks are sluggish, it indicates that the patient may be experiencing magnesium toxicity.
  • Magnesium sulfate (MgSO4) is used in the management of eclampsia to prevent seizures. However, monitoring for toxicity is crucial.
  • Signs of magnesium toxicity include:
    • Loss of DTR
    • Decreased urine output
    • Decreased respiratory rate

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Urine output exceeds 30 ml/hr:

 

  • Explanation: Adequate urine output is required to ensure magnesium is being excreted and to avoid toxicity. If urine output exceeds 30 ml/hr, it is generally a positive sign indicating good renal function and not a reason to withhold MgSO4.

 

Option C. Respiratory rate more than 14/min:

 

  • Explanation: A respiratory rate above 14 breaths per minute is not indicative of magnesium toxicity. Concerns arise when the respiratory rate is below 12 breaths per minute, suggesting possible respiratory depression due to toxicity.

 

Option D. None of the above:

 

  • Explanation: This is incorrect because sluggish knee jerks (Option A) are a valid sign of magnesium toxicity and warrant withholding the next dose of MgSO4.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient receiving magnesium sulfate for eclampsia, the next dose should be withheld if there is evidence of magnesium toxicity, such as loss of deep tendon reflexes (DTR).

 

Ref: page no 439, Textbook of Obstetrics, Dr JB Sharma 1st edition

choices.text: Serum cortisol levels
TSH levels
Sepsis screening
Serum IGF-1 levels

questions.text: A 3-week-old baby was brought to the pediatric OPD with yellowish discoloration of skin and hypotonia. On examination, the baby was also having large protruded tongue and umbilical hernia. Which of the following would be initial step in the management of this clinical condition? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) TSH levels.

 

Based on the clinical history given, a case of congenital hypothyroidism is suspected, to confirm the diagnosis TSH levels are measured with a dried blood spot.

 

 

The most common cause of Congenital hypothyroidism is Thyroid dysgenesis.

 

Untreated case may lead to

 

  • Intellectual disability,
  • Disproportionate stature,
  • Delayed bone maturation and
  • Delayed puberty.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Serum cortisol levels: Serum cortisol levels are not related to the diagnosis of congenital hypothyroidism. They are typically measured to assess adrenal function and would not be the initial step in this clinical scenario.

 

Option C. Sepsis screening: While sepsis can present with jaundice and hypotonia, the presence of a large protruding tongue and umbilical hernia strongly points towards congenital hypothyroidism. Sepsis screening is not the first step in this context.

 

Option D. Serum IGF-1 levels: Serum IGF-1 levels are related to growth hormone activity and are not relevant in the initial assessment of suspected congenital hypothyroidism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For an infant presenting with symptoms such as jaundice, hypotonia, large protruding tongue, and umbilical hernia, the initial step in management should be to measure TSH levels to diagnose congenital hypothyroidism. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent severe developmental issues.

questions.text: Identify the Xray? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hydropneumothorax

 

  • The chest X-ray shows left sided air-fluid level, suggestive of hydropneumothorax.
  • Hydro pneumothorax is a term given to the concurrent presence of a pneumothorax as well as a hydrothorax i.e., air and fluid in the pleural space.
  • Treatment for hydropneumothorax is ICD/chest tube insertion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Empyema: Typically involves an accumulation of pus in the pleural space but would generally not show a distinct air-fluid level unless there is also a fistula to the airways.

 

Option B. Pneumothorax: This condition involves air in the pleural space without accompanying fluid, typically showing a completely radiolucent area not bound by a fluid level.

 

Option D. Pleural effusion: This would show fluid accumulating in the pleural space but without the presence of air, typically creating a meniscus at the lung base and not a flat air-fluid level.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydropneumothorax is characterized by an air-fluid level within the pleural space and requires prompt diagnosis and management to prevent complications such as respiratory distress. The presence of both air and fluid distinguishes it from conditions that involve only one or the other.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis of the patient after looking at the karyotype given in the image as shown: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Down Syndrome

 

Down syndrome is a genetic condition where a person is born with an extra copy of chromosome 21. This means that they have a total of 47 chromosomes instead of 46. This can affect how their brain and body develop.

 

Down syndrome is a genetic disorder caused by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21. This extra genetic material affects the development of the body and brain, resulting in a range of physical and intellectual characteristics.

 

Here are some of the key features of Down syndrome:

 

  1. Intellectual disability: People with Down syndrome typically have some degree of intellectual disability, which can range from mild to moderate. This means they may have difficulty with learning, problem-solving, and communication.
  2. Physical features: Down syndrome can also cause certain physical features, such as a flat facial profile, small head and ears, and upward-slanting eyes with epicanthal folds. Other physical characteristics may include a short neck, broad hands with short fingers, and a single crease across the palm.
  3. Developmental delays: Children with Down syndrome often experience delays in their development, including in their motor skills and speech and language abilities. They may take longer to reach developmental milestones, such as crawling, walking, and talking.
  4. Health issues: People with Down syndrome are at an increased risk for certain health conditions, such as congenital heart defects, respiratory infections, hearing and vision problems, and thyroid disorders. Regular medical check-ups and interventions may be necessary to manage these issues.
  5. Behavioural and emotional issues: Some people with Down syndrome may also experience behavioral and emotional challenges, such as hyperactivity, anxiety, and difficulty with social interactions.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Turner Syndrome: Turner syndrome is characterized by the presence of a single X chromosome (45, X) and is typically found in females. It is not associated with trisomy 21.

 

Option C. Klinefelter Syndrome: Klinefelter syndrome is characterized by an extra X chromosome in males (47, XXY). It is not associated with trisomy 21.

 

Option D. Edward Syndrome: Edward syndrome, also known as trisomy 18, involves an extra copy of chromosome 18. It is not associated with trisomy 21.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Down syndrome is characterized by the presence of an extra copy of chromosome 21, leading to a total of 47 chromosomes. This genetic abnormality results in a range of physical and intellectual features, and the karyotype provided confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: The CXR of a 65-year-old male with a previous history of heart surgery is shown. Identify the device? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Prosthetic mitral valve

 

The CXR shows a prosthetic mitral valve.

 

To know the position of the valve:

 

Draw a line from the left hilum, take it to the right CP (cardio-phrenic) angle -

 

  • Above this line → Aortic valve
  • Below this line → Mitral valve

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option  B. Prosthetic aortic valve: This would be situated higher in the mediastinum, generally above the line from the left hilum to the right cardiophrenic angle.

 

Option C. Implantable defibrillator: An implantable cardioverter defibrillator (ICD) typically appears as a small, rectangular device under the skin in the chest area with leads running into the heart.

 

Option D. Pacemaker: Similar to an ICD, a pacemaker would show a small device with one or more leads, the leads typically being more pronounced.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The positioning of heart valves as shown on a CXR can help identify the type of prosthetic valve a patient has. This CXR shows a prosthetic mitral valve based on its relative position below the line from the left hilum to the right cardiophrenic angle.

questions.text: In ORS, sodium is given along with glucose to facilitate? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Co-transport

 

Explanation:

 

  • Co-transport refers to the process where two substances are simultaneously transported across a membrane in the same direction by a single protein, or symporter. In the case of Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS), sodium and glucose are absorbed together through the Sodium Glucose Linked Transporter (SGLT-1) in the intestines. This is an example of secondary active transport because it relies on the electrochemical gradient of sodium, which is maintained by primary active transport systems like the sodium-potassium pump.
  • Cotransporters can be classified as symporters and antiporters depending on whether the substances move in the same or opposite directions.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Simple diffusion: Incorrect because simple diffusion does not involve transport proteins and occurs without energy input, unlike the sodium-glucose co-transport.

 

Option C. Facilitated diffusion: Incorrect as this process does not require energy but still needs a carrier protein, and it doesn't apply to sodium and glucose transport in ORS.

 

Option D. Primary active transport: Incorrect for this context because although primary active transport does play a role in maintaining the sodium gradient utilized by SGLT-1, the actual transport of sodium and glucose via SGLT-1 is not primary active transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of transport:

 

Active transport: ATP dependent

 

1. Primary – energy is used directly to transport the substances

 

Primary active transport directly uses ATP to move molecules or ions across the membrane.

 

E.g., sodium potassium pump present in all cell

 

2. Secondary - energy is used indirectly to create the gradient for the transport by primary active transporters after which the secondary active transporters are activated.

 

Secondary active transport uses the energy stored in the electrochemical gradient of one molecule or ion to power the transport of another molecule or ion against its gradient.

 

   E.g., SGLT [Sodium linked glucose transport]

 

  • SGLT-1 Present in the intestine
  • SGLT-2 present in the kidney

 

Passive transport

 

  1. Simple diffusion:
    • No energy is required.
    • No carrier molecule is involved.
    • E.g., O2 exchange in alveoli.
  2. Facilitated diffusion:
    • No energy is required BUT always requires carrier protein
    • E.g., GLUT for the transport of glucose
  3. Osmosis 
    • Movement of water along its gradient via specific channels for water movement.
    • E.g., Aquaporins

choices.text: Paronychia
Yellow nail syndrome
Psoriasis
Alopecia areata

questions.text: A 38-year-old male comes with complaints in his fingernail. On examination, nail folds were seen to be erythematous & with pus collection as shown in the picture. The most likely diagnosis is? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Paronychia

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Yellow Nail Syndrome:

 

  • Description: A rare condition characterized by slow-growing, thickened, yellow nails as shown in the below image.

 

 

  • Symptoms: Besides the characteristic yellow nails, the syndrome may also present with lymphedema (swelling due to lymphatic obstruction) and respiratory manifestations.
  • Causes: The exact cause is unknown, but it's associated with chronic sinusitis, rheumatoid arthritis, and certain cancers.

 

Option C. Psoriasis:

 

  • Description: A chronic inflammatory skin condition.
  • Symptoms: Nail psoriasis can cause pitting, abnormal nail growth, and discoloration.

 

Option D. Alopecia Areata:

 

  • Description: An autoimmune disease where the body attacks its own hair follicles, resulting in hair loss.
  • Symptoms: Sudden patchy hair loss in small, round patches on the scalp or body. Nails can also be affected, showing pits (which are superficial regular & Fine as shown in the below image), white spots, roughness, or a sandpaper-like texture.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paronychia as a condition presenting with erythematous and edematous nail folds, often accompanied by pus collection, commonly resulting from bacterial infection.

 

Reference:

 

Fitzpatrick’s Textbook of Dermatology 9th edition chapter 150 page no 2725

Andrews Diseases of the skin Clinical Dermatology 11th edition Chapter 14, Page no 248

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition Chapter 95 Page no 95.35

questions.text: Identify the image given below? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) P. falciparum

 

  • Plasmodium falciparum is a unicellular protozoan parasite of humans.
  • P. Falciparum shows characteristic Maurer’s dot. multiple rings within RBC, with all ages of RBC involved. Accole Forms, Recrudescence is seen due to incomplete treatment. Durck’s Granuloma is a histopathological finding seen in Cerebral malaria caused by P. falciparum.

 

Note - Plasmodium vivax is the most geographically widespread human malaria parasite. Global malaria efforts have been less successful at reducing the burden of P. vivax compared to P. falciparum, owing to the unique biology and related treatment complexity of P. vivax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P. vivax: Typically shows larger, amoeboid trophozoites and Schüffner's dots in RBCs.

 

Option C. P. malariae: Characterized by band-shaped trophozoites and infected RBCs that do not enlarge.

 

Option D. P. ovale: Shows oval-shaped RBCs with Schüffner's dots and large, amoeboid trophozoites.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Plasmodium falciparum is identified by the presence of multiple ring forms within RBCs, Maurer’s dots, and accole forms. It is a significant cause of severe and cerebral malaria.

choices.text: Secular trend of a disease
Cyclical trend of a disease
Disease changing its traits according to herd immunity in the population
Disease changing the symptoms as per seasons

questions.text: A public health researcher is analyzing historical data to understand the long-term changes in the incidence and outcomes of a particular disease in a community. Which of the following patterns is most appropriate for observing these long-term changes?  (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Secular trend of a disease

 

A secular trend refers to long-term patterns or trends in disease occurrence over an extended period, typically years to decades. This type of trend is used to observe the long-term changes or sequelae of a disease within a population. It helps in identifying whether the incidence or prevalence of a disease is increasing, decreasing, or remaining stable over time.

 

Other Options

 

Option B. Cyclical trend of a disease: This refers to periodic fluctuations in disease incidence, often related to seasonal variations or other cyclic factors.

 

Option C. Disease changing its traits according to herd immunity in the population: This refers to changes in disease patterns due to the level of immunity in the population, not necessarily long-term trends.

 

Option D. Disease changing the symptoms as per seasons: This refers to seasonal variations in disease symptoms, which is a type of cyclical trend.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secular trends are important for understanding the long-term changes in disease patterns and the sequelae of diseases within a population.

 

Secular trend of a Disease is best depicted by Line diagram

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, a renowned ophthalmologist in Delhi with over 25 years of experience, is conducting a seminar on visual impairments and their global implications. She emphasizes the importance of standardized definitions to facilitate international collaboration, research, and policy implementation. She mentions the World Health Organization's criteria for categorizing visual impairments. If a patient were to be classified as "blind" as per the WHO, their visual acuity, even after the best possible correction, in which scenario would warrant this classification? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. <3/60 in better eye

 

‘Blindness’ is defined as visual acuity of less than 3/60, or a corresponding visual field loss to less than 10°, in the better eye with the best possible correction.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

(PL+: Perception of Light; PL–: No perception of light)

choices.text: Attempt Reduction followed by elective surgery

questions.text: A medical college student with irreducible inguinal hernia was brought to the casualty. What should be the next step? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Attempt reduction followed by elective surgery

 

Here is a break down each of the provided options for managing an irreducible inguinal hernia:

 

Option A. Exploratory laparotomy:

 

  • While it provides access to the herniated segment of the intestine, it is typically reserved for situations where there's a suspicion of bowel strangulation, perforation, or other intra-abdominal catastrophes. It's more invasive than required for a simple irreducible hernia without signs of complications.

 

Option B. Attempt Reduction followed by elective surgery:

 

  • This is the preferred approach for an irreducible hernia without signs of complications (e.g., strangulation, ischemia). The goal of manual reduction is to push the herniated contents back into the abdominal cavity to relieve the patient's immediate symptoms. Once reduced, an elective surgical repair of the hernia can be scheduled. This approach avoids the potential complications and recovery time associated with an emergency hernia repair.

 

Option C. Emergency surgery:

 

  • This would be the appropriate action if there were signs of complications like strangulation or bowel obstruction. Strangulation can lead to ischemia and eventual necrosis of the herniated bowel segment. In such cases, urgent surgery is necessary not only to reduce the herniated segment but also to assess the viability of the entrapped bowel.

 

Option D. Attempt reduction under local anesthesia:

 

  • This option involves injecting local anesthetic around the hernia site to numb the area, then attempting manual reduction. This might be considered if a patient is experiencing significant discomfort or if initial attempts at reduction without anesthesia were unsuccessful. It's less invasive than immediate surgery but could lead to potential complications if not done correctly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In the absence of signs of strangulation or obstruction, the best management for an irreducible inguinal hernia is to attempt reduction followed by elective surgery, providing relief from immediate symptoms while planning a controlled and less emergent surgical intervention.

choices.text: Give IV fluids only
Give IV fluids for 4 hours followed by ORS
Give ORS only
Plain water

questions.text: A 7-month-old boy was brought with history of loose stools 18 episodes, vomiting 2 episodes. The child is irritable but can drink orally. What is the best way to manage this child? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Give ORS only

 

As the guidelines the clinical history corelates with the Some dehydration.

 

 

The treatment protocol includes - 75ml/kg over hours, if accept orally-ORS

 

If, Persistent vomiting- IV Fluids can be provided.

 

Replacements of ongoing losses by ORS 5-10 ml/kg per episode of loose stool.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a child with some dehydration who is irritable but able to drink, the best management is to administer ORS according to the IMNCI guidelines.

questions.text: A 62-year-old nulliparous female who is on hormone replacement therapy developed abdominal pain and on examination, the right adnexal mass was palpable, non-tender. After workup, she was posted for laparotomy in which ovaries were seen as below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Ovarian Carcinoma

 

Explanation:

 

  • The most likely diagnosis is ovarian carcinoma.
  • Points in favor
    • Age (post-menopausal)
    • h/o HRT
    • The image shows bilateral, irregular lesions suggestive of ovarian malignancy

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Functional ovarian cysts:

 

  • Seen in reproductive age group
  • Appear regular, usually unilocular

 

Option B. Chocolate cyst of the ovary:

 

  • Seen in reproductive age group
  • Appears as chocolate filled material in the cyst
  • Treatment of choice: Ovarian cystectomy

 

Option C. Ovarian fibroma:

 

  • This is a solid ovarian tumor
  • Rarely malignant
  • Seen in the postmenopausal age group
  • May be associated with Meig syndrome (Fibroma + ascites + pleural effusion)
  • This is how a fibroma looks like

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ovarian carcinoma should be highly suspected in postmenopausal women presenting with a palpable adnexal mass, especially if they have a history of hormone replacement therapy and imaging shows bilateral, irregular ovarian lesions.

 

Ref: Page 375, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady presents to the emergency department with complaints of palpitation, sweating, heaviness and pain in chest with a feeling of impending doom. Her ECG, troponin levels, random blood sugar and chest radiograph are normal. What is the next best step?(FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Use benzodiazepines for symptom relief

 

The patient's symptoms, including palpitations, sweating, chest discomfort, and feeling of impending doom, are indicative of a panic attack. Once cardiac causes have been ruled out, the initial management for an acute panic attack is benzodiazepines.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Admit for detailed investigation: is not necessary once cardiac causes have been ruled out for a panic attack.

 

Option B. Start counseling sessions: can be helpful in the long term but is not the immediate step.

 

Option D. Use beta-blocker: It can be useful for prophylaxis of recurrent symptoms, but for acute relief, benzodiazepines are preferred.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For an acute panic attack, once cardiac causes are ruled out, benzodiazepines are the first-line treatment for immediate symptom relief.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 407

choices.text: Most common type of stone is triple phosphate
Stone can be managed conservatively with pharmacotherapy
Most of the renal stones can be removed by ESWL
Stones <5 mm can be managed conservatively

questions.text: What is not true regarding renal stones? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Most common type of stone is triple phosphate

 

This statement is not true. The most common type of kidney stone is calcium oxalate. Triple phosphate stones, also known as struvite or staghorn calculi, are associated with chronic urinary tract infections, especially from urease-producing bacteria like Proteus mirabilis. These stones can grow large and fill the entire renal pelvis, resembling a deer's antler – hence the name "staghorn".

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Stone can be managed conservatively with pharmacotherapy:

 

  • True. Some stones, especially uric acid stones, can be dissolved with medication. Additionally, medication can help in preventing stone formation or recurrence. For example, thiazide diuretics can help prevent calcium stones, and allopurinol can help prevent uric acid stones.

 

Option C. Most of the renal stones can be removed by ESWL:

 

  • True. Extracorporeal shock wave lithotripsy (ESWL) is a non-invasive procedure that uses high-energy shock waves to break up stones inside the kidney or upper urinary tract. Stones that are less than 2 cm in size and not located in the lower pole of the kidney are typically suitable for ESWL.

 

Option D. Stones <5 mm can be managed conservatively:

 

  • True. Small stones, especially those less than 5 mm in diameter, often pass out of the body on their own. Patients are typically advised to drink plenty of water to help pass the stone and may be given pain medications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most common type of kidney stone is calcium oxalate, not triple phosphate. Small stones (<5 mm) can often be managed conservatively, and many stones can be treated with ESWL or pharmacotherapy.

questions.text: Dr. Patel, an epidemiologist from Kolkata, attending a conference on global health security in Geneva. During one of the breakout sessions, a delegate from Africa shared about a recent surge in a rare but severe disease in their region. Dr. Patel recalled his own experiences managing outbreaks in India and the protocols that had to be followed for international notification. This got him pondering about the obligations and standards set by the World Health Organization (WHO) for countries suspecting a severe disease outbreak. As a member nation, within what specified duration should a country notify the WHO about a suspected severe disease to ensure timely global interventions and preventive measures? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 24 hours

 

The probable time within which one country should report it to WHO is 24 hrs. such serious diseases are termed as PHEIC (public health emergency of international concern)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Countries are required to notify the WHO within 24 hours of identifying a suspected case of a severe disease that could be a Public Health Emergency of International Concern (PHEIC), to facilitate timely and effective global response measures.

questions.text: A child was brought to the Emergency with Generalized Tonic Clonic Seizures. Which drug should be given first to control his symptoms? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Diazepam

 

As per the clinical features mentioned, Initial management for the Generalized Tonic Clonic Seizures is by administration of benzodiazepines like lorazepam/Midazolam/Diazepam.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Valproate: Sodium valproate is an anticonvulsant drug used primarily for the treatment of various types of epilepsy, including juvenile myoclonic epilepsy and absence seizures (after ethosuximide). However, it is not the first drug of choice in the acute management of generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Option C. Phenytoin: Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug that is often used in the management of seizures, including status epilepticus, but it is typically administered after benzodiazepines if seizures persist. It is also used as a second-line drug in the treatment of neonatal seizures.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: Haloperidol is an antipsychotic medication primarily used to treat schizophrenia and acute psychotic states. It is not used in the management of seizures and would not be appropriate for treating generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first line of treatment for managing acute generalized tonic-clonic seizures in children is the administration of benzodiazepines such as diazepam, lorazepam, or midazolam.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman came with the complaints of palpitations and weight loss on examination, sinus tachycardia is present and the following lesion was noticed on the shin of the patient. What is the clinical diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hyperthyroidism

 

The clinical history and image show pretibial myxedema which is seen in patients with Grave’s disease. Graves' disease is an autoimmune disorder that can cause hyperthyroidism; hence answer is hyperthyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hypothyroidism is characterized by low serum levels of thyroid hormone. The patient appears lethargic, obese with slow heart rate and slow basal metabolism. The clinical picture is going against this diagnosis, so Option A is false.

 

Option B. Filariasis is an parasitic lymphatic disorder characterized by unilateral lower limb edema, originating from upper thigh progressing to the lower. It is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti. The clinical picture would be recurrent episodes of fever along with pain, discomfort and swelling of limbs and genitalia. Given clinical history is against the diagnosis, so Option B is ruled out.

 

Option D. Milroy’s disease is also known as Primary Lymphedema type 1. It occurs due to mutation in FLT4 gene which codes for VEGFR-3 (for development of lymphatic vessels.) It is a congenital disorder and presents in the early childhood with swelling in the legs, feet and sometimes hands. The clinical scenario of sinus tachycardia and palpitations goes against this option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Graves' disease, an autoimmune disorder causing hyperthyroidism, can present with pretibial myxedema, weight loss, palpitations, and sinus tachycardia.

questions.text: Dr. Aadhya, the head of a prestigious hospital in Mumbai, is keen on improving the efficiency of healthcare delivery in his institution. She plans to meticulously document the time doctors spend with patients versus the time they spend on other non-patient related tasks. Her goal is to streamline operations and ensure optimal utilization of resources in the future. Which management technique is Dr. Aadhya  employing to achieve this? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Work Sampling

 

Work Sampling is the systematic observation and recording of activities of one or more individuals, carried out at pre-determined or random intervals. It provides quantitative measurement of various activities. 

 

Work sampling, also known as time study or time-and-motion study, is a method used to determine the proportions of time spent on different activities, especially in industries or institutions. 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Network Analysis: Network analysis involves techniques such as Program Evaluation Review Technique (PERT) and Critical Path Method (CPM) to plan, schedule, and control complex projects. It is primarily used for project management rather than analyzing day-to-day activities of individuals.

 

PERT (Program Evaluation Review Technique): Focuses on planning and coordinating large projects.

 

CPM (Critical Path Method): Used to determine the longest path of planned activities to the end of the project, ensuring that project deadlines are met.

 

Option B. System Analysis: System analysis involves comparing two or more cost-effective programs or systems within an organization to determine the most efficient and effective way to achieve objectives. It is broader and more comprehensive than work sampling, focusing on overall systems rather than individual activities.

 

Option D. Decision Making: Decision making refers to the process of making choices by identifying a decision, gathering information, and assessing alternative resolutions. While crucial for management, it is not a technique for observing and recording time spent on activities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Work Sampling is a management technique used to systematically observe and record the time spent on various activities. It helps in identifying inefficiencies and optimizing resource utilization by providing quantitative data on how time is allocated across different tasks.

questions.text: The image given below shows a female baby with rash on face and perineal area. What could be the underlying deficiency responsible for this rash? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Zinc

 

The image and clinical features of rash around the orifical regions of the mouth and perineal area are suggestive of Zinc deficiency known as Acrodermatitis Enteropathica. This condition is caused by an autosomal recessive trait involving a defect in the SLC39A4 gene, which encodes the hZIP4 protein, responsible for zinc absorption.

 

Diagnosis of Zinc deficiency:

 

Clinical Diagnosis (symptoms and signs):

 

  • Malnutrition (zinc deficiency likely to be present)
  • Decreased immunity
  • Prolonged diarrhea
  • Frequent respiratory infections
  • Poor growth / Stunting
  • Zinc deficiency increases diarrhea and respiratory infections by 25-50% in children under 5 years of age

 

Laboratory Diagnosis:

 

  • Serum Zinc level < 70 mcg/dl (normal range 70-120 mcg/dl)

 

Treatment:

 

  • Zinc supplementation at 3 mg/kg/day lifelong
  • 220 mg tablet of Zinc sulfate = 50 mg of elemental Zinc

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Copper: Copper deficiency typically leads to conditions like anemia, neutropenia, and osteoporosis, but it does not cause the periorifical rashes seen in this case.

 

Option B. Riboflavin: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) deficiency can cause symptoms like sore throat, redness and swelling of the lining of the mouth and throat, cracks or sores on the outsides of the lips (cheilosis) and at the corners of the mouth (angular stomatitis), but it does not cause the periorifical rashes seen in this case.

 

Option C. Vitamin C: Vitamin C deficiency, also known as scurvy, can lead to symptoms such as swollen and bleeding gums, bruising, joint pain, and anemia, but it does not cause the characteristic rash seen in Acrodermatitis Enteropathica.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zinc deficiency, characterized by Acrodermatitis Enteropathica, presents with rashes around the orifical regions such as the mouth and perineal area, and is diagnosed with clinical symptoms and confirmed by low serum zinc levels.

questions.text: A medical student is studying the principles of Primary Health Care (PHC) as laid out by the World Health Organization (WHO) during a global conference on primary health care. He learns that these principles aim to provide accessible, affordable, and acceptable quality care to all individuals. He reads about several key principles, too. Which of the following is NOT considered one of the principles of Primary Health Care? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Appropriate facility

 

"Appropriate Facility" is not considered one of the principles of Primary Health Care. Its Appropriate Technologies, which is the utilizing technology that is affordable, acceptable, and feasible within the community to provide effective health care.

 

Additional Information

 

Primary health care concept

 

  • Background: One year after the World Health Assembly stated its “Health for All” goal, WHO came up with the concept of primary health care at Alma-Ata Conference, USSR, in 1978
  • Broad principles: Social equity, National coverage, Self-reliance and Inter-sectoral coordination
  • Aim: To put the people’s health in the people’s hand
  • Definition: Essential health care based on practical, scientifically sound and socially acceptable methods and technology made universally accessible to individuals and families in the community through their full participation and at a cost that the community and the country can afford to maintain at every stage of their development in the spirit of self-reliance and self-determination
  • Hallmarks of Primary health care: 4 A’s
    • Affordability
    • Acceptability
    • Accessibility
    • Availability
  • 8 essential ELEMENTS/components of Primary Health Care (as outlined by the ‘Alma-Ata Declaration, 1978’):
    • E: Essential drugs
    • L: Locally endemic diseases prevention and control
    • E:Education concerning health problems and their control 
    • M: Maternal and child health care including family planning
    • E: EPI (Immunization) against Vaccine Preventable Diseases
    • N: Nutrition and promoting proper food supply
    • T: Treatment of common diseases and injuries
    • S: Safe water supply and sanitation

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Community participation: This principle emphasizes the involvement of the community in the planning, implementation, and maintenance of health services to ensure they meet the needs of the community effectively.

 

Option C. Intersectoral coordination: This principle highlights the need for collaboration between different sectors (e.g., health, education, agriculture) to address the broader determinants of health and achieve better health outcomes.

 

Option D. Equitable distribution: This principle ensures that health services are distributed fairly across the population, regardless of their socioeconomic status, to achieve universal health coverage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There are Four Principles of Primary Health Care (PHC):

 

  • Equitable distribution
  • Community participation
  • Intersectoral coordination
  • Appropriate technologies

questions.text: A 24-year-old office worker has a strong false belief that the colleagues in his office are planning to kill him, which is not true. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delusion of persecution

 

The patient is described as having a strong false belief that others are planning to harm him, which is not grounded. This type of fixed, false belief is termed a delusion. Specifically, when the belief canters on being plotted against, it is known as a delusion of persecution 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Delusion of guilt is a false belief that one has committed some grave sin or wrongdoing.

 

Option C. Delusion of infidelity is a false belief that one's spouse or partner is being unfaithful without any substantial evidence to support this claim.

 

Option D. Othello syndrome is another name for delusional jealousy or the delusion of infidelity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Delusions are false beliefs that are unshakeable and cannot be explained based on a person's social and cultural background. A delusion of persecution specifically refers to the belief that others are plotting harm against the individual.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 345-346

questions.text: Dr. Aishwarya is a Public Health Specialist from Pune, India. She has recently been awarded a grant to establish a non-governmental organization (NGO) focused on improving maternal and child health in rural Maharashtra. As she begins to lay the foundation for her NGO, she participates in several workshops to refine her organizational strategy. One workshop emphasized the need to differentiate between planning terminologies to ensure clarity in setting the organization's direction and milestones. If Dr. Aishwarya wishes to set a broad desired outcome, which isn't typically bound by a specific time frame or limited resources, which terminology should she prioritize? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Goal

 

Goal is the Ultimate desired end point or state towards which objectives and resources are directed. It is not constrained by time or existing resources and is not necessarily attainable. 

 

Goals provide a general direction and desired outcomes for an organization or project.

 

Other Options:

 

Vision, mission and target are time line bound.

 

Option A. Vision: The ultimate impact expected out of a health program. It represents what the organization hopes to achieve in the long term and serves as a source of inspiration and motivation. While important, it is often broader and more aspirational than a goal.

 

Option B. Targets: Achievable midterm milestones. Targets are discrete activities that help measure the extent of attainment of objectives. They represent a concept of achievement and are concerned with the factors involved in addressing a problem. Targets are typically more specific and measurable compared to goals.

 

Option D. Mission: Describes how to achieve the vision. It is a statement of the fundamental principles of existence of a program, often time-bound and outlining the purpose and primary objectives of the organization. The mission is usually more specific and focused on the methods and means to achieve the vision.

 

 Educational Objective:

 

  • Vision – ultimate impact expected out of a health program
  • Mission – how to achieve the vision
  • Objectives- Short term end points.
  • Targets- Achievable midterm milestones
  • Goal-Ultimate desired end point.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic present with visual hallucinations and disorientation two days after the last alcohol intake. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Alcohol withdrawal delirium

 

The patient's presentation of visual hallucinations and disorientation two days after the cessation of alcohol intake is indicative of alcohol withdrawal delirium (often called "delirium tremens" or DTs).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alcohol withdrawal seizures: Typically occur within 24-48 hours after the last drink and are characterized by generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Option C. Alcoholic hallucination: While it can cause hallucinations, it usually does not present with the marked confusion or disorientation seen in DTs.

 

Option D. Dementia: Chronic alcohol use can lead to dementia. However, it would not typically present acutely after cessation of alcohol.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Alcohol withdrawal delirium (DTs) typically presents 48-72 hours after the last drink and is characterized by disturbances of consciousness, disorientation to time, place, and person, hallucinations (especially visual), agitation, coarse tremors and autonomic hyperactivity. It is a medical emergency requiring prompt intervention.

 

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 276-277

questions.text: A patient was brought to the OPD with history of excessive cheerfulness, increased activity, excessive talking and lack of sleep for last 10 days. What is the treatment of choice in this case? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Haloperidol.

 

The patient's presentation of excessive cheerfulness, increased activity, excessive talking, and decreased need for sleep is consistent with a manic episode. When managing acute mania, antipsychotics like haloperidol are commonly used due to their rapid onset of action and efficacy.

 

Other Options :

 

Option A. Lithium is a mood stabilizer and is effective for the long-term treatment of bipolar disorder, but its onset of action is slower, making it less ideal for acute mania.

 

Option C. Carbamazepine is also a mood stabilizer and can be used in the treatment of bipolar disorder, but it's not the first-line treatment for acute mania.

 

Option D. Lorazepam, a benzodiazepine, can be useful for initial sedation in very agitated patients but would not address the underlying manic episode on its own.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

For the acute management of mania, antipsychotics like haloperidol are preferred due to their rapid onset of action. Mood stabilizers such as lithium are more appropriate for long-term management and prevention of bipolar disorder episodes.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 373

questions.text:
A 56-year-old female with a history of MI 2 years ago presented with cough and shortness of breath on walking a few meters. Physical examination revealed dullness to percussion and reduced breath sounds on the right side. Chest X-ray showed moderate pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis was performed under USG guidance and lab investigations are given below. Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis in this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)

 

  • Pleural protein: 3.2 g/dL
  • LDH: 80 U/L
  • PF protein/Serum protein ratio: 0.34
  • Glucose: 54 mg/dL
  • ADA: 30 U/L
  • AFB smear microscopy: Negative
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Congestive cardiac failure

 

The patient has a history of myocardial infarction (MI), which increases the likelihood of heart failure, a common cause of transudative pleural effusion. The clinical presentation includes cough, shortness of breath (SOB) on minimal exertion, dullness to percussion, and reduced breath sounds, which are consistent with pleural effusion.

 

According to Light's criteria, a pleural effusion is classified as transudative if:

 

  • The pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio is less than 0.5
  • The pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio is less than 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH is less than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH

 

In this patient:

 

  • The pleural protein/serum protein ratio is 0.34, which is less than 0.5
  • The LDH level is 80 U/L, which, assuming normal serum LDH values, is likely within the criteria for transudative effusion

 

These findings suggest the pleural effusion is transudative, consistent with congestive cardiac failure, especially given the patient's history of coronary artery disease (CAD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parapneumonic effusion: This typically results in exudative effusion with high protein and LDH levels, which does not match the patient's laboratory results.

 

Option B. Malignant pleural effusion: Malignant effusions are usually exudative and would show higher protein and LDH levels along with possible presence of malignant cells, which is not supported by the patient's lab findings.

 

Option D. Tubercular pleural effusion: Tubercular effusions are also exudative with elevated ADA levels (>40 U/L typically), which is not consistent with the patient’s ADA level of 30 U/L and the overall profile.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with a history of heart disease, presenting with symptoms of pleural effusion and lab findings consistent with transudative effusion, congestive cardiac failure should be highly suspected.

questions.text: What is the likely causative organism in a 33-year-old female patient presenting with symptoms of pruritus, greenish vaginal discharge. (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Trichomonas

 

The clinical presentation of pruritus and greenish vaginal discharge points towards Trichomonas vulvovaginitis, which is caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis.

 

 

  • Most common is vaginitis
  • Etiology – Trichomonas vaginalis – flagellated protozoan
  • Mode of Spread: Sexual & non-sexual
  • Symptoms – Nature of discharge: Profuse frothy, Color of discharge: Yellowish green, Pruritis: Present
  • Signs – Discharge: serous & frothy & greenish, pH: > 5, Vulva: inflamed, Vagina: Strawberry Vagina
  • Investigation: Wet mount: motile flagellated trichomonas, Clue cells: absent, Whiff test: negative
  • Definitive Diagnosis: culture on Feinberg – Whittington media or Diamonds TYM media
  • Treatment – Metronidazole 400mg TID x 5days ‘or’ Metronidazole 2gm single dose (Mode: both partners)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Candida: Typically presents with curdy white discharge and itching, not greenish discharge.

 

Option C. Bacterial Vaginosis: Presents with foul-smelling, greyish-white discharge and no itching.

 

Option D. Chlamydia: Usually causes mucopurulent endocervical discharge, not greenish vaginal discharge.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 Trichomonas vulvovaginitis presents with profuse, frothy, greenish discharge and pruritus. It is diagnosed by identifying motile trichomonads in a wet mount and is treated with Metronidazole.

questions.text: A young female has presented to the OPD with burning sensation during urination, increased frequency and urgency. Which of the following fluoroquinolones should not be given to the patient? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Moxifloxacin

 

Moxifloxacin does not accumulate significantly in urine and is not approved for the treatment of urinary tract infections (UTIs).

 

Fluoroquinolones are DNA gyrase inhibitors. These are bactericidal drugs and may induce seizures in the patient. These are contraindicated in pregnancy and children (< 18 years of age).

 

Following Fluoroquinolones are mainly excreted by non-renal methods and thus are safe in renal failure, not effective in UTI and are avoided in liver failure:

 

  • P: Pefloxacin

  • M: Moxifloxacin

  • T: Trovafloxacin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ofloxacin: This drug is effectively excreted in the urine, making it suitable for treating UTIs due to adequate urinary concentrations.

 

Option B. Ciprofloxacin: Known for its good urinary excretion, ciprofloxacin is frequently used to treat UTIs because of its effective levels in the urinary tract.

 

Option D. Levofloxacin: Also primarily excreted in the urine, levofloxacin is effective against UTIs due to favorable urinary concentrations.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Moxifloxacin should not be used for urinary tract infections as it does not accumulate significantly in the urine and thus does not achieve therapeutic concentrations necessary for effective treatment of these infections.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman comes for her regular antenatal checkup. Which arterial gas abnormality is expected to be seen in this woman? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Chronic respiratory alkalosis

 

Chronic respiratory alkalosis is a normal physiologic change seen in pregnancy. Progesterone directly stimulates central respiratory centers to increase tidal volume and minute ventilation. This leads to increased PaO2 and decreased PaCO2. This paradoxically causes physiological dyspnea, which is an increased awareness of a desire to breathe. This results in a state of chronic respiratory alkalosis. Metabolic compensation of respiratory alkalosis leads to a decrease in bicarbonate level from approximately 26 to 22 mmol/L.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute metabolic acidosis: This condition is characterized by a rapid decrease in blood pH due to an increase in acid or a significant loss of bicarbonate. It is not typically seen in normal pregnancy.

 

Option B. Acute metabolic alkalosis: This condition involves a rapid increase in blood pH due to a loss of acid or an excess of bicarbonate. It is not a typical finding in normal pregnancy.

 

Option D. None of the above: This option is incorrect as chronic respiratory alkalosis is the expected arterial gas abnormality in pregnancy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pregnancy typically causes a state of chronic respiratory alkalosis due to progesterone-induced increased ventilation.

 

Ref: Page 63, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: High calories and high protein
Low calories and high protein
High calories and low protein
Low calories and low protein

questions.text: A 35-year-old nutritionist is discussing the nutritional differences between buffalo milk and cow's milk with her patients. Which of the following statements accurately describes buffalo milk compared to cow's milk? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. High calories and high protein

 

Buffalo milk is rich in vitamin A, has a higher protein value, high calories and contains more iron, calcium and phosphorus than the Cow’s milk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Comparative contents of nutrients in different types of milk:

 

  • Fat content of milk: Buffalo > Goat > Cow > Human
  • Protein content of milk: Buffalo > Goat > Cow > Human
  • Energy content of milk: Buffalo > Goat > Cow > Human
  • Lactose content of milk: Human > Buffalo > Goat > Cow

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in Anal Fissure? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proctoscopy

 

Anal fissure will cause extensive spasm of anal sphincter and both digital exploration and proctoscopy are contraindicated. This is due to extensive spasm of anal sphincter that causes extreme pain.

 

A proctoscopy is a procedure to examine the inside of the rectum and the anus. It is usually done to look for tumors, polyps, inflammation, bleeding, or hemorrhoids.

 

Proctoscope

 

Anal Fissure is a linear/longitudinal tear in the anal mucosa at the anal verge. It starts below dentate line and is extremely painful condition. Most commonly it occurs in the posterior midline or 6 o’ clock position.

 

It presents with bleeding per rectum (blood streaking the stools), pain and constipation.

 

 

Treatment: Lifestyle changes (High fiber diet) + Sitz Bath + Laxative.

 

Chronic Anal Fissure can have a sentinel pile / skin tag associated with it.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (Incision):
    • Incisions or cuts are not typically the first line of treatment for anal fissures. The primary treatment involves measures to ensure soft stools and reduce trauma to the anal canal. Surgical procedures, such as a lateral internal sphincterotomy, involve making a small incision in the internal anal sphincter muscle to reduce muscle tension and promote healing.
  • Option B (Topical calcium channel blockers):
    • Topical calcium channel blockers, such as diltiazem or nifedipine, are used to treat anal fissures. They work by relaxing the smooth muscle of the internal anal sphincter, decreasing muscle tone and tension, thereby improving blood supply to the region and promoting healing.
  • Option D (High fiber diet):
    • A high fiber diet is recommended for patients with an anal fissure. Fiber softens the stool and increases its bulk, reducing trauma to the anal canal during bowel movements, alleviating pain, and promoting healing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Proctoscopy is contraindicated in patients with anal fissure due to the extreme pain caused by the spasm of the anal sphincter.

questions.text: In a busy tertiary care hospital in Kolkata, Nurse Sunita was assisting a surgeon during a complicated surgical procedure. During the operation, there was an unexpected arterial bleed, and some of the blood splashed onto the operation theatre floor. Given the potential for blood-borne pathogens, it is critical to disinfect the spilled blood promptly and effectively. Nurse Sunita instructed her junior to clean the area as per the disinfection protocols. Which of the following should the junior use to disinfect the blood spill? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 1% Sodium hypochlorite

 

1% Sodium hypochlorite is widely recognized and recommended for the disinfection of blood spills in healthcare settings. It is effective against a broad range of pathogens, including viruses, bacteria, and fungi that might be present in blood.

 

The initial cleaning of the spill involves removing the bulk of the blood using a sponge, water, and detergent, which is then followed by disinfection with 1% sodium hypochlorite to ensure all potential pathogens are eradicated. This two-step process helps maintain a safe and sterile environment, crucial in an operation theatre setting.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Cresol: Cresol emulsions are very powerful disinfectants: Lysol (50 – 60% cresol). 5% cresol is used for sputum disposal. Cresol is the ideal treatment of stools to prevent contamination in Cholera epidemic. 

 

Option B. 70% Ethyl alcohol: While 70% ethyl alcohol is effective against many microbes and is commonly used for disinfecting skin and surfaces, it is not the best choice for disinfecting blood spills due to its rapid evaporation and limited efficacy against certain pathogens.

 

Option C. Glutaraldehyde: Glutaraldehyde is best high-level disinfectant used mainly for sterilizing medical instruments. It's not typically used for environmental surface disinfection like blood spills. 


Educational Objective:

 

For effectively disinfecting blood spills, especially in high-risk areas like operation theatres, 1% sodium hypochlorite is the recommended disinfectant. It ensures thorough eradication of potential blood-borne pathogens, maintaining the critical sterility required in surgical environments.

questions.text: Which of the following compounds is responsible for the development of angiosarcoma of the liver? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arsenic

 

Chronic arsenic exposure leads to the development of various liver lesions, including angiosarcoma of the liver, cirrhosis, hepatocellular carcinoma, and hepatoportal sclerosis.

 

Diseases Related to Arsenic Exposure:

 

  • Liver Lesions:
    • Angiosarcoma of the liver
    • Cirrhosis
    • Hepatocellular carcinoma
    • Hepatoportal sclerosis
  • Skin Pathology:
    • Hyperkeratosis
    • Pigmentation changes
    • Bowen disease (squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin)
    • Squamous cell carcinoma
    • Basal cell carcinoma

 

Bowen Disease:

 

  • Bowen disease is a form of squamous cell carcinoma in situ of the skin, and it has been well documented as a consequence of arsenical exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sulphur: Sulphur exposure is not linked to angiosarcoma of the liver.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium exposure is not associated with angiosarcoma of the liver.

 

Option D. Iron: Iron exposure is not associated with angiosarcoma of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chronic arsenic exposure is associated with the development of angiosarcoma of the liver, as well as other liver lesions and skin pathologies.

questions.text: A 25-year-old migraine patient has taken a drug which resulted in numbness of his hand. His hand appears like in the image shown below. Which of the following drugs is most likely to be implicated in this case? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Dihydroergotamine

 

  • The clinical scenario of history of migraine taking a drug which causes numbness is pointing towards Ergot-induced vasoconstriction. The bluish discoloration of the tips of the digits is due to peripheral vasoconstriction.

  • Dihydroergotamine is an ergot derived potent vasoconstrictor which can cause even gangrene of the organs.

  • It is also avoided in patients with coronary artery disease, Uncontrolled hypertension, within 24 hours of using triptans and peripheral vascular disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sumatriptan: It is a 5HT 1B/1D receptor agonist which causes vasoconstriction of the blood vessels. It is not indicated in patients with coronary artery disease. It is not typically associated with blue discoloration of the fingertips.

 

Option C. Butorphanol: It is an opioid analgesic, which is partial agonist at mu-receptor and full agonist at kappa receptors. It is not known to cause any peripheral vasoconstriction and its use is not indicated in migraine.

 

Option D. Aspirin: It is also not known to cause any peripheral vasoconstriction. It has an antiplatelet activity which is used to increase the blood flow by inhibiting the platelet aggregation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dihydroergotamine can cause severe peripheral vasoconstriction, leading to symptoms such as numbness and bluish discoloration of the extremities, which can be a serious concern in migraine treatment. Its use should be carefully monitored, especially in patients with existing cardiovascular issues or those susceptible to vascular complications.

choices.text: All of the following bind equally

questions.text: The major thyroxine-binding protein is? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Thyroxine -binding globulin

 

Explanation

 

Thyroxine-binding globulin (TBG) is the primary carrier of thyroid hormones (thyroxine and triiodothyronine) in the blood. It binds a significant portion of the circulating T4 and T3, more so than any other proteins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Albumin: Incorrect because although albumin has a high plasma concentration, it binds a smaller proportion of thyroid hormones compared to TBG.

 

Option B. Transthyretin: Incorrect as it binds less thyroid hormone than TBG, making it a secondary binder.

 

Option D. All of the following bind equally: Incorrect because TBG binds a significantly higher percentage of thyroid hormones than the other proteins listed.

 

Educational Objective:

choices.text: Rett syndrome
Fragile X syndrome
Eisenmenger syndrome
William syndrome

questions.text: A child has large head, large tongue and his both testicles are also large in size. The child also has features of autism spectrum disorder. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Fragile X syndrome

 

Fragile X syndrome is the second most common cause of mental retardation and is a trinucleotide repeat disorder.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Rett syndrome: Rett syndrome is a cause of acquired microcephaly. It is seen most commonly in girls and its onset starts after 6 months of life.

 

Option C. Eisenmenger syndrome: Condition seen in congenital heart diseases where there is reversal of shunt due to irreversible obstructive pulmonary vascular changes in PDA, VSD, ASD.

 

Option D. William syndrome: There is micro deletion in chromosome 7 and these individuals have hypercalcemia and supravalvular aortic stenosis and some facial dysmorphism (Thick cheeks, full cheeks).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Fragile X syndrome is characterized by intellectual disability, large head, large ears, long face, prominent jaw, large testicles, and autism spectrum disorder features. It is caused by an expansion of the CGG trinucleotide repeat in the FMR1 gene and follows an X-linked dominant inheritance pattern.

choices.text: Ischiocavernosus contraction - External urethral sphincter relaxation- Bulbospongiosus contraction
Ischiocavernosus contraction – Bulbospongiosus contraction- external urethral sphincter relaxation
Ischiocavernosus relaxation - External urethral sphincter contraction- Bulbospongiosus relaxation
Bulbospongiosus contraction - Ischiocavernosus contraction -external urethral sphincter relaxation

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct sequence of muscles used in ejaculation? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ischiocavernosus contraction – Bulbospongiosus contraction- external urethral sphincter relaxation

 

Explanation:

 

The sequences of events:

 

Ejaculation involves a series of muscle contractions that expel seminal fluid from the prostatic urethra to the exterior, encompassing both autonomic and somatic control components. The correct sequence begins with the contraction of the ischiocavernosus muscle, which aids in the erection of the penis by compressing the base of the penile shaft and obstructing blood flow out of the erect penis, thereby maintaining its rigidity. Following this, the bulbospongiosus muscle contracts, which propels the seminal fluid along the urethra. The final step is the relaxation of the external urethral sphincter, which allows the semen to exit the urethra.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of muscular contractions during ejaculation: first, the ischiocavernosus muscle contracts to maintain erection, followed by the contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle to propel seminal fluid, and finally, the relaxation of the external urethral sphincter allows the ejaculate to exit.

 

Reference - Gray’s Anatomy- the Anatomical basis of clinical practice – 42nd edition- page no. 1304

questions.text: What is the gold standard investigation performed prior to FESS (Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery)? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. CT scan

 

Before undergoing Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery (FESS), the standard and most reliable investigation is a CT scan.

 

This procedure is essential to eliminate the possibility of other underlying conditions and to confirm the diagnosis, while also assessing the scope of the disease and any anatomical irregularities. By using CT Paranasal Sinus (PNS) imaging, surgeons can effectively plan their approach for endoscopic sinus surgery, using it as a valuable guide to navigate through the sinuses.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MRI scan: While MRI provides excellent soft tissue contrast, it is less effective than a CT scan at illustrating the fine bony details necessary for sinus surgery planning.

 

Option B. Xray: Plain radiographs (X-rays) are not detailed enough for the preoperative assessment needed for FESS, as they do not provide enough information about sinus anatomy or the extent of disease.

 

Option C. Antral lavage: This is more of a therapeutic procedure used for the treatment of sinusitis rather than a diagnostic tool for pre-surgical planning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Before undergoing Functional Endoscopic Sinus Surgery, a CT scan of the paranasal sinuses is imperative. It plays a critical role in confirming the diagnosis, ruling out other conditions, and providing a clear map of the sinus anatomy to guide surgical intervention effectively.

questions.text: Dr. Priya, a senior epidemiologist at a premier medical research institution in India, has observed an alarming rise in depressive symptoms among young adults. Intrigued by this trend and recognizing the increasing usage of social media among this demographic, she postulates a possible association between the two. To ascertain if the history of social media usage might be a contributing factor to depression, she meticulously designs a study. Dr. Priya recruits two distinct groups: the first comprises social media users who have clinically been diagnosed with depression, and the second includes social media users who, after rigorous psychological assessment, show no signs of depression. Based on this setup and the approach she intends to adopt, which of the following epidemiological study methodologies is Dr. Priya most likely employing? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Case control study

 

Here we have two groups which are selected, one group already having the disease(effect) and another group not having the disease. From the effect, we will try to go backwards in this study to mark out its cause (Social media use) and find out the Odds Ratio in order to assess the strength of association between the cause and the effect. Thus, this is an example of case control study.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cohort study: In a cohort study, participants are selected based on their exposure status and are followed over time to observe the incidence of the outcome. This study is prospective and not retrospective like the case control study described.

 

Option C. Cross sectional study: A cross-sectional study examines both the exposure and the outcome at the same point in time. It is useful for determining prevalence but does not establish a cause-effect relationship as effectively as a case control study.

 

Option D. Random sampling: Random sampling is a method of selecting participants randomly from a population to ensure a representative sample. It is not a study design but a sampling technique used in various types of epidemiological studies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A case control study is an observational study design used to identify and evaluate associations between exposures and outcomes by comparing subjects with the disease (cases) and without the disease (controls). It is particularly useful for studying rare diseases or diseases with a long latency period.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents to the clinic, anxious about his health after the recent loss of his father to a cerebrovascular accident. Upon inquiry, he reveals that his father had a history of hypertension and had been on medication for the same from 15 years. The young man is concerned about his own risk and wishes to undertake measures to prevent a similar fate. In the context of public health and preventive medicine, the type of prevention he is seeking falls under which category? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Primary 

 

  • Primary - Risk factor is present (hereditary - from father), but disease is being prevented.
  • Primary level of prevention is applied when ‘risk factors are present but disease has not yet taken place’
  • It signifies ‘intervention in the Pre-pathogenesis Phase of a disease/health problem.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Primordial: Prevention of development/emergence of risk factors

 

Note - Primordial Level is Best level of prevention for Non-communicable diseases

 

Option B. Secondary: Disease is already present. Screening/early diagnosis and treatment is done in order to prevent the complications. It halts the progress of disease at its’ incipient stage and prevents complications

 

Option C. Tertiary: Complications are present, death is being prevented. Is applied when disease has advanced beyond early stages: It aims to reduce or limit impairments and disabilities, minimize suffering caused by existing departures from good health. Tertiary level of prevention signifies ‘intervention in late pathogenesis phase

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary prevention is used to reduce or eliminate risk factors and prevent the onset of disease in individuals known to be at risk due to hereditary or other predisposing factors.

 

Levels of Prevention

questions.text: A 5 -year-old child presents with development of fever, petechial spots and complaint of fatigue. He is Also having presence of pallor, hepato-splenomegaly as well as sternal tenderness. The clinical situation of the above condition is associated with which of the following? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Acute lymphoblastic leukemia  

 

Acute lymphoblastic leukemia is the most common childhood cancer.

 

Age: 2-9 years.

 

Clinical features: Anemia→ pallor, fatigue, ↑ infections, bleeding tendency, Hepatosplenomegaly, CNS involvement, Bone pain (sternal tenderness)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML): More common in adults, with symptoms such as anemia, infection, and bleeding, but it typically presents with myeloblasts on peripheral smear rather than lymphoblasts.

 

Option C. Chronic Lymphocytic Leukemia (CLL): Rare in children, more common in older adults, characterized by an indolent course and often asymptomatic lymphocytosis.

 

Option D. Chronic Myeloid Leukemia (CML): Typically presents in middle-aged adults, characterized by marked leukocytosis with a significant number of myelocytes and metamyelocytes, along with splenomegaly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The combination of fever, petechial spots, fatigue, pallor, hepatosplenomegaly, and sternal tenderness in a child is highly suggestive of Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia (ALL).

choices.text: Retention cyst of major salivary glands
Most common site is lower lip
Retention cyst of minor salivary glands

questions.text: Which is the false statement among the following for the condition given in the picture? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Retention cyst of major salivary glands

 

The picture shows a mucocele located on the lower lip, which is essentially a retention cyst arising from the minor salivary glands of the lip.

 

MUCOCELE

 

  • Most common site is the lower lip
  • It is a retention cyst of minor salivary glands of the lip
  • The lesion appears as a soft and cystic mass of bluish color
  • Treatment is surgical excision.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Most common site is lower lip: This is a true statement as mucoceles most frequently occur on the lower lip.

 

Option C. Retention cyst of minor salivary glands: This is also true and accurately describes the nature of a mucocele.

 

Option D. Treatment is surgical excision: True, the recommended treatment for a mucocele is surgical excision to prevent recurrence and ensure complete removal of the glandular tissue involved.

 

Educational Objective:
