Mucoceles are retention cysts of the minor salivary glands commonly found on the lower lip and should not be confused with cysts of the major salivary glands. Treatment typically involves surgical excision to remove the cyst and associated glandular tissue to prevent recurrence.

questions.text: After returning from a malaria-endemic area in sub-Saharan Africa, Sarah, who took preventive measures during her trip, consults you about continuing her malaria chemoprophylaxis. How long should she continue the treatment to effectively prevent malaria? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 4 weeks

 

Continuing chemoprophylaxis for 4 weeks after leaving a malaria-endemic region is essential to ensure coverage during the entire potential incubation period of the malaria parasite. This period allows for the effective management of any latent parasites that may become active after Sarah has returned.

 

Drugs used for malaria chemoprophylaxis in India:

 

Doxycycline – it is used for short term (<6 weeks) chemoprophylaxis, started 2 days before travel to a malaria endemic country continued throughout the stay and after return continued till 4 weeks. It is given at a dose of 100 mg daily.

 

Mefloquine – Used for long term (>6 week) chemoprophylaxis. Started 2-3weeks before and continued throughout the stay and after return continued till 4 weeks. It is given as 250 mg weekly.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For optimal protection against malaria after travel to an endemic area, it's recommended to continue chemoprophylaxis for 4 weeks. This duration covers the incubation period of the parasite, ensuring any late-developing infections are prevented.

questions.text: In fatty liver, which is not given: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Ethanol

 

Ethanol (alcohol) is a substance that should not be given in the case of fatty liver, especially alcoholic fatty liver disease. Alcohol consumption can exacerbate liver damage and is one of the leading causes of fatty liver disease. Therefore, abstinence from alcohol is crucial in managing this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Choline: Choline is often recommended for the treatment of fatty liver disease. It is an essential nutrient that plays a vital role in lipid metabolism. Choline deficiency can lead to fat accumulation in the liver, so supplementing with choline can help in the management of fatty liver disease.

 

 Option C. Folic acid: Folic acid, a type of B vitamin, may be beneficial in the management of fatty liver disease. It plays a role in methylation processes and helps in the metabolism of homocysteine, which is linked to liver disease. Folic acid supplementation can support liver health.

 

 Option D. Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that is sometimes used in the treatment of fatty liver disease. It is involved in many detoxification processes in the liver and is a precursor to S-adenosylmethionine (SAMe), a compound involved in methylation pathways critical for liver health.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LIPOTROPIC FACTORS

 

  • These are factors which are required for the synthesis of phospholipids. They help in mobilization of TG out of liver cells. Their deficiency leads to Fatty Liver (due to TG accumulation in liver)
  • Lipotropic factors:
    • EFA/PUFAs
    • Vitamins- B9 and B12
    • Choline, Betaine and Inositol
    •  Three amino acids
      1. Serine
      2. Glycine
      3. Methionine

 

Lipotropic factors reverse the effects of fatty liver by mobilization of TG out of liver. Ethanol on the other hand can cause increased formation of fat synthesis in liver due to excess NADH/NAD ratio which inhibit acetyl CoA oxidation for energy through TCA and ETC thereby increasing the flux of acetyl CoA in the fatty acid synthesis in liver.

 

Ref: Textbook of Medical Biochemistry by Dinesh Puri 3rd ed/p 249-250

questions.text: A 10-year-old child was brought to the OPD following a sting on his toe. On examination, he had tachycardia, hypertension, tongue fasciculation, hypersalivation, and dilated pupils. Local examination of the wound showed mild erythema. He remembers the animal having a curved tail upwards. Which of the following has most likely bitten him? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Scorpion

 

The clinical presentation of tachycardia, hypertension, tongue fasciculation, hypersalivation, and dilated pupils, along with the description of the animal having a curved tail upwards, is indicative of a scorpion sting. Scorpion venom causes an autonomic storm by releasing excess catecholamines, leading to the observed symptoms such as hypertension, tachycardia, pulmonary edema, restlessness, and seizures.

 

Management:

 

  • Prazosin: Used to counteract the adrenergic surge.
  • Supportive care: Includes monitoring and managing symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Caterpillar: Caterpillar stings generally cause local irritant effects, such as pain, itching, and erythema. They do not produce the systemic autonomic symptoms seen in this case.

 

Option B. Sea urchin: Sea urchin stings also cause localized pain and irritation.

 

Option D. Black widow spider: The bite of a black widow spider can cause latrodectism, which involves systemic symptoms like diffuse muscle rigidity and cramping, abdominal tenderness, nausea, and vomiting due to high catecholamine release. However, the child’s description of the animal with a curved tail upwards and the combination of symptoms is more consistent with a scorpion sting.

 

Treatment: BZD/Opioids

 

Educational Objective:

 

Scorpion stings can cause severe systemic effects due to an autonomic storm characterized by excessive catecholamine release, leading to symptoms such as hypertension, tachycardia, hypersalivation, and dilated pupils. The characteristic description of the animal with a curved tail upwards aids in identifying the scorpion as the culprit.

choices.text: Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with severe dysmenorrhea; dyspareunia infertility and a diagnosis of endometriosis was made. The patient was posted for laparoscopy and at surgery dense pelvic adhesions were seen with bowel stuck to the fundus. Ovaries were cystic and stuck to each other. What is the next step of management in this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cystectomy and adhesiolysis

 

Explanation:

 

  • The clinical scenario is suggestive of endometriosis, characterized by severe dysmenorrhea, dyspareunia, infertility, and the presence of dense pelvic adhesions observed during laparoscopy.
  • In endometriosis, the management approach differs based on the primary concern:
    • For infertility: Surgery is generally preferred to improve fertility outcomes. This involves cystectomy and adhesiolysis to remove endometriotic cysts and adhesions, thereby restoring normal pelvic anatomy and improving the chances of conception.
    • For pain management: Medical treatment is often the first line. However, in this scenario where infertility is also a concern, surgical intervention is prioritized.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. LUNA for chronic pelvic pain: Laparoscopic uterosacral nerve ablation (LUNA) is used for severe pelvic pain associated with endometriosis that is not relieved by medication. It is not the first choice when infertility is also an issue.

 

Option B. Gestrinone to decrease the LH surge: Gestrinone is a progesterone derivative used in the medical management of endometriosis to alleviate pain. However, it is not suitable when fertility is a primary concern, as it does not address the mechanical and structural problems caused by endometriotic cysts and adhesions.

 

Option D. Hysterectomy and oophorectomy: Hysterectomy and oophorectomy are considered definitive treatments for endometriosis but are not suitable for a young woman seeking fertility. This approach is more appropriate for patients who have completed their families or are in severe, refractory pain not managed by other means.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of endometriosis with associated infertility, surgical management involving cystectomy and adhesiolysis is preferred to improve fertility outcomes.

 

Ref: Page 249, DC Duttas Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient presented with a thyroid swelling, weight loss and cervical lymphadenopathy. For the thyroid swelling, Total thyroidectomy with radical lymph node dissection was performed. Histopathology report of the resected specimen is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

The Histological picture shows thyroid follicles lined with cells with large empty looking Nuclei called as “Orphan Annie eye nuclei”. This is a feature of papillary carcinoma of thyroid. It shows lymphatic spread which explains the cervical lymphadenopathy.

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B (Follicular carcinoma thyroid):
    • It shows hematogenous spread and requires biopsy for confirmation due to capsular invasion.
  • Option C (Hyperparathyroidism):
    • Not related to thyroid carcinoma; involves parathyroid glands.
  • Option D (Anaplastic carcinoma thyroid):
    • Presents with a rapidly enlarging neck mass and compressive symptoms, not typically with Orphan Annie eye nuclei.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Papillary carcinoma thyroid is identified by the presence of Orphan Annie eye nuclei, lymphatic spread, and specific genetic mutations (BRAF, RET/PTC).

choices.text: 24 hours urinary V.M.A levels

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents with sweating, headache, anxiety and palpitations. On examination, her heart rate is 110/min and BP 140/100 mm Hg. She gives history of Renal cell cancer in her mother. What would be the investigation of choice in this patient? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Plasma free metanephrines

 

 

The symptoms described (sweating, headache, anxiety, palpitations) are suggestive of pheochromocytoma. The history of renal cell carcinoma in the patient's mother indicates a possible VHL gene mutation, as patients who inherit this mutation can develop pheochromocytomas. The investigation of choice for screening pheochromocytoma is plasma free metanephrines due to its high sensitivity.

 

Pheochromocytoma:

 

  • Origin: Chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla.
  • Gene Mutations: RET, VHL, NF-1, SDH-B.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Most Common Symptom: Headache.
  • Most Common Sign: Hypertension.
  • Other Symptoms: Sweating, palpitations.
  • Rule of 10s: 10% bilateral, 10% familial, 10% malignant, 10% in children, 10% extra-adrenal.
  • Associated Conditions: MEN 2, NF-1, VHL, Familial Paraganglioma syndromes (SDH-B gene mutation).

 

Investigations:

 

  • Screening: 24-hour urinary VMA (vanillylmandelic acid).
  • Most Sensitive: Plasma free metanephrine level.
  • Investigation of Choice (IOC): MRI, which shows the light bulb sign.
  • For Extra-Adrenal Pheochromocytoma: Gallium DOTATATE scan.

 

Management:

 

  • Medical Management: Alpha-blocker (Phenoxybenzamine) followed by beta-blocker to prevent hypertensive crisis.
  • Surgical Management: Surgery is the definitive treatment. In case of intra-operative hypertensive crisis, IV Phentolamine can be used.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (Renal cysts):
    • Renal cysts are not relevant to the diagnosis or investigation of pheochromocytoma.
  • Option B (Serum hydroxy-tryptamine levels):
    • Serum hydroxy-tryptamine levels are not used for diagnosing pheochromocytoma.
  • Option C (24-hour urinary V.M.A levels):
    • 24-hour urinary VMA levels can be used for screening but are less sensitive than plasma free metanephrines for detecting pheochromocytoma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The investigation of choice for suspected pheochromocytoma is plasma free metanephrines due to its high sensitivity, especially in the context of a family history suggestive of a genetic predisposition.

questions.text: A 34-year-old G2P1L1 presents with abdominal pain, bleeding per vaginum in labour and loss of fetal movements. She occasionally smokes but does not consume alcohol or recreational drugs. On examination, her pulse rate is 80 bpm and BP is 150/90 mm of Hg and a tense abdomen on palpation. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Abruption placenta

 

Explanation:

 

  • Painful vaginal bleeding after 28 weeks is suggestive of abruption
  • Abruption is premature separation of a normally implanted placenta
  • It presents as an acute emergency requiring urgent delivery
  • Other clues in this scenario
    • Loss of fetal movements: Abruption is commonly associated with fetal distress/ death
    • Tense abdomen: Typically seen in abruption
    • High BP: Hypertension in pregnancy is commonly associated with abruption

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Placenta previa:

 

  • Typically presents as painless vaginal bleeding
  • Commonly presents as recurrent episodes of bleeding
  • Abdomen is soft and non tender
  • High BP is not a risk factor
  • Fetal distress is rare unless the bleeding is excessive

 

Option C. Hydramnios:

 

  • This present as a tense, overdistended abdomen due to which the patient will be uncomfortable and may have respiratory distress in severe cases
  • FHR is difficult to hear
  • Vaginal bleed is rare unless associated with abruption

 

Option D. Preterm labor:

 

  • This would present as regular contractions (abdominal pain) before 37 weeks
  • Vaginal bleeding will not be seen (Show may be seen)
  • Fetal heart will be normal
  • The uterus will not be tense or tender, but contractions will be appreciated
  • There wil be associated cervical dilatation and effacement

 

Educational objective:

 

Painful vaginal bleeding with loss of fetal movements and tense abdomen after 28 weeks is suggestive of abruptio placentae.

 

Ref: Page 295, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A farmer was brought to the emergency department with a history of snake bite from the snake shown in the picture below. During treatment of the snake bite the patient died. What is the main cause of death in this patient? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Respiratory paralysis

 

The snake shown in the picture is a krait.

 

In krait bites, cramping abdominal pain followed by diarrhea and collapse may occur.

 

Cause of death - Respiratory paralysis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Heart failure: While snake venom can have various effects on the cardiovascular system, heart failure is not the primary cause of death in krait envenomation.

 

Option C. Shock: Shock can occur in various types of snake bites, particularly those that cause severe bleeding or anaphylactic reactions, but it is not the main cause of death in krait bites.

 

Option D. Coagulopathy: Coagulopathy is more commonly associated with bites from snakes like vipers, whose venom contains hemotoxins that affect blood clotting. Krait venom is neurotoxic, not hemotoxic.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary cause of death in krait envenomation is respiratory paralysis due to the neurotoxic effects of the venom.

questions.text: A patient is presents with pain along the course of trigeminal nerve while speaking and chewing. Which of the following drug should be given for the management? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Carbamazepine

 

The patient's symptoms are indicative of trigeminal neuralgia, a condition characterized by severe, episodic facial pain along the distribution of the trigeminal nerve. Carbamazepine, a sodium-channel blocker, is the drug of choice for this condition. It works by stabilizing hyperactive neurons, reducing neuronal firing, and thus alleviating pain. Carbamazepine is particularly effective in treating neuralgia because it directly targets the nerve impulse transmission at the level of the sodium channel, which is often hyperactive in this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lamotrigine: it is also an anticonvulsant which is used to treat neuropathic pain but it is not used as a first line treatment in Trigeminal Neuralgia as it is not as effective and efficacious as Carbamazepine and Oxcarbazepine.

 

Option C. Phenobarbitone: Due to its limited efficacy, sedative effects, tolerance and dependence with long term use, it is not used in management of trigeminal neuralgia.

 

Option D. Haloperidol: it is an antipsychotic medication used for management of schizophrenia and bipolar disorder. It doesn’t possess any analgesic properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carbamazepine is the preferred initial treatment for trigeminal neuralgia due to its effectiveness in reducing the hyperactivity of sodium channels that contributes to the neuropathic pain characteristic of this condition.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female with a history of recurrent headaches presented for further evaluation. Evaluation revealed normal hemoglobin and WBC counts with elevated platelet count. Bone marrow showed increased megakaryocytes and JAK2 mutation. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Essential thrombocytosis (ET)

 

Patient has unexplained elevated platelet counts. Most common causes are reactive, however in presence of JAK2 mutation it is suggestive of Essential thrombocytosis.

 

Essential Thrombocytosis (ET):

 

  • Presentation: Often includes symptoms related to abnormal blood clotting or bleeding, such as headaches, visual disturbances, or thrombosis.
  • Laboratory Findings: Elevated platelet count with normal hemoglobin and WBC counts.
  • Bone Marrow: Increased number of megakaryocytes.
  • Genetics: Frequently associated with mutations in the JAK2, CALR, or MPL genes.

 

Myeloproliferative neoplasms are disorders characterized by increased differentiation of myeloid lineage cells. These include CML, ET, PCV (Polycythemia vera), primary myelofibrosis (PMF)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Polycythemia vera (PV): Characterized by an increase in red blood cell mass, leading to elevated hemoglobin levels. The absence of increased hemoglobin makes PV unlikely in this patient.

 

Option C. Chronic myelogenous leukemia (CML): Characterized by the presence of the BCR-ABL translocation (Philadelphia chromosome). It usually presents with elevated WBC counts, which is not seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Primary myelofibrosis (PMF): Can have overlapping features with ET and may also have JAK2 mutations. However, PMF typically presents with more severe symptoms, including splenomegaly and bone marrow fibrosis. This patient's clinical presentation and lack of significant splenomegaly or fibrosis point more towards ET.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Essential thrombocytosis (ET) is indicated by an elevated platelet count, normal hemoglobin and WBC counts, increased megakaryocytes in the bone marrow, and the presence of JAK2 mutation. It is one of the myeloproliferative neoplasms, characterized primarily by increased platelet production.

questions.text: A child ingested a bottle full of iron tablets. Which drug is used as antidote for poisoning? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Desferrioxamine

 

  • In cases of acute iron poisoning, the antidote used for iron chelation is Desferrioxamine. It is given IV.

  • It is a chelating agent that binds to excess iron in the body and forms a complex that can be excreted through urine. This helps to reduce the toxic effects of iron overload.

  • Deferipirone is oral chelating agent for iron. It is drug of choice of chronic iron overload

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Luspatercept: It is a fusion protein that acts by modifying the activity of certain proteins involved in RBC production. It is recently FDA-approved drug used for the treatment of anemia in adult patients with Beta-Thalassemia and Myelodysplastic syndrome.

 

Option C. EDTA: It is the antidote of choice in Lead poisoning and is administered via intravenous route.

 

Option D. DMSA: It is the oral agent of choice in treatment of Lead poisoning, especially in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Desferrioxamine is the crucial antidote for acute iron poisoning, efficiently chelating excess iron and facilitating its excretion through the urine, thereby rapidly reducing the toxicity associated with iron overdose.

questions.text: A mother brought her 16-year-old daughter to the hospital with complaints of primary amenorrhea. On evaluation axillary and pubic hair were present and other secondary sexual characteristics normal. USG showed absence of uterus. What is the next step in diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Karyotyping

 

Explanation:

 

  • The probable diagnosis is MRKH syndrome (mullerian agenesis) and the next step in the diagnosis is karyotyping.
  • MRKH syndrome (46XX) presents with primary amenorrhoea in the presence of secondary sexual characters with an absent uterus

 

Evaluation of primary amenorrhoea

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Testosterone levels: Measuring testosterone levels would be more relevant if androgen insensitivity syndrome (AIS) was suspected. In AIS, patients typically have a 46XY karyotype and elevated testosterone levels.

 

Option C. Estrogen measurement: Estrogen levels might provide some information about ovarian function, but they are not specific for diagnosing the absence of the uterus or differentiating between possible underlying causes of primary amenorrhea.

 

Option D. LH and FSH measurement: While these measurements are useful in evaluating gonadal function and hypothalamic-pituitary axis, they are not as specific as karyotyping in diagnosing MRKH syndrome or other structural anomalies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a 16-year-old girl presenting with primary amenorrhea, normal secondary sexual characteristics, and an absent uterus on ultrasound, the next diagnostic step should be karyotyping to confirm the diagnosis of MRKH syndrome or other potential conditions.

 

Ref: Page no 451, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: A 1-year-old male child brought with urinary retention was found to have bilateral hydronephrosis. The mother gives a history of recurrent urinary tract infections in the child since birth. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Posterior urethral valve

 

The given scenario points towards a young male child with a history of recurrent urinary tract infections and urinary retention, combined with the finding of bilateral hydronephrosis. These are typical features of Posterior Urethral Valve (PUV), especially in male infants.

 

  • This is an obstructive defect in the male urethra, where an abnormal valve-like tissue in the posterior urethra prevents normal urine flow. The urine then backs up, causing swelling (hydronephrosis) of the ureters and kidneys. It can also cause bladder distention and thickening. The urinary retention and recurrent UTIs are common in affected infants, making this the most probable diagnosis in the given scenario. Most of time it is picked up antenatally by USG as it leads to Bilateral hydronephrosis and is seen as a ‘Keyhole Defect’.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. PUJ obstruction: PUJ stands for Pelvi-Ureteric Junction. A PUJ obstruction is a blockage at the junction where the renal pelvis meets the ureter. This obstruction leads to hydronephrosis (swelling of a kidney). While this can cause hydronephrosis, it typically wouldn't be the direct cause of recurrent UTIs or urinary retention in a young male child.

 

Option C. Horseshoe kidney: This is a congenital condition where the two kidneys are joined together at the lower end, forming a U-shape that looks like a horseshoe. While it can be associated with hydronephrosis and UTIs, it's not the most common cause of urinary retention in male infants.

 

Option D. Retrocaval ureter: This is a rare congenital anomaly where the right ureter passes behind and is compressed by the inferior vena cava. It can cause unilateral hydronephrosis.

 

Given the age of the child, the clinical presentation, and the findings on evaluation, Posterior Urethral Valve (Option B) is the most likely diagnosis.

 

 

Antenatal USG showing Keyhole deformity (Posterior Urethral Valve)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Posterior urethral valve (PUV) is the most likely cause of urinary retention, recurrent UTIs, and bilateral hydronephrosis in a young male child. It is characterized by an abnormal valve-like tissue in the posterior urethra obstructing urine flow.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis of the condition shown in the image which has been progressively increasing for the last 6 months? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Malignant melanoma

 

The image shown above is of a nevus which looks malignant due to following features (ABCDE):

 

 

Thus, this points towards the diagnosis of Malignant Melanoma.

 

Malignant melanoma, is a type of cancer that develops from the pigment-containing cells known as melanocytes.

 

 

 

Squamous Cell Cancer

 

 

Basal Cell Cancer (Note the true palisading on the histology image on left)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malignant melanoma is identified by asymmetry, irregular borders, multiple colors, a diameter larger than 1/4 inch, and changes over time. It has a high risk of metastasis and requires prompt diagnosis and treatment.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man was receiving treatment for a high-grade soft-tissue sarcoma with radiotherapy. Unresponsive to the treatment, he was shifted to chemotherapy. Following chemotherapy, he developed erythematous rashes over the areas where radiotherapy was administered earlier. Which of the following drugs is most likely implicated in this condition? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Doxorubicin

 

  • Given clinical scenario (Radiotherapy followed by chemotherapy leading to erythematous rashes) is pointing towards Radiation Recall Syndrome. It is most commonly caused by Doxorubicin.

  • Radiation Recall Syndrome is believed to result from the interaction between radiation therapy and certain drugs. When specific chemotherapy agents are given after radiation therapy, they can recall or trigger an inflammatory reaction in the previously irradiated tissues, manifesting as redness, swelling, blistering and skin rashes, similar to an acute radiation reaction. 

  • Doxorubicin is an anthracycline which inhibits DNA Topoisomerase II and affects the ability of DNA to unwind itself and replicate during cell division.

  • Apart from Radiation Recall Syndrome, Doxorubicin is also been known to cause Cardiotoxicity due to production of free radicals. This can be prevented by administration of Dexrazoxane (cytoprotective drug)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vincristine: This drug, a part of the vinca alkaloid class, interferes with microtubule formation but is not commonly associated with Radiation Recall Syndrome.

 

Option C. Cyclophosphamide: Although it's an alkylating agent used in various chemotherapeutic protocols, it does not typically cause Radiation Recall Syndrome.

 

Option D. 6-mercaptopurine: This antimetabolite drug is used primarily in the treatment of leukemia and is not linked to the induction of Radiation Recall Syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Doxorubicin can trigger Radiation Recall Syndrome in previously irradiated areas when administered post-radiotherapy. This syndrome is an inflammatory reaction that mimics acute radiation effects, and awareness of this potential reaction is crucial for managing patients undergoing combined modalities of cancer treatment. Additionally, it's important to recognize the cardiotoxic risk associated with doxorubicin, which can be mitigated with the concurrent use of cytoprotective drugs like Dexrazoxane.

questions.text: An operated appendix specimen is shown below. Patient had raised serum chromogranin levels. What is likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Carcinoid tumor

 

The image shows a well-circumscribed yellow appearance of a tumor in the appendix specimen, which is suggestive of a carcinoid tumor.

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors.

 

Origin:

 

  • They arise from APUD cells or enterochromaffin cells (Kulchitsky cells) in Lieberkuhn.

 

Gross Features:

 

  • Carcinoid tumors are benign, encapsulated, and slow-growing. They release serotonin.
  • The most common site of carcinoid tumors is the gastrointestinal tract (GIT), specifically the small bowel, followed by the lungs.
  • In the small bowel, the most common site of a carcinoid tumor is the appendix.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Due to increased serotonin levels, patients may experience flushing, diarrhea, and bronchospasm. However, these symptoms only occur if there are liver metastases, as serotonin is metabolized in the liver.
  • Cardiac valvular defects such as tricuspid incompetence (most common) and pulmonary stenosis (least common) can also occur.

 

Tumor Markers:

 

  • The tumor markers for carcinoid tumors include 5-HIAA and chromogranin A, indicating neuroendocrine origin.

 

Investigations:

 

  • The investigation of choice (IOC) for carcinoid tumors is measuring urinary levels of 5-HIAA.
  • For localization, the Ga-68 DOTATATE scan is used.

 

Treatment:

 

  • The primary treatment for carcinoid tumors is surgical excision with lymph node removal.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (Colorectal cancer):
    • Colorectal cancer typically does not present with raised serum chromogranin levels and has different pathological and clinical features.
  • Option B (Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma):
    • Mucinous cystadenocarcinoma is a type of epithelial tumor, not associated with raised serum chromogranin levels.
  • Option C (Cystic tumor):
    • Cystic tumors can be benign or malignant but are not characterized by raised serum chromogranin levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors that arise from enterochromaffin cells, most commonly in the appendix, and are associated with raised serum chromogranin levels and serotonin release.

questions.text: 35-year-old female with fever, weight loss, elevated levels of ACE levels presented with chest X-ray as below. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sarcoidosis

 

Explanation

 

The clinical scenario with elevated ACE levels and bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is suggestive of sarcoidosis.

 

SARCOIDOSIS

 

  • C/F: Fever with dry cough, bilateral hilar lymph nodes are enlarged.
  •  

Non caseating/non-necrotic lymph nodes – Sarcoidosis

(Vs Necrotic lymph nodes - TB)

 

  • Characteristic lab findings: Increased ACE levels, Hypercalcemia
  • Chest X-Ray - 1-2-3 sign / Garland Sign
  • Gallium scan - Lambda sign / Panda sign

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. TB (Tuberculosis): Typically presents with a more localized infection, often with cavitation and necrotic lymph nodes, which are not evident here.

 

Option C. Silicosis: A pneumoconiosis that would show more diffuse nodular opacities predominantly in the upper lobes, not just the hilar lymphadenopathy.

 

Option D. Lymphoma: Could also present with lymphadenopathy, but would more likely show mediastinal widening and may not correlate with elevated ACE levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a patient presenting with systemic symptoms, elevated ACE levels, and a chest X-ray showing bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, sarcoidosis is a likely diagnosis. This condition's management requires a comprehensive approach involving respiratory, rheumatological, and sometimes dermatological evaluation due to its systemic nature.

choices.text: Taste sensation of posterior one-third of tongue is lost
Taste sensation of anterior two-third of tongue is lost
General sensation of posterior one-third of tongue is lost
General sensation of anterior two-third of tongue is lost

questions.text: During submandibular gland tumor removal lingual nerve was found to be damaged. Which of the following statement is correct? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. General sensation of anterior two-third of tongue is lost

 

Explanation:

 

General sensation from the anterior 2/3rd of the tongue is carried by the lingual nerve, which is injured in this case.

 

Lingual nerve damage results in the loss of general sensation from the anterior two-thirds of the tongue. The lingual nerve, a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve (V3), carries general sensory information from this area.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A: Incorrect because taste sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue is carried by the glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial nerve IX), not affected by lingual nerve damage.

 

Option B: Incorrect as the chorda tympani (a branch of the facial nerve, VII), which carries taste sensation from the anterior two-thirds, is not impacted by lingual nerve injury.

 

Option C: Incorrect because general sensation of the posterior one-third of the tongue is primarily mediated by the glossopharyngeal nerve (IX), unrelated to the lingual nerve.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sensory supply of the tongue

 

Anterior two-thirds: Lingual nerve (a branch of the mandibular division of the trigeminal nerve – V3), which carries General sensation from the respective part.

 

Chorda Tympani (Branch of Facial nerve 7th cranial nerve) carries the special sense i.e., Taste Sensation from Anterior two-third part of tongue.

 

Taste sensation from Posterior one-third carried by Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial nerve IX),

 

Taste sensation from Posterior most part of tongue carried by small branch of the internal laryngeal nerve (branch of the vagus nerve, cranial nerve X).

questions.text: In a Train accident, the morbidity and mortality chart were as follows- 74 dead, 64 were severely injured, 20 moderately injured and 32 mildly injured. Color-coding in triage highest to lowest category is? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Red – Yellow – Green – Black

 

In triage, patients are prioritized based on the severity of their injuries and the urgency of their need for treatment. The color-coding system used in triage is as follows:

 

  • Red: Most critically injured patients who need immediate treatment right now.
  • Yellow: Less critical patients who need urgent treatment within hours.
  • Green: Patients with no limb or life-threatening injury who are likely to survive even if treatment is delayed by hours or days.
  • Black: Moribund patients, non-breathing or pulseless, who are not expected to survive.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A.  White – Yellow – Red – Black: Incorrect. The color-coding sequence is not used in triage.

 

Option B. Yellow – Red – Green – Black: Incorrect. The order is incorrect for triage priority.

 

Option C. Black – Blue – Red – Green: Incorrect. This sequence does not represent the correct triage color-coding system.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In triage, the correct color-coding sequence from highest to lowest priority is Red, Yellow, Green, and Black, ensuring that critically injured patients receive immediate treatment.

questions.text: Identify the clinical condition from the skin finding as given below? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chicken pox

 

Chickenpox is a very contagious infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus. It mainly affects kids, but adults can get It, too. The tell-tale sign of chickenpox is a super-itchy skin rash with red blisters.

 

 

 

Various techniques can be used to visualize VZV.

 

  1. Electron microscopy:  provide high-resolution images of viral particles, not routinely used for diagnosis due to its complexity and limited availability.
  2. Immunofluorescence assay (IFA): This technique involves the use of specific antibodies that bind to VZV antigens, which can then be visualized under a fluorescent microscope. Immunofluorescence staining can provide a rapid and specific detection of VZV in certain laboratory settings.
  3. Polymerase chain reaction (PCR): PCR assays targeting VZV DNA can be used to confirm the presence of the virus in clinical samples. This method is highly sensitive and specific and can be employed in research or specialized laboratory settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Influenza virus: Typically causes respiratory symptoms such as fever, cough, and body aches, and is not associated with a blistering skin rash.

 

Option C. HPV: Human papillomavirus (HPV) causes warts, which appear as small, rough growths on the skin, not as a blistering rash.

 

Option D. Measles: Characterized by a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward, along with high fever, cough, runny nose, and conjunctivitis, but not the blistering rash seen in chickenpox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, presents with a characteristic itchy, blistering rash that can be rapidly diagnosed using methods such as immunofluorescence assay (IFA) and PCR.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with history of dysphagia, halitosis and aspiration pneumonia. A barium swallow was done and is given below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Zenker’s diverticulum

 

The given picture displays a pouch-like structure exhibiting a notable contrast, aiding in the identification and diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum.

 

  • Symptoms of dysphagia after few swallows, gurgling sound while swallowing and regurgitation of undigested food is suggestive of Zenker’s diverticulum or hypopharyngeal pouch.
  • Most common site is Killian’s dehiscence which lies between the horizontal fibers cricopharyngeus and oblique fibers of thyropharyngeus.
  • It is a pseudo-diverticulum (pulsion diverticulum)
  • It occurs due to the incoordination between Thyropharyngeus (supplied by glossopharyngeal nerve (IX)) and Cricopharyngeus (supplied by External laryngeal nerve (X)).
  • Dohlman’s procedure is done for Zenker’s diverticulum

 

 

Ba Swallow of Zenker’s diverticulum

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diffuse esophageal spasm: This condition would typically present with chest pain and intermittent dysphagia, but would not create a visible pouch on a barium swallow.

 

Option B. Achalasia cardia: Characterized by the failure of the lower esophageal sphincter to relax, achalasia would show a dilated esophagus with a bird-beak appearance at the gastroesophageal junction, not a diverticulum.

 

Option D. Esophageal cancer: This might cause irregular narrowing or mass effect in the esophagus, typically not forming a diverticular structure as seen in Zenker's.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Zenker's diverticulum should be suspected in elderly patients presenting with dysphagia, halitosis, and regurgitation of undigested food. It is a pseudo-diverticulum that forms at Killian’s dehiscence and is managed surgically, typically by a procedure known as Dohlman’s procedure to prevent complications such as aspiration pneumonia

questions.text: A patient with head and neck cancer was told by his oncologist that he needs radiotherapy at a total dose of 60 Gy over a 6-week period for his tumor. He was scheduled to receive a dose of 1 Gy per fraction, once daily over 6 days a week, for 6 weeks. What is this type of radiotherapy called?(FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Regular Fractionated radiotherapy

 

Explanation

 

This method of dividing the total dose in multiple fractions with a break in between is called Regular/Conventional Fractionated Radiotherapy.

 

Fractionated RT: 5Rs

 

  1. Repair - for normal surrounding cells
  2. Repopulation
  3. Reoxygenation
  4. Reassortment /Redistribution
  5. Radiosensitivity

 

CHART   

 

  • It stands for: Continuous Hyper fractionated Accelerated RadioTherapy
  • Used for: Non-small cell Ca lung

 

Hypo fractionated Radiotherapy  

 

The entire dose is given as single regime.

 

  • Commonly used in bone metastasis for palliation
  • ~ 8 Gy dose is given in bone metastasis

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Hyperfractionated Radiotherapy: Involves smaller doses given more than once a day, which isn't the case here.

 

Option C. Accelerated Fractionation Radiotherapy: Has a shorter overall treatment time with the same total dose, usually by giving more than one fraction per day.

 

Option D. Brachytherapy: Involves placing radioactive sources close to or inside the tumor, which is different from the external beam radiotherapy described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Regular or conventional fractionated radiotherapy is a standard approach in treating cancers, including head and neck cancers. It balances the efficacy of radiation in controlling the tumor with the need to minimize side effects by allowing healthy tissue recovery time between treatments.

questions.text: A 42-year-old female patient with dysphagia underwent a barium swallow whose image is shown. what is the diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Achalasia cardia

 

The given barium swallow image shows smooth tapering of the lower distal esophagus giving a characteristic ‘Bird Beak or Rat Tail appearance’. This is characteristic of Achalasia Cardia.

 

Achalasia Cardia is a rare disorder that makes it difficult for food and liquid to pass from the esophagus. Pathologically, Achalasia cardia is caused by loss of inhibitory ganglion in the myenteric plexus of the esophagus. This leads to loss of LES relaxation, and consequently elevated LES pressure & loss of peristaltic movements.

 

It is associated with Chagas disease, Allgrove syndrome.

 

The hallmark of the Xray of achalasia cardia is a gradually tapering, smooth, conical narrowing (bird’s beak or rat-tail appearance) of the distal esophageal segment.

 

Investigations: Upper GI endoscopy with Esophageal Manometry

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nutcracker Esophagus: It is also called as Jackhammer Esophagus. It is the most common hypermotility disorder of esophagus. The patient presents with chest pain which mimics cardiac chest pain and dysphagia.

 

For diagnosis, Castell Criteria is used - Mean Peristaltic amplitude more than 180 mm Hg and Presence of two or more contractions that are greater than six seconds in duration.

 

Option B. Esophageal Cancer: The patient is generally an elderly with complaints of dysphagia more to liquid than solid. On barium swallow, tapering of the distal esophagus will be seen with irregular margins.

 

 

Option D. Esophagitis: On barium swallow, concentric rings are seen.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Achalasia Cardia is characterized by a loss of inhibitory ganglion in the esophageal myenteric plexus, leading to loss of LES relaxation and a characteristic 'Bird Beak or Rat Tail' appearance on a barium swallow.

choices.text: Dying declaration recorded by medical officer
The victim survive after recording dying declaration.
Dying declaration not sign by attendant

questions.text: In which of the below circumstances does Dying declaration become invalid? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The victim survive after recording dying declaration

 

  • Dying declaration refers to the statement which is made by a dying person explaining the circumstances of his death.
  • It is written or oral statement given by a dying person .
  • Ideally magistrate should record but if not present can be recorded by a doctor or police officer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dying declaration recorded by a medical officer: This is valid as long as the procedure is followed correctly.

 

Option C. Dying declaration not signed by an attendant: While it is ideal for an attendant to sign, the absence of such a signature does not necessarily invalidate the declaration if it can be otherwise verified.

 

Option D. Dying declaration by a police officer: This is valid if recorded correctly and without coercion, especially if no magistrate or doctor is available.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A dying declaration becomes invalid if the victim survives after recording the declaration, as it then becomes a regular statement subject to cross-examination and other legal procedures.

questions.text: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows a displaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 5-7 days following injury

 

The optimal management of a displaced nasal fracture involves consideration of the patient's clinical presentation and the timing of intervention to maximize cosmetic and functional outcomes. In this scenario, the correct time to perform a reduction of the nasal fracture is 5-7 days following the injury. This timing allows for the initial swelling to decrease, which can obscure the anatomical landmarks necessary for precise reduction. Additionally, intervening before the onset of significant edema can prevent complications associated with delayed treatment, such as increased difficulty in manipulating the bones and the risk of more permanent deformity.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Within 12 hours following the injury: Reducing a nasal fracture within 12 hours is generally not advisable as the swelling from the trauma may not have fully manifested, making it difficult to accurately assess and align the fracture.

 

Option C. After 2 weeks of injury: Waiting two weeks can lead to beginning of the healing process, potentially making the reduction more complicated or necessitating surgical intervention.

 

Option D. After 4 weeks of injury: Delaying the reduction of a nasal fracture to four weeks post-injury significantly increases the likelihood of the bones healing in a displaced position, requiring more invasive surgical procedures to correct.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Best time to reduce the fracture in this patient would be after 5-7 days.

 

 

 

Reference – Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 204

choices.text: LH, FSH level and TSH

questions.text: A 14 years old girl was brought by her mother with complaints that the child has not even menstruated once. On examination secondary sexual characters are seen and uterus and ovaries were seen to be normal on USG. What is next step of management? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Reassure mother and patient

 

Explanation:

 

  • Definition of primary amenorrhea:
    • Absent menses in a girl
      • 13 years in the absence of secondary sexual characters
      • 15 years in the presence of secondary sexual characters
  • Hence this patient, who is 14 years and has presence of secondary sexual characters, we can wait for an additional 1 year before we need to evaluate her

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Combined oral contraceptives: This is indicated only in girls diagnosed with Turner syndrome/ gonadal dysgenesis

 

Option B. Karyotype: This is indicated in evaluation of a woman with primary amenorrhoea.

 

Option D. LH, FSH, TSH: This is indicated especially in differentiating hypergonadotropic hypogonadism from hypergonadotropic hypogonadism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primary amenorrhea with secondary sexual characteristics in a 14-year-old girl does not require immediate intervention; reassurance and observation for another year is appropriate.

 

Ref: Amenorrhoea, Berek and Novak’s Gynecology, 16th edition

questions.text: A patient has been diagnosed with DNA repair gene defect. He is having hyper pigmentation on the skin and high risk for development of skin cancers as per physical examination. Which of the following is a likely enzyme defect in the patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) NER gene

 

  • Nucleotide excision repair (NER) is the main pathway used by mammals to remove bulky DNA lesions such as

 

Those formed by UV light, environmental mutagens, and some cancer chemotherapeutic adducts from DNA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. P53 gene: The P53 gene is a tumor suppressor gene that helps regulate cell division and prevents the formation of tumors. Mutations in P53 are associated with Li-Fraumeni syndrome and various cancers, but they do not specifically cause the symptoms described.

 

Option C. BRCA 1 gene: The BRCA1 gene is involved in the repair of double-strand breaks in DNA. Mutations in BRCA1 are associated with an increased risk of breast and ovarian cancers, but not with the skin hyperpigmentation and cancer risk described in the scenario.

 

Option D. MSH gene: The MSH gene is involved in mismatch repair (MMR), a pathway that corrects errors that occur during DNA replication. Mutations in MSH genes (such as MSH2 and MSH6) are associated with Lynch syndrome (hereditary non-polyposis colorectal cancer), but not with the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Deficiencies in NER are associated with the extremely skin cancer-prone inherited disorder xeroderma Pigmentosum.
  • DNA Helicase defect is associated with Werner syndrome
  • ATM gene defect is associated with Ataxia Telangiectasia.
  • MSH gene defect is associated with colon cancer

questions.text: Arjun (32, M) comes to your clinic for a regular health check-up with his wife, 28-years-old. He weighs 65 kg and his lifestyle is predominantly sedentary. His wife weighs 55 Kg, is pregnant and is in her second trimester. Her lifestyle is sedentary too. According to the latest NINDA guideline, how many calories should Arjun and his wife respectively consume? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 2350 kcal, 2150 kcal

 

Explanation:

 

The dietary guidelines of the National Institute of Nutrition are as follows:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

According to NINDA guidelines, a sedentary man should consume 2350 kcal/day, and a sedentary pregnant woman in her second trimester should consume 2150 kcal/day.

 

Ref: https://www.nin.res.in/downloads/DietaryGuidelinesforNINwebsite.pdf

questions.text: A child is having different types of rashes all over the body including papules, vesicles and pustules and these rashes are present all at the same time. The rash is associated with the onset of fever. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Chicken pox

 

 

  • Cause: DNA VIRUS
  • Dew drop appearance
  • Polymorphus rash
  • Centripetal
  • Maculo popular vesicular rash
  • Period of communicability:

 

When all the vesicles get crusted

 

  • Most common complication:
    • Secondary bacterial infections

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Measles:

 

  • Incubation period: 8-10 days
  • Communicable-3days before to 4-6days after onset of rash
  • The clinical features include Cough, Coryza, conjunctivitis and a maculopapular rash.
  • The pathognomic sign is presence of the Koplik Spots.

 

 

  • The most common complication is Otitis media.
  • The most serious complication is SSPE.

 

Option C. Scabies: Scabies will have itching and rashes over the web spaces of the fingers with +ve family history.

 

Option D. Rubella: Congenital RUBELLA will have congenital heart disease, cataract and deafness

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chicken pox is characterized by a polymorphous rash with lesions at different stages (papules, vesicles, pustules) present simultaneously, often associated with fever. The presence of these types of lesions at the same time is a hallmark of chicken pox.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female presented with intractable seizures. CT Brain shows intracranial space occupying lesion for which the mass was excised and sent for histopathology. The histopathology reported presence of psammoma bodies. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis of this patient? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Meningioma

 

The image in question shows psammoma bodies in brain specimen of a patient with intracranial space occupying lesion. This is a characteristic feature seen in Meningioma. This lamellated concentric calcification occurs around necrotic tumor cells and is an example of dystrophic calcification.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Astrocytoma is a benign cerebellar tumor which is commonly seen in children. It is a WHO Grade I tumor. On histopathology, Rosenthal fibers are seen which bipolar cells. Hence this option is ruled out on the basis of age and the given histopathological image. On CE-MRI, it is described as ‘mural nodule within a cyst’.

 

 

Option C. Ependymoma is a small round blue cell tumor which arises from the ependymal lining of the ventricles. It doesn’t have Psammoma bodies, rather perivascular Pseudo-rosettes are seen.

 

 

Option D. Medulloblastoma is a primitive neuroectodermal malignant tumor (PNET) which is commonly seen in elderly patients. It is aggressive and spread via CSF (Drop metastases). On histopathology, it has Homer Wright Rosettes.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Psammoma bodies are characteristic of meningiomas and are a key histopathological feature distinguishing them from other intracranial tumors.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient has a solitary thyroid nodule. What is the first investigation the surgeon should advice before planning thyroid surgery? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) TFT

 

The first investigation is to identify the hormonal status of the patient – whether the patient is euthyroid, hypothyroid, or hyperthyroid. Therefore, the first test to be done is the Thyroid Function Test (TFT).

 

Thyroid Function Test (TFT):

 

  • TFT helps determine the levels of thyroid hormones (T3, T4) and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) in the blood. This is crucial for assessing the functional status of the thyroid gland and planning further management.

 

Additional Points:

 

  • Best Imaging Modality: The best imaging modality for solitary thyroid swelling is Ultrasound (USG). It helps in assessing the size, composition, and characteristics of the nodule.
  • Investigation of Choice for Solitary Thyroid Nodule: The investigation of choice for a solitary thyroid nodule is USG-guided Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC). This helps in obtaining a tissue sample for cytological examination to determine the nature of the nodule (benign or malignant).

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B (Biopsy):
    • Biopsy is generally not the first investigation for a solitary thyroid nodule. FNAC is preferred initially due to its less invasive nature.
  • Option C (FNAC):
    • FNAC is an important investigation for evaluating the nature of a thyroid nodule, but it is usually performed after assessing the hormonal status with TFT.
  • Option D (RFT):
    • Renal Function Test (RFT) is not relevant in the initial evaluation of a solitary thyroid nodule.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The first investigation for a patient with a solitary thyroid nodule is the Thyroid Function Test (TFT) to determine the hormonal status.

choices.text: Reassure her that it's normal to have delayed period

questions.text: A 26-year-old unmarried woman complained of missed periods. She always had regular menstrual cycles. The pelvic examination is normal. What is the next step of management for this patient?(FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Beta HCG estimation

 

Explanation:

 

  • Beta-HCG estimation is the next step.
  • Pregnancy (even if unmarried) needs to be ruled out as it is the most common cause of secondary amenorrhea

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transvaginal ultrasound: Transvaginal ultrasound can be done in women who are sexually active to rule out structural causes in the uterus. It can also detect pregnancy as early as 5 weeks

 

Option B. Reassure her that its normal to have a delayed period: Although anovulatory cycles may occasionally occur, a missed period in a woman with otherwise regular cycles, pregnancy should always be checked.

 

Option D. FSH and LH: This is indicated when suspecting hypothalamic/ pituitary causes of anovulation

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a woman with missed periods and previously regular cycles, Beta-HCG estimation is the first step to rule out pregnancy.

questions.text: Identify the structure marked in the given image of nasopharynx? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Torus tubarius

 

The structure marked in the image is the Torus tubarius. It is a tubal elevation formed by the eustachian tube cartilage on its posterior aspect of nasopharyngeal opening.

 

Above and behind the tubal elevation is a recess called fossa of Rosenmüller, which is the commonest site for origin of carcinoma nasopharynx. Tumors arising in this region are difficult to detect.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sinus of Morgagni: This is present between skull base and superior constrictor. Contents are Levator veli palatini, Ascending palatine artery, Tensor veli palatini, Eustachian tube.

 

Option B. Passavant's ridge: This is a ridge formed by the contraction of the superior constrictor muscle during swallowing, seen in the pharyngeal wall but not typically marked in nasopharyngeal imaging.

 

Option C. Fossa of Rosenmüller: While important, this is a different structure located behind the torus tubarius and is often a site where nasopharyngeal carcinomas can originate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The torus tubarius, marked in the image, is an anatomical landmark in the nasopharynx formed by the cartilage of the Eustachian tube. Its identification is essential in the evaluation of nasopharyngeal anatomy and pathology, particularly in the context of nasopharyngeal carcinoma arising from the nearby fossa of Rosenmüller.

questions.text: Dr. Rakesh is a young emergency physician, who recently began his duty at a district hospital in Uttar Pradesh. One fateful evening, he received news of a catastrophic train accident nearby. As victims began pouring into the emergency department, he quickly realized the necessity for triage - an essential procedure during mass casualty events to determine the order of treatment based on the severity of a patient's condition. Keeping in mind the situation described, with 74 deceased, 64 severely injured, 20 moderately injured, and 32 mildly injured individuals, Dr. Rakesh recalls the color coding system used in triage. What is the correct order of priority, from the highest to the lowest? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Red – Yellow – Green – Black

 

In a situation of disaster or accidents, color coded triage system is used to prioritize treatment.

 

Categories in Triage: 

 

Red- needs immediate treatment, life threatening injuries present but can be saved it treated immediately.

 

Yellow- needs medical attention

 

Green- ambulatory patients with minor injuries, can wait for healthcare facility.

 

Black- Dead person.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which is involved in protein folding: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Chaperone

 

Chaperone proteins play a crucial role in protein folding. They assist in the proper folding of newly synthesized proteins and help refold misfolded proteins. Chaperones also prevent the aggregation of proteins, which can be detrimental to cell function. Examples of chaperones include heat shock proteins and chaperonins.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ubiquitin: Ubiquitin is a small protein that tags misfolded or damaged proteins for degradation. It is part of the ubiquitin-proteasome system, which is responsible for protein degradation, rather than folding. Ubiquitin attaches to proteins and signals for their destruction by the proteasome.

 

Option C. Proline: Proline is an amino acid that is a component of proteins. Its unique structure (a ring linking to the amino group) can induce kinks or turns in protein chains, influencing the overall structure of the protein. However, proline itself does not actively participate in the process of protein folding.

 

Option D. Arginine: Arginine is another amino acid that is a building block of proteins. While it can influence protein structure due to its charge and interaction with other amino acids, it does not directly assist in the folding process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Chaperons are protein which helps in folding of protein. They are present in Rough endoplasmic reticulum (RER), where Protein Synthesis occurs on Ribosomes.
  • Chaperons are present in RER, so that during the translation process, side by side folding can also occur, so that the end result of translation is a fully folded polypeptide chain
  • e.g. of chaperons
    • BIP (Immunoglobulin Heavy chain Binding Protein)
    • GRP – 78
    • GRP – 94
    • GRP – 170
    • Calnexin
    • Calreticulin
    • HSP – 40 (Also known as Cochaperone)
    • HSP – 47 (Heat Shock Protein)
    • HSP – 70
    • HSP – 90
    • ERP – 29 (Endoplasmic Reticulum protein)
    • ERP – 57

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 582-584

questions.text: A person returning from malaria endemic country should continue chemoprophylaxis for how long? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 4 weeks

 

Chemoprophylaxis is essential for individuals traveling to and returning from malaria-endemic regions to prevent malaria infection. The duration for continuing chemoprophylaxis after returning from a malaria-endemic area is 4 weeks.

 

Drugs used for malaria chemoprophylaxis in India are:

 

Doxycycline – It is used for short term (<6 weeks) chemoprophylaxis, started 2 days before travel to a malaria endemic country continued throughout the stay and after return continued till 4 weeks.

 

Mefloquine – Used for long term (>6 week) chemoprophylaxis. Started 2 weeks before and continued throughout the Stay and after return continued till 4 weeks

 

Educational Objective:

 

For effective malaria prevention, individuals returning from malaria-endemic regions should continue their chemoprophylaxis for 4 weeks after returning, regardless of whether they used doxycycline or mefloquine.

questions.text: A 20-year-old male is brought to the emergency with acute chest pain for which nitroglycerin was administered sublingually. His pain got relieved within 5 minutes. What could be the possible mechanism of this drug? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Release of NO

 

  • Nitroglycerine is a venodilator, that helps in reducing the preload. It is metabolized into NO which stimulates Guanylate Cyclase and Increases cGMP levels. This leads to endothelium independent coronary vasodilatation.

  • To bypass its high first pass metabolism, Nitroglycerin is given sublingually.

  • The side effects include Monday Morning Headache, reflex Tachycardia, Methemoglobinemia.

  • Contraindications include Concurrent use with PDE-5 inhibitors (Sildenafil), Right ventricular infarction and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endothelins are potent vasoconstrictor agents. For acute chest pain, these analogs should not be given as they may aggravate ischemia by reducing blood flow to the heart.

 

Option C. Calcium channel blockers are the drugs which block L-type voltage gated calcium channels and include Verapamil, Diltiazem, Dihydropyridines (Nifedipine, Nicardipine etc.). Verapamil and Diltiazem have strong myocardial depressant activity. Dihydropyridines mainly dilate arteries. Their side effects include Hypotension, reflex tachycardia, gum hypertrophy etc.

 

Option D. Beta Blockade is the mechanism of action seen with beta receptor antagonists.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nitroglycerin relieves chest pain primarily through the release of nitric oxide (NO), which causes vasodilation, predominantly venous, reducing the preload on the heart and thereby decreasing myocardial oxygen demand. This mechanism is crucial for the quick relief of symptoms associated with acute chest pain, particularly in conditions like angina pectoris.

questions.text: Macrocytic anemia case with normal methyl-malonyl with increased level of homocysteine. Diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B9 deficiency

 

  • Folate is crucial for DNA synthesis and repair. Its deficiency leads to macrocytic anemia, characterized by the presence of large red blood cells (macrocytes).
  • Folate deficiency elevates homocysteine levels but does not affect MMA levels.
  • Thus, normal MMA with increased homocysteine suggests a problem with folate metabolism rather than vitamin B12 deficiency.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12 and B9 (Folate) Deficiency:

 

  • Vitamin B12 is also essential for DNA synthesis and red blood cell formation.
  • Deficiency of B12 leads to elevated levels of both homocysteine and MMA.
  • However, in this case, since MMA levels are normal, it's less likely that vitamin B12 deficiency is present alongside folate deficiency.

 

Option C. Iron deficiency: Iron deficiency usually leads to microcytic anemia rather than macrocytic anemia. It is not associated with increased levels of homocysteine.

 

Option D. Anemia of chronic disease: Anemia of chronic disease typically presents as normocytic or microcytic anemia and is not associated with increased levels of homocysteine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Deficiency of both Vit B9 and B12 causes macrocytic anemia whereas high homocysteine levels are caused due to deficiency of Vit B6, B9 and B12. But in vitamin B12 deficiency, methyl malonyl CoA levels are also increased which is not the case here. Hence the most accurate diagnosis for the above patient is Vit B9 deficiency.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 536, 545

questions.text: 15-year-old girl was kidnapped from school. The kidnapper was nabbed by the police, but he died in police custody. Who would do the inquiry for the kidnapper’s death? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Judicial magistrate

 

In cases involving death in police custody, the inquiry is carried out by a judicial magistrate. This ensures that the investigation is conducted impartially and transparently. Judicial inquiries help maintain the integrity of the legal system and ensure that human rights are upheld, even in cases involving law enforcement agencies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medical officer: A medical officer may be involved in conducting the post-mortem examination but does not carry out the judicial inquiry.

 

Option B. Police officer: Police officers are not permitted to conduct inquiries into deaths in police custody to avoid conflicts of interest and ensure impartiality.

 

Option D. Lawyer: A lawyer may represent the interests of involved parties but does not conduct the judicial inquiry.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inquiry is carried out by a judicial/ executive magistrate is cases of:

 

  • Death in police custody
  • Death in police firing
  • Death in mental hospital

questions.text: A G2P1L1 lady underwent LSCS in previous pregnancy for fetal distress. This time she had an uneventful vaginal birth after caesarean section (VBAC) but the placenta could not be removed completely. The cord snapped on traction, but the placenta did not deliver. She also started to bleed more profusely now. What is the likely reason for this? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Placenta Percreta

 

  • This is a scenario of an adherent placenta
  • Adherent placentas can be
    • Simple adherent: can be removed by manual removal of placenta
    • Morbidly adherent
      • Should be suspected whenever there is a history of previous cesarean with retained placenta
      • Treatment: Urgent hysterectomy

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abruptio Placenta: This presents as ante partum hemorrhage (painful vaginal bleeding after 28 weeks)

 

Option B. Placenta previa: This presents as antepartum hemorrhage due to a low lying placenta (Presents as painless vaginal bleeding after 28 weeks)

 

Option C. Uterine rupture: This presents as shock with vaginal bleeding with sudden cessation of uterine contractions usually in a patient with a prior cesarean section undergoing a trial of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Morbidly adherent placenta, such as placenta percreta, should be suspected in cases of retained placenta with a history of previous cesarean section, and it often requires urgent hysterectomy to manage severe hemorrhage.

 

Ref: Page no 484, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: The image of a cut specimen of gall bladder is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Carcinoma gall bladder

 

The above image shows a fungating mass inside the lumen of the resected specimen of the gall bladder, which is specific for carcinoma of the gall bladder.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Mixed gall bladder stone: Mixed gall bladder stones would be visible as well-defined concretions within the lumen of the gall bladder.

 

Option C. Gall bladder polyp: Gall bladder polyps would also be seen as well-defined masses projecting into the lumen of the gall bladder.

 

Option D. Strawberry gall bladder: Strawberry gall bladder refers to the appearance of the mucosa of the gall bladder due to multiple focal collections of triglycerides and cholesterol esters within the lamina propria of the gall bladder wall, giving it a speckled appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Carcinoma of the gall bladder presents as a fungating mass within the lumen, unlike gall bladder stones, polyps, or the speckled appearance of a strawberry gall bladder.

 

Strawberry Gallbladder (Note the appearance of mucosa)

questions.text: Identify the Instrument shown below? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LMA ProSeal

 

ProSeal LMA is a second generation reusable LMA. It has two tubes – a gastric drainage tube, and a main airway tube. The gastric drainage tube forms a channel for regurgitated gastric contents and prevents gastric insufflation and pulmonary aspiration.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option C: LMA classic is a 1st generation LMA with only airway tube and no gastric drainage tube.

 

 

Special features of 2nd generation LMAs:

 2 tubes (gastric tube, airway tube) –

Improved airway seal and higher leak pressures,

suitable in obese patients , nonsupine positions (e.g., lateral, prone) & in laparoscopic surgery.

 

Ex: ProSeal LMA, I gel airway, LMA supreme

 

 

 

Educational Objective : 

 

The LMA depicted in the image in the question is LMA Proseal.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1389-1391

questions.text: Which of the following drugs acts by inhibiting the enzyme, catechol-0-methyltransferase? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Tolcapone

 

  • Tolcapone acts by inhibiting the catechol-O-methyltransferase (COMT) enzyme and is used in the management of Parkinson's disease. COMT enzyme metabolizes dopamine as well as L-dopa to form 3-O-methyldopa.

  • By giving COMT inhibitors, metabolism of L-dopa is reduced thereby increasing the availability of Dopamine. Also, 3-O-methyldopa competes with L-dopa for the entry in the brain. Therefore, by reducing the levels of 3-O-methyldopa, this interaction is reduced.

  • Tolcapone inhibits COMT enzyme in periphery as well as in brain whereas entacapone acts only in the periphery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amantadine: It is an NMDA receptor antagonist. It is an antiviral drug which is used against Influenza A virus, but is also useful in Parkinson’s disease, where it acts by releasing Dopamine from the vesicles. So, it increases dopamine release and reduces dopamine reuptake. Its side effects include peripheral edema, livedo reticularis, ataxia.

 

Option B. Rotigotine: Non-ergot derivative Dopamine receptor agonist which acts on both D1 and D2 receptors. It is given through transdermal patch.

 

Option D. Selegiline: It is a selective MAO-B inhibitor which acts by inhibiting MAO-B enzyme. It increases the dopamine concentrations in these neurons.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tolcapone is a COMT inhibitor used in the treatment of Parkinson's disease, enhancing the effectiveness of L-dopa therapy by reducing the peripheral and central metabolism of L-dopa and decreasing competition at the blood-brain barrier, thus increasing the availability of dopamine in the brain.

questions.text: Identify the type of substance abuse? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Bagging

 

Explanation:

 

The image shows a person inhaling a chemical from a bag, which is a method of substance abuse known as bagging. In this method, the substance is placed inside a plastic or paper bag and then inhaled.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Huffing: Huffing involves sniffing a chemical from a cloth and then inhaling it by mouth or nose. It is different from bagging as it does not involve using a bag.

 

Option B. Blading: This is not a recognized term for a method of substance abuse in common medical or forensic contexts.

 

Option D. Sniffing: Sniffing is the inhalation of a liquid from an open container, which differs from bagging as it does not use a bag to contain the substance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Huffing. Sniffing a chemical from a cloth and then inhaling it by mouth or nose

 

Bagging. Sniffing a chemical from a bag

 

Sniffing. Inhaling of liquid from an open container.

questions.text: In a diabetic patient which of the following is a macrovascular complication that occurs in the later stage of the disease? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Coronary artery disease

 

Diabetes mellitus is a disease having multi system involvement characterized by deposition of AGE (Advanced glycation end products) causing micro and macrovascular complications.

 

Microvascular complications (Retinopathy, nephropathy, neuropathy): Correlate with HbA1c

 

Macrovascular complications (Coronary artery, peripheral artery, Cerebrovascular disease): No specific correlation parameter, hence most common cause of death among DM is cardiovascular disease. Hence Statins are recommended for all diabetics >40 years.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Foot ulcer: This is typically a result of diabetic neuropathy (a microvascular complication) and peripheral arterial disease (a macrovascular complication). While it can involve macrovascular disease, it is more directly a consequence of neuropathy and poor wound healing due to microvascular damage.

 

Option B. Nephropathy: This is a microvascular complication characterized by damage to the small blood vessels in the kidneys.

 

Option C. Retinopathy: This is a microvascular complication involving damage to the small blood vessels in the retina.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Coronary artery disease is a macrovascular complication of diabetes mellitus and is a major cause of morbidity and mortality in diabetic patients. It highlights the need for cardiovascular risk management, including the use of statins, in this population.

questions.text: A woman 3 months postpartum who regularly breastfeeds presented with amenorrhea for 3 months and is concerned about this problem and is requesting surgery. Before considering surgery what can be done to manage this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Reassure

 

Explanation:

 

The best management of this patient is to reassure her, as this is normal during the postpartum period and is due to lactational amenorrhea. A woman who is exclusively breastfeeding will be anovulatory due to high prolactin levels and hence have amenorrhea. Lactational amenorrhea is a natural contraceptive method that occurs when a woman breastfeeds exclusively, leading to suppression of the menstrual cycle.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Laparoscopic ovarian drilling: Laparoscopic ovarian drilling is done as a second-line measure in women with polycystic ovary syndrome (PCOS) who do not respond to ovulation induction methods. It is not appropriate for managing lactational amenorrhea.

 

Option B. Contraceptives to be prescribed: Contraceptives may be prescribed to women who are not exclusively breastfeeding, are not amenorrheic, or if their infant is older than 6 months. In this case, the patient is exclusively breastfeeding and experiencing normal lactational amenorrhea, so contraceptives are not necessary.

 

Option C. Pulsatile GnRH: Pulsatile GnRH has no role in the management of lactational amenorrhea. It is typically used for ovarian stimulation in specific infertility treatments, which is not relevant for this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lactational amenorrhea is a normal physiological response to exclusive breastfeeding, leading to anovulation and temporary cessation of menstruation due to elevated prolactin levels.

 

Ref: Page no 635, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the emergency unit after he is pushed down while playing. After falling on his knees, he developed swelling and bruising of his left knee. History revealed that his maternal uncle is also having similar presentation. What could be the probable mode of inheritance of this clinical condition? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) XLR

 

The clinical case given is the case of a Hemophilia A, and the pattern of inheritance seen in Hemophilia is XLR.

 

Deficiency of factor VIII.

 

C/F:

 

  • Family history
  • ﻿﻿Bleeding/Bruising
  • ﻿﻿Hemarthrosis (ankle > knee)

 

Pathology: Intrinsic pathway is affected-prolonged aPPT (Normal PT, BT, Platelet count).

 

 

Note that X-linked recessive inheritance means that the gene for the disorder is located on the X chromosome, and males are typically more severely affected since they only have one X chromosome. Females who inherit one copy of the mutated gene are usually carriers and may have milder symptoms or be asymptomatic. Autosomal recessive inheritance means that both parents must carry a copy of the mutated gene for their child to be affected, and the disorder affects males and females equally. Acquired haemophilia is not inherited and can occur in anyone, regardless of their family history.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia A is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by a deficiency in clotting factor VIII.

choices.text: GH deficiency
GH receptor deficiency
GHRH deficiency
GHRH receptor deficiency

questions.text: A 7-year-old child is presented with short stature. On biochemical examination, growth hormone levels are normal with very low levels of IGF-1. Which of the following could be the possible defect in this child? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) GH receptor deficiency

 

The clinical scenario of a child with short stature, normal growth hormone (GH) levels, and very low levels of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1) is indicative of a condition where the body is resistant to the effects of growth hormone. This condition is known as Laron dwarfism or GH insensitivity syndrome.

 

Laron Dwarfism:

 

  • Cause: Mutations in the GH receptor gene (GHR) that lead to a failure of the body to respond to growth hormone.
  • Pathophysiology: Despite normal or elevated levels of growth hormone, the defective GH receptors do not transmit the signal to produce IGF-1, resulting in low levels of IGF-1 and subsequent short stature and growth failure.
  • Clinical Features: Severe short stature, small head size, high-pitched voice, delayed or absent puberty, and characteristic facial features.
  • Diagnosis: Normal GH levels with low IGF-1 levels, confirming GH receptor resistance.
