  • Treatment: Administration of recombinant IGF-1 to bypass the defective GH receptors and promote growth and development.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. GH deficiency: GH deficiency would present with low GH and low IGF-1 levels.

 

Option C. GHRH deficiency: Would present with low GH and low IGF-1 levels due to inadequate stimulation of GH secretion.

 

Option D. GHRH receptor deficiency: Would similarly result in low GH and low IGF-1 levels due to the inability of GHRH to stimulate GH secretion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A child with short stature, normal GH levels, and low IGF-1 levels likely has a GH receptor deficiency (Laron dwarfism). This condition results from the body's inability to respond to GH due to defective receptors, leading to low IGF-1 levels and subsequent growth failure. Treatment involves administering recombinant IGF-1.

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presented previous history of chlamydia infection now presents with low-grade fever and non-specific lower abdominal pain. Examination reveals mild diffuse lower abdominal tenderness on deep palpation, cervical motion tenderness, and a mucopurulent vaginal discharge. What is the long-term sequelae of this condition? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Infertility

 

Explanation:

 

  • The diagnosis is pelvic inflammatory disease most likely due to Chlamydia trachomatis
  • Long term sequelae of PID include
    • Infertility
    • Increased incidence of ectopic pregnancy
    • Tubo-ovarian abscess
    • Hydrosalpinx

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Risk factors of uterine cancer are:

 

  • Endometrial hyperplasia
  • Unopposed estrogen: PCOS, anovulation, HRT
  • Tamoxifen
  • Nulliparity
  • Diabetes
  • Family h/o cancer syndromes

 

Option C. Risk factors for Pelvic organ prolapse are:

 

  • Hypoestrogenism
  • Multiple vaginal births; unsupervised births, forceps delivery
  • Raised intra-abdominal pressure
  • Congenital weakness of muscles/ connective tissue disorders

 

Option D. Risk factors for cervical cancer:

 

  • HPV infection
  • Early age at 1st intercourse
  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Smoking
  • Immunocompromised states
  • Low socio-economic status
  • Prolonged use of OCPs (?)

 

Educational Objective:

 

The long-term sequelae of pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) include infertility, increased incidence of ectopic pregnancy, tubo-ovarian abscess, and hydrosalpinx.

 

Ref: Page no 144, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: All of the following are components of Tetralogy of Fallot EXCEPT? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Tricuspid stenosis

 

Tricuspid stenosis is not a component of Tetralogy of Fallot, where as the Pulmonary infundibular stenosis is included in Tetralogy of Fallot.

 

Tetralogy of Fallot (components of TOF)

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Large VSD
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Pulmonary stenosis
  3. ﻿﻿﻿Overriding of Aorta
  4. ﻿﻿﻿Right ventricular hypertrophy

 

It is the Most common congenital cyanotic heart disease seen in children

 

 

Cor en sabot or Boot shaped heart on chest X ray

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tetralogy of Fallot consists of four components: a large ventricular septal defect (VSD), pulmonary stenosis, an overriding aorta, and right ventricular hypertrophy.

questions.text: Patient presents with frequent urination, nocturia, enuresis. 24-hour urine volume was measured and recorded to be 7 liters. The urine osmolarity was 260 mOsm/L. ADH assay was performed and reported as 0.8 pg/ml. An MRI of the brain in T1 weighted indicated absence of pituitary bright spot. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pituitary DI

 

The patient presents with symptoms of frequent urination, nocturia, and enuresis, along with a very high 24-hour urine volume of 7 liters and low urine osmolarity (260 mOsm/L), indicating dilute urine. The ADH (antidiuretic hormone) level is significantly low at 0.8 pg/ml, suggesting a deficiency in ADH. Additionally, the MRI finding of an absent pituitary bright spot on T1-weighted imaging further supports the diagnosis of central diabetes insipidus (DI), also known as pituitary DI. Central DI is characterized by a deficiency in ADH production, leading to excessive urine production and dilution.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nephrogenic DI: In nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, ADH levels are typically elevated because the kidneys are resistant to the hormone's effects. This condition is not characterized by low ADH levels, as seen in this patient.

 

Option B. Mannitol infusion: Mannitol infusion would lead to osmotic diuresis, resulting in increased urine osmolarity, not the low urine osmolarity observed in this patient.

 

Option C. Primary polydipsia: Primary polydipsia, or psychogenic polydipsia, involves excessive water intake leading to diluted urine. However, the absence of the pituitary bright spot on MRI makes primary polydipsia less likely, as it is typically associated with normal pituitary imaging.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pituitary (central) diabetes insipidus is characterized by a deficiency in ADH, leading to polyuria, dilute urine, and low ADH levels, often accompanied by the absence of the pituitary bright spot on MRI.

questions.text: Dr. Anjali, an epidemiologist, consults on a case where a teacher has been exposed to an infectious disease. To prevent the spread within the community, she recommends keeping him isolated until the incubation period has passed. What is this preventative strategy called? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Absolute quarantine

 

"Absolute quarantine" is the practice of isolating individuals who have been exposed to a disease but have not yet shown symptoms, for the length of the disease's incubation period. This method ensures that if the individual develops symptoms, they do so while already isolated, thus minimizing the risk of transmission to the community.

 

Quarantine is done for healthy contacts till maximum incubation period of the disease.

 

Example: Quarantine period of yellow fever is 6 days-done for travellers coming from endemic areas.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option B. Isolation: Is done for cases to decrease the communicability of the disease in the population (method of primary prevention for the population). It is done for the period of maximum communicability.

 

Option C. Generation time: Is the time from entry of the organism to maximum communicability of the infectious agent. It determines the period of communicability.

 

Option D. Serial interval: Is the average time difference between the primary and secondary case, which is similar to the median incubation period.

 

Educational Objective:

 

"Absolute quarantine" is implemented to monitor exposed, asymptomatic individuals during the incubation period to prevent potential outbreaks in community settings.

questions.text: A patient on anti-cancer therapy developed infection. Blood Analysis revealed a Total Leucocyte Count of 2000/mm3. Which of the following drug is likely to be effective in this patient?  (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Filgrastim

 

Patient on chemotherapy with TLC count less than 4000/mm3 means that the patient has chemotherapy induced leukopenia. In this case, a G-CSF should be administered. Out of the four options, Filgrastim is the Granulocyte Colony Stimulating Factor. It increases leucocytes proliferation and is administered subcutaneously or by slow intravenous infusion.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Romiplostim: It is a thrombopoietin analog which stimulates the thrombopoietin receptors. It is used in ITP, given by S.C. route.
 

Option B. Oprelvekin: It is IL-11, it stimulates the proliferation of megakaryocytes. Useful in Thrombocytopenia


Option D. Erythropoietin: It is secreted from Kidney and helps in erythropoiesis. Its recombinant form Epoietin or Darbopoietin Alpha is mainly used for the treatment of anemia due to chronic kidney disease or due to Bone Marrow Suppression. Its side effects include hypertension and polycythemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Filgrastim is the recommended treatment for chemotherapy-induced leukopenia, due to its ability to specifically stimulate the proliferation of granulocytes and thereby counteract the reduced white blood cell counts that significantly increase infection risk in cancer patients.

questions.text: Which amino acids is required for the formation of nitric oxide in the blood vessels? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arginine

 

  • The production of NO from arginine involves the conversion of arginine to citrulline, with the release of NO as a byproduct.
  • Arginine is the primary substrate for the production of NO by endothelial NOS (eNOS). Once produced, nitric oxide acts as a vasodilator, relaxing the smooth muscle in the blood vessels and promoting their dilation. This leads to increased blood flow and improved endothelial function.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lysine: Primarily involved in protein synthesis and not directly in NO production.

 

Option C. Histidine: Important for the production of histamine and the function of hemoglobin, but not in NO synthesis.

 

Option D. Tryptophan: A precursor for serotonin and melatonin synthesis, not involved in NO production.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Arginine is essential for the production of nitric oxide, a critical molecule for vasodilation and endothelial health.

questions.text: X-ray of a 2-year-old child presenting in an unconscious state is given, what is the possible diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pneumoperitoneum

 

  • The X-ray shows "football sign" which is suggestive of massive pneumoperitoneum.
  • It is usually seen on a supine X-ray.

 

Other named signs in pneumoperitoneum:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pneumatosis Intestinalis: This involves gas cysts within the bowel wall, typically seen as intramural gas and does not present as a football sign.

 

 

Option C. Subcutaneous emphysema: Involves air trapped under the skin, usually noticeable in the chest and neck regions, and would not present as abdominal radiolucency.

 

 

Option D. Duodenal atresia: Characterized by the "double bubble" sign with distension of the stomach and proximal duodenum, distinct from the free air under the diaphragm seen in pneumoperitoneum.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "football sign" on an abdominal X-ray of a young child is a classic indication of pneumoperitoneum, suggesting a significant underlying pathology such as gastrointestinal perforation that requires immediate medical attention to determine the cause and appropriate intervention.

questions.text: Identify the image shown below? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Trichuris trichiura eggs 

 

Trichuris trichiura eggs are 50-55 micrometers by 20-25 micrometers. They are barrel-shaped, thick-shelled and possess a pair of polar “plugs” at each end as shown in the image in the question. The eggs are un-embryonated when passed in stool. Iron deficiency Anemia is seen. Frequent rectal prolapse leads to coconut cake like rectum.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Taenia solium: Eggs are spherical with a thick shell and radial striations, and are not barrel-shaped.

 

Option B. Enterobius vermicularis: Eggs are asymmetrical with one side flattened, (planoconvex) diagnosed using an NIH swab (Scotch tape test), and associated with perianal pruritus and autoinfection.

 

Option D. H. nana: Eggs are spherical with a thin shell and contain an oncosphere with polar filaments and 6 hooklets , differing from the barrel-shaped Trichuris trichiura eggs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichuris trichiura eggs are identified by their barrel shape, thick shell, and polar plugs. They are unembryonated when passed in stool and are associated with iron deficiency anemia and rectal prolapse.

choices.text: The prevalence of ASB is 50%
It is lower in people with sickle cell trait
The preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin

questions.text: True regarding UTI in pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. C) The preferred antibiotic in pregnancy is amoxicillin

 

Explanation:

 

The prevalence of asymptomatic bacteriuria (ASB) in pregnancy is approximately 5%, not 50%. ASB, if untreated, can lead to pyelonephritis in up to 25% of cases. It is crucial to treat ASB in pregnancy to prevent such complications. Additionally, ASB is more common in patients with sickle cell trait, contrary to the suggestion in option B. The preferred antibiotic for treating UTIs in pregnancy is amoxicillin due to its safety profile for both the mother and the fetus.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. The prevalence of ASB is 50%: This statement is incorrect. The actual prevalence of ASB in pregnancy is around 5%.

 

Option B. It is lower in people with sickle cell trait: This statement is incorrect. ASB is more common in people with sickle cell trait, not lower.

 

Option D. ASB is not treated: This statement is incorrect. ASB is always treated in pregnancy to prevent progression to pyelonephritis and other complications.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred antibiotic for treating UTIs in pregnancy is amoxicillin.

 

Ref: Page no 2584, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

choices.text: Abstinence for 3 months after the procedure
Usage of barrier methods for 3 months after the procedure
Female condom usage for 1 month

questions.text: After undergoing a vasectomy performed by Dr. Patel, a 35-year-old farmer finds out three months later through his wife’s unexpected pregnancy that crucial post-procedure advice may have been missed. What should Dr. Patel have recommended immediately after the procedure to ensure its effectiveness? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Usage of barrier methods for 3 months after the procedure

 

Post-vasectomy, it is essential to continue using contraception until tests confirm the absence of sperm in the semen. Dr. Patel should have advised the use of barrier methods for at least three months. During this period, sperm can still be present in the semen until the vas deferens naturally clears out remaining sperm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Abstinence for 3 months after the procedure: While abstinence is effective in preventing pregnancy, it might not be a feasible or desirable option for every couple.

 

Option C. OCPS usage for 1 month: OCPS, or oral contraceptive pills, are for female use and irrelevant in the context of male sterilization.

 

Option D. Female condom usage for 1 month: Recommending female condoms for one month does not cover the necessary period until aspermia can be confirmed, typically up to three months.

 

Educational Objective:


Following a vasectomy, barrier methods should be used for three months or until a semen analysis confirms no sperm presence, ensuring the effectiveness of the procedure in preventing pregnancy.

 

Post-operative advice:

 

  • Patient need 30 ejaculations after vasectomy, before turning sterile
  • Use of barriers methods till aspermia
  • Avoid bath for 24 hours after operation
  • T-bandage for support for 15 days, keep site dry
  • Avoid cycling, lifting heavy weights for 15 days
  • Stitch removal on 5th day

 

Additional Information

 

After-effects of vasectomy:

 

  • Operative: Pain, scrotal hematoma, local infection
  • Sperm granules: 7 mm painful mass; appears 10–14 days after vasectomy; can provide a medium for re-anastomosis of vas; using metal clips reduce this problem; 
  • Spontaneous recanalization -  seen in 0–6% cases; require regular follow-up for 3 years
  • Autoimmune response - seen in 54% of vasectomised persons; require regular follow-up for 3 years
  • Psychological - diminution of sex vigour, impotence, fatigue, headache
  • Post-Vasectomy Pain Syndrome: primary long-term complication (permanent feeling)

 

Failure of vasectomy – MCC in India: Mistaken identification of vas deferens

 

  • Failure rate (Pearl Index): 0.15 per HWY
  • Confirmation of successful vasectomy by Histology - Smear of squeeze of vas by Wright’s stain

choices.text: Baby with serious mental or physical abnormality

questions.text: Which of the following indications is not true regarding medical termination of pregnancy? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) When the family is large

 

Explanation:

 

The Medical Termination of Pregnancy (MTP) Act provides specific indications under which a pregnancy can be legally terminated. The following are the primary indications:

 

  • Maternal (Therapeutic or Medical Indication): When there is a significant risk to the mother's health if the pregnancy continues. This includes conditions such as:
    • Cardiac disease
    • Chronic kidney disease
    • Malignant hypertension
    • Malignancies (e.g., cervical or breast cancer)
    • Psychiatric illnesses
    • Uncontrolled epilepsy
  • Eugenic/Fetal: When there are significant fetal anomalies, which could include:
    • Congenital anomalies
    • Chromosomal anomalies
    • Infections like rubella
  • Social: This includes situations such as pregnancies resulting from rape or where continuing the pregnancy would cause significant social or psychological distress.
  • Failure of Contraception: This indication allows for termination when contraceptives fail, and the pregnancy is unintended.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pregnancy resulting from rape: This is a valid indication for MTP under the social category as the pregnancy is a result of an act of rape and could lead to significant psychological and social distress.

 

Option C. Baby with serious mental or physical abnormality: This falls under the eugenic/fetal category and is a valid reason for MTP, as carrying such a pregnancy to term could result in severe mental or physical abnormalities in the baby.

 

Option D. Failure of contraceptives: This is a valid indication under the MTP Act. It recognizes that unintended pregnancies due to contraceptive failure can be terminated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The MTP Act allows for the termination of pregnancy under specific conditions, including maternal health risks, fetal anomalies, pregnancies resulting from rape, and failure of contraception.

choices.text: N acetyl cysteine

questions.text: Iron poisoning antidote is: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Deferoxamine

 

Deferoxamine is a chelating agent specifically used to treat acute iron poisoning. It binds to free iron in the bloodstream and enhances its excretion in the urine

 

Other Options

 

Option B. N acetyl cysteine: This is the antidote for paracetamol (acetaminophen) poisoning. It replenishes glutathione stores and helps detoxify the liver.

 

Option C. Oxygen: Used in various conditions like carbon monoxide poisoning but not specifically an antidote for any chemical poisoning.

 

Option D. Ethanol: Used as an antidote in methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning because it competes for the same metabolic pathway.

 

Educational objective

 

Antidotes:

 

  • Iron poisoning - Deferoxamine
  • Paracetamol poisoning - N acetyl cysteine
  • Methanol poisoning - Ethanol

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with a gradual loss of visual acuity in the right eye. A post-contrast MRI reveals 'tram-track' appearance, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Optic nerve sheath Meningioma

 

 

ON meningioma: Tram-track appearance with ON seen separately

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ON Glioma: Fusiform mass involving the optic nerve

 

 

Option B. Retinoblastoma: A child with intra-ocular mass with calcification on CT

 

 

Option D. Rhabdomyosarcoma. This is a malignant soft tissue tumor more commonly associated with the orbit rather than the optic nerve itself and would not typically show a 'tram-track' sign.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Optic nerve sheath meningioma should be considered in patients presenting with gradual visual loss and characteristic 'tram-track' appearance on post-contrast MRI. This finding highlights the tumor's pattern of encasing the optic nerve, leading to symptoms through compressive effects. Early diagnosis and management can help preserve visual function and address any potential complications.

questions.text: Dr. Iyer, treating a 40-year-old farmer with a chronic cough and weight loss in a rural Tamil Nadu clinic, suspects tuberculosis due to the region's high incidence and the patient's symptoms. What is the initial recommended test for diagnosing TB? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Sputum smear examination

 

The first investigation that is ordered in a case of pulmonary TB is sputum test and NAAT (in HIV positive cases).  If sputum test and NAAT are positive, then it is a microbiologically confirmed TB case.

 

Two Sputum Smears Collection

 

  • Two-day collection (Day 1: Spot sample and Day 2: Morning sample): 2 mL mucopurulent each
  • One day collection (Day 1: Both Spot samples): 2 mL mucopurulent each.

 

Other options: 

 

Option A. Chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray can show signs suggestive of TB, such as cavities or infiltrates, it is not definitive for diagnosis and is used adjunctively with microbiological tests.

 

Option C. CB-NAAT: Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CB-NAAT) is a more recent, advanced diagnostic tool and extremely sensitivity than smear microscopy, +ve even with ‘1 – 10 bacilli per mL sputum’. It can detect within 1 day. It can also detect rifampicin resistance. It is the first investigation for TB Diagnosis among HIV positives cases. While crucial, especially in certain scenarios, it's not the primary initial test in all settings.

 

Option D. Liquid culture: Culture methods are more sensitive than smear microscopy but take longer to provide results. Liquid culture is typically used as a follow-up test when other tests are inconclusive or when drug susceptibility testing is required.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • First investigation for TB Diagnosis Sputum smear examination
  • First investigation for TB Diagnosis among HIV positives CBNAAT

questions.text: A 8-month-old child is brought to the ED by his mother with complains of incessant crying and blood-stained stools. The barium enema is shown. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Intussusception

 

The given clinical scenario and the barium enema of claw sign or the pincer sign in barium enema is suggestive of intussusception.

 

INTUSSUSCEPTION

 

It is the telescoping of one bowel loop into the other.

 

  • Age: 6-8months most common
  • C/F: Painful red currant jelly stools
  • MC type: Ileocolic Intussusception (due to accumulation of Peyer’s patches in the terminal ileum)
  • Initial Investigation: USG - Target/Donut/Sandwich/Pseudo kidney sign
  • IOC: Barium enema

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Sigmoid volvulus: Kidney shaped without haustrations and apex pointing towards left hypochondrium (Bent-tube sign).

 

 

Option C. CHPS: Single bubble sign

 

 

Option D. Duodenal atresia: Double bubble sign

 

 

Note: Triple bubble sign – Jejunal atresia

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The diagnosis of intussusception is confirmed by the classic radiographic "coil-spring" or "pincer" sign on barium enema, coupled with the clinical presentation of cyclical pain and bloody stools. Prompt diagnosis is crucial as intussusception can lead to bowel necrosis and perforation if not treated in a timely manner.

questions.text: A public health intern is working on a research project that requires the calculation of various population health metrics for a region. In one of the conversations with her colleague, they discuss the importance of considering the mid-year population to get accurate results for some specific indicators. Her colleague asks her on what date the mid-year population is typically taken. The correct date for determining the mid-year population is? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 01 July 

 

The mid-year population is typically taken on July 1st. This date is used as a reference point for calculating various demographic and health indicators such as the Crude Birth Rate (CBR) and the Crude Death Rate (CDR). Using a standard date helps in maintaining consistency and accuracy in population-based calculations and comparisons over time.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The midyear population is taken on July 1.

choices.text: Prior to the removal of Placenta accreta in Multiparous woman
Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

questions.text: As a senior resident in the OBG department, you would consider uterine artery embolization as a treatment option in all of the following cases except: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Patient diagnosed with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids

 

Explanation:

 

Uterine artery embolization (UAE) is a procedure used to control bleeding and treat conditions like fibroids by reducing the blood supply to the uterus. While it is effective for many indications, it is contraindicated in certain situations. Pedunculated and submucous fibroids are contraindications for UAE due to the risk of expulsion and infection of the fibroids after the procedure.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Patient with Postpartum hemorrhage: UAE is an effective treatment for controlling primary and secondary postpartum hemorrhage (PPH).

 

Option B. Prior to the removal of Placenta accreta in Multiparous woman: UAE can be used to manage bleeding associated with placenta accreta syndromes, making it a useful adjunct prior to surgical intervention.

 

Option D. Multiparous woman with menorrhagia: UAE is indicated for the treatment of menorrhagia, especially in cases where it is caused by fibroids or other uterine vascular issues.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine artery embolization is contraindicated in patients with calcified and pedunculated submucous fibroids due to the risk of complications such as expulsion and infection.

 

Ref: Page no 283, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: In retroperitoneal trauma, in which zones of retroperitoneum is surgical exploration mandatory? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

In retroperitoneal trauma, Zone 1 requires mandatory surgical exploration due to the high risk of vascular injuries involving the aorta and inferior vena cava.

choices.text: Intestinal columnar metaplasia
Simple columnar metaplasia

questions.text: Which of the following feature associated with Barrett’s esophagus? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intestinal columnar metaplasia

 

Barrett's esophagus –

 

  • It is associated with GERD. The acid content of stomach comes upward to the lower part of esophagus. The esophagus is lined by squamous epithelium which is replaced by intestinal columnar epithelium
  • Squamous metaplasia – it is the commonest epithelial metaplasia which is associated with smoking. It affects the respiratory tract of smokers.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Squamous Metaplasia: This type of metaplasia occurs when columnar epithelium is replaced by squamous epithelium. It is commonly seen in the respiratory tract of smokers.

 

Option C. Stratified Metaplasia: This term is not commonly used in the context of esophageal changes. Metaplasia usually refers to the transformation to a different type of epithelium rather than stratified epithelium.

 

Option D. Simple Columnar Metaplasia: This option refers to a type of metaplasia but does not specify the presence of goblet cells which are a hallmark of intestinal metaplasia in Barrett's esophagus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Barrett’s esophagus is characterized by the replacement of the normal squamous epithelium of the esophagus with intestinal-type columnar epithelium, often as a result of chronic GERD.

questions.text: Which of the following incisions is not used for Appendicectomy? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Kocher’s incision

 

 

Kocher’s incision is used for open cholecystectomy and is not utilized for appendectomy. The other listed incisions, Lanz, McBurney’s, and Rutherford Morrison, are commonly used for appendectomy.

 

Incisions Used for Appendectomy:

 

  • Rutherford Morrison Incision:
    • Useful if the appendix is paracecal, retrocecal, or fixed. It is an oblique muscle-cutting incision with its lower end over McBurney’s point. All the layers are divided in the line of the incision.
  • McBurney’s Incision:
    • A muscle-splitting incision commonly used for appendectomy. It provides good exposure with minimal muscle damage.
  • Lanz Incision:
    • Cosmetically the best incision, producing minimal scarring. It is a transverse incision made at the same level as McBurney’s point but extends more medially and laterally.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option B (Lanz’):
    • Used for appendectomy, providing good cosmetic results and minimal scarring.
  • Option C (McBurney’s incision):
    • A standard incision for appendectomy known for its effectiveness and minimal muscle damage.
  • Option D (Rutherford Morrison):
    • Another incision used for appendectomy, particularly useful in cases where the appendix is not in its usual position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Kocher’s incision is used for open cholecystectomy, not appendectomy. For appendectomy, incisions such as McBurney’s, Lanz, and Rutherford Morrison are utilized.

choices.text: Helper T cell
Cytotoxic T cell

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents in the emergency because of development of allergy due to pollen inhalation. Which cell is important in the pathogenesis of this condition? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Helper T cell

 

Explanation: - Type 1 Hypersensitivity reaction. Allergic reactions arise from an inappropriate immune response to substances such as pollen, mold, or peanuts, initiated by a group of immune cells known as the TH2 subset, or type 2 "helper" T cells.

The two cells critical in the pathogenesis of Type 1 hypersensitivity reaction are TH2 cells and mast cells

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Macrophages: Involved in phagocytosis and antigen presentation, but not directly in the pathogenesis of Type 1 hypersensitivity. They play a key role in chronic inflammation and innate immunity.

 

Option B. Lymphocytes: A general term for white blood cells, including T cells and B cells, but the specific role of TH2 cells is critical in allergies.

 

Option D. Cytotoxic T cells: These cells are involved in directly killing infected or cancerous cells but do not play a primary role in allergic reactions. They are more involved in Type 4 hypersensitivity reactions and cellular immunity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The development of allergy due to pollen inhalation is primarily driven by Helper T cells (TH2), which are crucial in the pathogenesis of Type 1 hypersensitivity reactions.

questions.text: A 26-year-old first-time expectant mother comes to the local community health center. She is in her first trimester and is overwhelmed by the amount of advice she has received from well-meaning friends and family. They've given her various opinions on everything, from diet to exercise and even the number of doctor's visits she should have. Wanting to ensure her baby's and her own health, she seeks clarity on how often she should ideally see her doctor. Based on standard guidelines, what is the minimum number of antenatal visits she should have during her pregnancy if it progresses without complications? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4

 

Minimum 4 ANC visits are recommended.

1st visit - <12 weeks (Registration visit)

2nd visit - 14-26 weeks

3rd visit - 28-34 weeks

4th visit - 36 weeks till term

 

Educational Objective:

 

The standard guideline recommends a minimum of four antenatal visits during an uncomplicated pregnancy to ensure effective monitoring and health maintenance of both mother and baby.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is synthesized from: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arginine

 

Nitric oxide is synthesized from the amino acid L-arginine. This process is catalyzed by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). There are several isoforms of NOS, and they all use L-arginine as a substrate, converting it into nitric oxide and citrulline.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. L-Hydroxy proline: This is an amino acid derivative commonly found in collagen, a structural protein. L-Hydroxy proline is not involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

 

Option C. D-Histidine: This is an isomer of the amino acid histidine. Amino acids in the D form are not commonly used in human biochemistry as substrates for enzymes. Nitric oxide synthesis does not involve D-histidine.

 

Option D. Cysteine: This amino acid is important for protein structure (due to its ability to form disulfide bonds) and is a precursor for glutathione, a major antioxidant. However, it is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NO is also called as Endothelium Derived Relaxing Factor (EDRF). NO (nitric oxide) is synthesized from arginine by enzyme NOS (Nitric oxide synthase) in the endothelial cells.

 

 

NO synthase complex

 

  • There are three isoforms of NOS (Nitric oxide synthase)
    1. nNOS - neuronal
    2. eNOS- endothelial
    3. iNOS- inducible

 

The secondary messenger involved in the mechanism of action of NO vasodilation is cGMP by the activation of enzyme guanylate cyclase.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 286, 307

questions.text: A 45-year-old presents with chest pain, dyspnea increasing on lying down and relieved on sitting upright. On examination, heart sounds are muffled. CXR given below. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Pericardial effusion

 

The patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down and are relieved by sitting up, along with muffled heart sounds on examination. These symptoms, combined with the chest X-ray findings, suggest a diagnosis of pericardial effusion.

 

The chest X-ray shows signs characteristic of pericardial effusion, including cardiomegaly, rounded cardiophrenic angles, and a "money bag" appearance. Pericardial effusion requires at least 200 mL of fluid to be detectable on a chest X-ray. In some cases, a lateral chest X-ray may show the "Oreo Cookie" sign, which consists of a lucent area of paracardiac fat anteriorly, an opaque line of effusion, and a lucent area of epicardial fat.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Tetralogy of Fallot: This congenital heart defect presents with a combination of four heart malformations and typically does not present with pericardial effusion. The X-ray findings would include a boot-shaped heart due to right ventricular hypertrophy, which is not seen here.

 

Option B. Pulmonary Hypertension: This condition involves elevated pressure in the pulmonary arteries and may cause signs of right ventricular hypertrophy or enlarged pulmonary arteries on X-ray, but it would not present with the "money bag" appearance seen in pericardial effusion.

 

Option C. Transposition of great arteries: This is a congenital heart defect where the aorta and pulmonary artery are transposed. It typically presents in neonates and infants with cyanosis and would show different X-ray findings, such as an "egg on a string" appearance.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Pericardial effusion presents with symptoms such as chest pain and dyspnea that worsen when lying down, muffled heart sounds, and characteristic X-ray findings like cardiomegaly, rounded cardiophrenic angles, and a "money bag" appearance.

questions.text: Which of the following is contraindicated in Acute Intermittent Porphyria? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Thiopentone

 

Acute Intermittent Porphyria (AIP):

 

  • This is a genetic disorder that affects the production of heme, a component of hemoglobin. Certain substances can trigger the symptoms of AIP by causing a buildup of porphyrins, which are intermediates in the heme synthesis pathway. Thiopentone, a barbiturate is contraindicated in Acute intermittent porphyria.
  • Thiopentone is a barbiturate anesthetic agent. Barbiturates enhance porphyrin synthesis. By doing so, they can exacerbate the symptoms of acute intermittent porphyria. Thus, Thiopentone is absolutely contraindicated in patients with a history of AIP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alcohol: Alcohol can also be a triggering factor for AIP attacks but only in some individuals.

 

Option C. Etomidate: Etomidate is an intravenous anesthetic agent with no relation to porphyrias.

 

Option D. Ketamine: Ketamine is a dissociative anesthetic and analgesic with no relation to porphyrias.

 

Educational Objective : 

 

Contraindications of Thiopentone:

 

  1. Acute Intermittent Porphyria: As already mentioned, Thiopentone can exacerbate AIP symptoms.
  2. Shock: Thiopentone can cause a decrease in blood pressure, which can be harmful in patients already in shock.
  3. Bronchial Asthma: Thiopentone has the potential to cause bronchoconstriction, which can be dangerous in patients with bronchial asthma as it may trigger an asthma attack.

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pg 426

choices.text: Total deaths due to that disease

questions.text: Dr. Mehta, a seasoned physician in a tertiary care hospital in Cochin, is witnessing an upsurge in cases of a novel viral illness. He is actively involved in collating data on patient outcomes, specifically focusing on understanding the severity and lethality of this newfound disease. To determine the percentage of people diagnosed with the disease who eventually succumb to it, which metric would Dr. Mehta most likely employ to indicate the Severity / lethality of disease? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Case fatality rate

 

The Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is the metric that measures the severity and lethality of a disease by indicating the percentage of diagnosed individuals who die from the disease within a specified period. The formula for CFR is:

 

Case fatality rate = (Number of deaths due to a disease/ number of cases of that particular disease) * 100

 

Case fatality rate typically is used as a measure of disease severity and is often used for prognosis. Always expressed in %; Ex.  CFR of Rabies is 100%.

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Proportional mortality rate (PMR) = No of deaths from a specific disease/Total deaths from all causes that year × 100. This is the ‘simplest measure of estimating the burden of a disease’ in the community

 

Option B. Case specific Death rate: This rate helps to identify the particular ‘at risk’ group(s) for preventive action.

 

Specific Death rate (SDR) is defined as -

 

 

Option D. Total Deaths Due to That Disease: This simply refers to the total number of deaths caused by a specific disease and does not provide a measure of severity or lethality in relation to the number of diagnosed cases.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Case Fatality Rate (CFR) is the most appropriate metric to use when determining the severity or lethality of a disease, as it indicates the percentage of people diagnosed with the disease who eventually succumb to it.

questions.text: A veterinary surgeon presents with fever, muscle pain, joint pain, and weight loss for a few weeks. The fever persists for weeks before resolving, only to relapse. You obtain his blood sample and inoculate it on the medium shown below to isolate the organism. What is the likely organism? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Brucella

 

Clinical vignette is suggestive of undulant fever affecting at-risk population (veterinary worker). Brucella affects the reticuloendothelial system and presents as PUO, arthralgia, sweating, Loss of weight. Culture shown above is the biphasic (Solid: agar slant, Liquid: Broth) CASTANEDA medium.

 

Serological tests include ELISA, agglutination and complement fixation tests.

 

Rx: Rifampicin + Doxycycline / Streptomycin + doxycycline for 6 weeks.                                        

 

Prevention with pasteurization

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Burkholderia is a GNB (similar to pseudomonas family) that causes hospital acquired infection, colonization in Bronchiectasis, Cystic fibrosis and PUO. Ashdown media is selective media.

 

Treatment with Ceftazidime/Carbapenem in intensive phase(2weeks) followed by TMP-SMX/Amoxyclav as Eradication for 3-6 months.

 

Option B. Coxiella is an intracellular organism causing Q fever, causing culture negative infective endocarditis. Diagnosis is based on serology as they have deficient cell wall.

 

Option C. Mycobacterium is grown on MGIT or LJ (Lowenstein jensen media)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brucella is identified in individuals with undulating fever and systemic symptoms, particularly in those working with animals. The organism can be cultured on Castaneda biphasic medium and requires specific serological tests for confirmation.

questions.text: Identify the labelled structure in the image? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Midbrain

 

The labeled structure is the midbrain, which can be identified on the basis of the red nuclei, substantia nigra and aqueduct of Sylvius.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The midbrain is identified on MRI scans by anatomical structures including the red nuclei, substantia nigra, and the cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented to the hospital with palpitations. Physical examination showed diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space with pistol shots over femoral arteries. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Aortic regurgitation

 

Palpitations with diastolic murmur (Neoaortic area) suggest volume overload likely Aortic regurgitation. Pistol shot over femoral (traube sign) suggestive of chronic Aortic insufficiency.

 

Blood enters from Aorta →LV during diastole (central runoff = fall in DBP). Increased EDV (regurgitant fraction of blood) causes increase stretch of muscle (Frank starling law) → increase SBP.

 

↑SBP + ↓DBP = Wide Pulse pressure

 

Other Options:
 

Option A. Aortic stenosis causes ejection systolic murmur in aortic area.

 

Option C. Mitral regurgitation causes pansystolic murmur with volume overload.

 

Option D. Tricuspid regurgitation = Pansystolic murmur increase on inspiration (carvallo sign)

 

Educational Objective:

 

A diastolic murmur in the left 3rd intercostal space with pistol shots over femoral arteries is highly indicative of aortic regurgitation.

 

Ref: Harrison 21E/Physical Examination of CVS/Chapter 239

questions.text: A 47-year-old male patient comes with abdominal pain and hepatomegaly. Ultrasound image is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydatid cyst

 

The above USG picture shows the characteristic ‘Water-lily’ sign, also known as the Camalote sign, is seen in hydatid cyst of liver. It occurs when there is detachment of the endocyst membrane which results in floating membranes within the pericyst that mimics the appearance of a water lily.

 

Hydatid cyst is a parasitic disorder caused by larva of E. granulosus (Dog Tape Worm). It is mostly asymptomatic or sometimes, may cause abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting. It commonly affects Liver and Lung. Its management involves Albendazole therapy followed by PAIR (Puncture, Aspiration, Instillation of Scolicidal agents, Re-aspiration).

 

USG Classification of Hydatid Cysts

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B, C & D Amebic liver abscess, Liver abscess and Hepatic cyst will not have a floating membrane in it. The Liver abscess on USG appears as shown below –

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A hydatid cyst shows a characteristic 'Water-lily' sign on ultrasound due to detached endocyst membranes. It is caused by Echinococcus granulosus and is managed with Albendazole and PAIR.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical syndromes is most likely in this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cushing syndrome

 

Cushing syndrome refers to excess cortisol with change in circadian rhythm. Iatrogenic administration remains the most common cause.

 

Clinical features that have high predictive value for Cushing syndrome

 

  • Facial plethora
  • Violaceous striae
  • Easy bruising
  • Muscle weakness /atrophy

 

Onset within 18 months and rapid weight loss, hypokalemia suggest Ectopic ACTH production

 

Screening tests for Cushing

 

1. Overnight 1mg DST (Dexamethasone suppression test)

2. 24hr Urinary Free cortisol

3. Late night salivary cortisol

 

2 screening tests should be positive for diagnosis of ENDOGENOUS HYPERCORTISOLISM

 

High dose dexamethasone test: Differentiates Pituitary vs Ectopic ACTH production (Pituitary sources are typically suppressed)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Advanced obesity: While advanced obesity can present with some similar features, it does not typically cause the full constellation of signs seen in Cushing syndrome, such as facial plethora, violaceous striae, and easy bruising. Additionally, obesity can cause pseudo-Cushing's syndrome on biochemical analysis.

 

Option C. Acromegaly: This condition is characterized by the enlargement of hands and feet, hyperglycemia, and new-onset diabetes mellitus. The physical signs differ significantly from those of Cushing syndrome.

 

Option D. PCOS: Polycystic Ovary Syndrome presents with hirsutism, irregular menstrual cycles, and sometimes obesity, but it does not typically cause the physical signs of Cushing syndrome such as violaceous striae, buffalo hump, or easy bruising.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing syndrome is characterized by a constellation of signs and symptoms due to prolonged exposure to high cortisol levels, including facial plethora, buffalo hump, violaceous striae, easy bruising, and muscle weakness. It requires specific screening tests for diagnosis, and the most common cause is iatrogenic glucocorticoid use.

questions.text: Minimum number of antenatal visits according to WHO is? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 8

 

Explanation:

 

Protocol for Antenatal Visits  

 

MOHFW (Indian guidelines)

 

  • At least 4 visits including the first (Registration visit) – Minimum requirement
  • Suggested schedule
    • 1st Visit: Within 12 weeks
    • 2nd Visit: 14 – 26 weeks
    • 3rd Visit: 28 – 34 weeks
    • 4th visit: 36 weeks – term

 

WHO (2016): 8 visits.

 

  • 1st Trimester: 
    • Contact 1: upto 12 weeks
  • 2nd Trimester
    • Contact 2 (20 weeks) & Contact 3 (26 weeks)
  • 3rd Trimester  
    • Contact 4 (30 week), Contact 5 (34 weeks), contact 6 (36 weeks), contact 7 (38 weeks) & Contact 8 (40 weeks)

 

Ideally (& as per ACOG): once every month till 28 weeks, every 2 weeks till 36 weeks and then weekly till 40 weeks: So total of 12 – 14 visits.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The World Health Organization recommends a minimum of 8 antenatal visits to ensure comprehensive care and monitoring throughout pregnancy.

 

Ref: WHO Website, MOHFW guidelines and Williams Obstetrics, 25th edition

questions.text: A 54-year-old woman presents with complaints of swollen fingers, heartburn, and occasional joint pains. On examination, the skin over her hands was shiny, taut, and thickened with non-pitting edema. There is associated interstitial lung disease and the presence of ANA, Topoisomerase I (Anti-SCL 70), and Polymerase III antibodies. What is the most likely diagnosis here? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis

 

The clinical presentation of swollen fingers, shiny and taut skin with non-pitting edema, and the presence of specific antibodies (ANA, Topoisomerase I, and Polymerase III) strongly suggest diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSc).

 

Diffuse Cutaneous Systemic Sclerosis (dcSSc):

 

  • Skin Involvement: Includes both proximal and distal skin thickening.
  • Pulmonary Involvement: More commonly associated with interstitial lung disease (ILD) than pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH).
  • Antibodies: Presence of Anti-SCL 70 (Topoisomerase I) and RNA Polymerase III antibodies are characteristic.
  • Other Features: Constitutional symptoms are common, and renal involvement can occur early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Peutz Jeghers syndrome: This is a genetic condition characterized by gastrointestinal polyps and pigmented macules on the lips, oral mucosa, and digits, not by the described systemic sclerosis symptoms.

 

Option B. Limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc): Typically involves skin thickening limited to areas distal to the elbows and knees (face and neck can be involved), and often associated with PAH. Anti-centromere antibodies are more common in lcSSc.

 

Option D. Raynaud's phenomenon: While Raynaud's phenomenon can be a feature of systemic sclerosis, it alone does not account for the extensive skin and systemic involvement described in this patient.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Fast vibration sense is mediated by? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pacinian corpuscles

 

  • Fast vibration sense is mediated by Pacinian corpuscles.
  • Pacinian corpuscles are specialized for sensing high frequency (fast) vibrations and pressure. They are located deeper in the dermis, which makes them ideally suited for detecting rapid changes in texture and vibrations, such as those from a buzzing cell phone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Merkel's cell: Incorrect because Merkel cells (discs) are slow adapting receptors that are best for sensing fine touch and edges, important for two-point discrimination.

 

Option B. Meissner's corpuscle: Incorrect because while they are rapid adapting receptors, they are primarily responsible for fine touch and low frequency vibrations, not fast vibrations.

 

Option D. Ruffini's endings: Incorrect because Ruffini endings are slow adapting receptors that sense skin stretch and sustained pressure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rapid adapting touch receptors are -

 

  • Meissner's corpuscle – responsible for fine Touch, Low frequency Vibration (tap and flutter) present in superficial dermis i.e., dermal papillae
  • Pacinian corpuscles it senses High Frequency (Fast) vibration and pressure as it is present deeper in the dermis.
  • Hair end organ - Mechanoreceptor

 

[Note- always remember corpuscles are rapid adapting]

 

Slow adapting touch receptors are:

 

  • Merkel disc: it senses fine touch and Edges so best for Two Point Discrimination located in epidermis
  • Ruffini's endings: it senses skin stretch and Sustained Pressure

questions.text: A 45-year P3L3 woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Adenomyosis

 

Explanation:

 

Adenomyosis is characterized by the presence of endometrial tissue within the myometrium, leading to a uniformly enlarged uterus often associated with pain and heavy menstrual bleeding. In multiparous women over 40 years old, presenting with a lower abdominal mass, discomfort, and myometrial cysts on MRI, adenomyosis is a highly probable diagnosis.

 

Clinical features of adenomyosis:

 

  • Age and parity: Commonly affects multiparous women over 40 years old.
  • Symptoms: Lower abdominal mass, discomfort, heavy menstrual bleeding (menorrhagia), and dysmenorrhea.
  • Physical examination: Uniformly enlarged uterus with free adnexa.
  • Imaging: MRI showing myometrial cysts, irregular endo-myometrial junctional zone, and bulky myometrium.

 

Management of adenomyosis:

 

  • Definitive treatment: Total hysterectomy, especially if the family is complete.
  • Other options: NSAIDs and anti-fibrinolytics to manage dysmenorrhea and menorrhagia, combined oral contraceptives (OCPs), and Levonorgestrel-containing intrauterine device (IUCD) (MIRENA).

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Endometriosis: Endometriosis involves the presence of endometrial tissue outside the uterus, often causing pelvic pain, dysmenorrhea, and infertility. It does not typically present with a uniformly enlarged uterus or myometrial cysts.

 

Option C. Leiomyoma: Leiomyomas (fibroids) are benign tumors of the smooth muscle of the uterus. They can cause an enlarged uterus, but the enlargement is usually irregular, not uniform. Myometrial cysts are not a feature of fibroids.

 

Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia: Endometrial hyperplasia is the thickening of the endometrial lining, which can present with abnormal uterine bleeding. It does not typically cause a uniformly enlarged uterus or myometrial cysts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Adenomyosis is characterized by a uniformly enlarged uterus, often in multiparous women over 40 years old, and is identified by the presence of myometrial cysts on imaging.

 

Ref: https://obgyn.onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/full/10.1002/uog.19096

questions.text: A 56-year-old man presents with a facial lesion as shown in the image below. On examination, the lesions are painful & the edges are well demarcated & raised. Ear is also showing similar erythematous lesions. He also complains of blisters over his body. He is otherwise normal & does not have any other diseases. This infection is most likely to be caused by which of the following organisms?(FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Group A streptococcus

 

  • In the provided image, erythematous skin lesions with clearly defined borders are visible. It has a raised edge. This is the hallmark of erysipelas. It is brought on by Group A streptococcus in patients who are immune-competent.
  • Erysipelas is a bacterial infection of the dermis and lymphatic tissue.

 

The most common site is the leg followed by the face. It can also affect the ear.

 

 

Clinical features of Erysipelas:

 

  • The affected area will be covered in erythema, heat, swelling, pain, or tenderness in the patients.
  • The edge of the lesion is well demarcated & raised.
  • Blistering can also be seen.
  • Milian’s ear sign is used to distinguish between erysipelas and cellulitis of the facial region, where there is involvement of ear in erysipelas and sparing in cellulitis, as there is no deeper dermal tissue and subcutaneous fat in the pinna.

 

 

  • Milian’s ear sign: Depicted in the images above

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Group B streptococcus, which is less common but can still cause infection in infants under three months old and pelvic erysipelas following surgery.

 

Option C. Staphylococcus aureus is NOT associated with Erysipelas.

 

Option D. Facial cellulitis is brought on by type b Hemophilus influenza.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Erysipelas as a skin infection most commonly caused by Group A streptococcus, which presents with painful, well-demarcated, raised lesions with erythema.

 

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology- 9th Edition Chapter 26 page no 26.17-21

questions.text: 30-year-old woman presents with headache, amenorrhea, loss of libido and infertility with acromegaly. Examination shows bitemporal hemianopia. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Mammotroph adenoma

 

The patient presents with multiple symptoms indicative of a pituitary adenoma. Her symptoms include headache, amenorrhea, loss of libido, infertility, and acromegaly. Additionally, she has bitemporal hemianopia, which suggests structural compression of the optic chiasm by a pituitary mass.

 

A mammotroph adenoma, also known as a prolactinoma, produces excess prolactin (PRL). High levels of prolactin can cause amenorrhea, loss of libido, and infertility. Furthermore, the mammotroph adenoma can also secrete growth hormone (GH), leading to acromegaly. This combination of symptoms makes mammotroph adenoma the most likely diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Gonadotroph adenoma: Gonadotroph adenomas typically do not produce significant hormonal symptoms as they are usually non-functional. They often present with mass effects such as headache and visual disturbances, but they do not cause the endocrine symptoms seen in this patient (acromegaly, amenorrhea, loss of libido).

 

Option C. Corticotroph adenoma: Corticotroph adenomas are functional tumors that produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), leading to Cushing's disease. These are typically microadenomas and do not present with the symptoms of acromegaly, amenorrhea, or loss of libido described in this case.

 

Option D. Glioma: Gliomas are tumors of the glial cells, which are supportive cells in the central nervous system. They do not typically cause endocrine symptoms like those observed in this patient. Gliomas would present with neurological deficits depending on their location but are not associated with the hormonal symptoms noted here.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A mammotroph adenoma (prolactinoma) can produce both prolactin and growth hormone, leading to symptoms such as amenorrhea, loss of libido, infertility, and acromegaly, along with bitemporal hemianopia due to compression of the optic chiasm.

questions.text: Which cell in the liver is primarily responsible for phagocytosis, similar to the crucial role played by macrophages in phagocytosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Kupffer cell

 

Kupffer cells are specialized macrophages located in the liver. They play a crucial role in phagocytosis, similar to macrophages found in other tissues. They are situated in the sinusoids of the liver, which are blood vessels that allow the cells to interact directly with blood components. In addition to phagocytosis, Kupffer cells secrete cytokines and other mediators that help in the immune response and inflammation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lymphocytes: Lymphocytes are a type of white blood cell involved in the adaptive immune response, but they are not primarily responsible for phagocytosis.

 

Option B. Parietal Cell: Parietal cells are found in the stomach and are responsible for secreting hydrochloric acid (HCl) and intrinsic factor, not for phagocytosis.

 

Option D. Hepatocytes: Hepatocytes are the main functional cells of the liver involved in metabolism, detoxification, and protein synthesis, but they do not play a primary role in phagocytosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Macrophages of the liver - Kupffer cells

 

Specialized macrophages:

questions.text: A patient is started on a DMARD which requires regular monitoring of visual acuity and fundus examination. Identify the drug. (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Hydroxychloroquine


DMARD stands for Disease Modifying Anti Rheumatoid drugs, which slow down the progression of the disease process in rheumatoid arthritis. These drugs are used to treat autoimmune conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, psoriatic arthritis and SLE.

 

Hydroxychloroquine toxicity causes corneal opacity and bull's eye maculopathy. Hence, ophthalmic monitoring every 12 months is necessary.

 

Bull’s Eye Maculopathy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Methotrexate: It is a first choice DMARD in Rheumatoid Arthritis. Its side effects include Gastric irritation (Most common), Pancytopenia, Hepatotoxicity, Interstitial pneumonitis, Teratogenicity (Clover Leaf Skull). It requires LFT monitoring.

 

Option C. Sulfasalazine: It is a pro-drug, which is used as the first line in Ulcerative Colitis. It is used in Rheumatoid arthritis when Methotrexate is contraindicated. Its side effects are Malaise, nausea, sulfonamide toxicity, reversible oligospermia

 

Option D. Leflunomide: It is a prodrug and the fastest acting DMARD which inhibits dihydro-orotate dehydrogenase, resulting in inhibition of pyrimidine synthesis and suppression of T-cell proliferation. It also causes Bone Marrow Suppression, Diarrhea, Hypertension, Hepatotoxicity and Teratogenicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hydroxychloroquine requires regular monitoring of visual acuity and fundus examination to detect and prevent ocular toxicities like corneal opacity and bull's eye maculopathy, making ophthalmic monitoring a critical component of its long-term use.

questions.text: A 19-year-old female comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness, amenorrhea, and fatigue. Upon eliciting history, she reveals that she is always worried about gaining weight. Her mother complains that she doesn't eat well. Her BMI is 15.8. Laboratory findings in this patient will show which of the following? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of anorexia nervosa. Anorexia nervosa is a type of eating disorder characterized by self-induced starvation to a significant degree, an intense drive for thinness, a morbid fear of fatness, and the presence of medical signs and symptoms resulting from starvation.

 

In patients with anorexia nervosa, there is hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone (CRH). This hormonal alteration is part of the body's stress response to severe caloric restriction and malnutrition. The hypersecretion of CRH can lead to an increase in the secretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) and cortisol, contributing to many of the physiological changes seen in these patients, including amenorrhea and fatigue.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Hypocholesterolemia: Hypocholesterolemia is not typically associated with anorexia nervosa. In fact, patients with anorexia nervosa may have elevated cholesterol levels due to changes in liver metabolism and reduced clearance of cholesterol from the blood.

 

Option B. Hyperthyroidism: Hyperthyroidism is not a common finding in patients with anorexia nervosa. These patients are more likely to exhibit symptoms of hypothyroidism (e.g., bradycardia, cold intolerance) due to the body's metabolic adaptation to chronic starvation.

 

Option D. Hyperglycemia: Hyperglycemia is not typical in patients with anorexia nervosa. These patients often present with hypoglycemia due to reduced caloric intake and depleted glycogen stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypersecretion of corticotrophin-releasing hormone is seen in patients with anorexia nervosa and is part of the body's stress response to severe caloric restriction and malnutrition.

 

Ref: Page no 376, Williams Gynecology, 3rd edition

questions.text: A 30-year-old female patient presents to the clinic with complaints of fatigue and weakness. After laboratory tests reveal iron deficiency anemia, Now you have to advise the patient on dietary sources of iron to help increase her iron levels. Which of the following foods should be identified as containing the least amount of iron? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Milk

 

Milk contains the least amount of iron among the listed foods. While beans, spinach, and liver are all rich sources of iron, milk is not considered a good source of this mineral.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Beans: A good source of iron, especially for vegetarians.

 

Option C. Spinach: Contains a significant amount of iron, though it is non-heme iron, which is less readily absorbed than the heme iron found in animal products.

 

Option D. Liver: One of the richest sources of iron, particularly heme iron, which is highly bioavailable.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Among the given options, milk has the least iron content. Human milk has a better bioavailability of iron compared to cow’s milk. Liver, meat, beans, spinach have high iron content.

questions.text: Dr. Arjun, a public health researcher in Kolkata, is tasked with formulating guidelines for a novel health intervention in the community. Recognizing the complex nature of the task, he opts for delphi method that seeks expert consensus. Given this approach which of the following best describes the method Dr. Arjun is employing? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Group

 

Delphi is a type of group discussion to arrive at the solution of a complex problem. The problems and solutions are shared with other groups, so as to make the final outcome acceptable and practically implementable for all sectors of the society.

 

Delphi Method

 

  • Is a ‘systematic interactive forecasting method’ for obtaining consensus forecasts from a panel of independent experts
  • Objective of most Delphi applications: The reliable and creative exploration of ideas or the production of suitable information for decision-making
  • In general, the Delphi method is useful in answering one, specific, single-dimension question
  • Mini-Delphi or Estimate-Talk-Estimate (ETE): The delphi technique when adapted for use in face-to-face meetings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Total Population: This would involve collecting data or feedback from the entire population, which is not practical or necessary for the Delphi method, which focuses on expert opinion.

 

Option C. Community: While the community may benefit from the guidelines formulated through the Delphi method, the process itself does not directly involve the entire community but rather a selected group of experts.

 

Option D. Individual: The Delphi method does not focus on individual opinions in isolation but rather on the collective consensus of a group of experts.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Delphi method is a type of group discussion and consensus-building process used to solve complex problems by collecting and synthesizing expert opinions through multiple rounds of questionnaires and feedback.

questions.text: 24-year-old presents with prolonged menstrual bleeding. Her investigations showed normal platelet, PT, aPTT while bleeding time was increased. Further analysis showed GpIIb-IIIa deficiency. What is the likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Glanzman thrombaesthenia

 

The patient has prolonged menstrual bleeding with normal platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT), but an increased bleeding time. This pattern suggests a qualitative platelet defect rather than a quantitative deficiency or a coagulation factor disorder. The specific finding of GpIIb-IIIa deficiency confirms the diagnosis of Glanzmann thrombasthenia. Glanzmann thrombasthenia is a rare autosomal recessive disorder characterized by the lack of GpIIb-IIIa, a receptor necessary for platelet aggregation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bernard-Soulier syndrome: Bernard-Soulier syndrome results from a deficiency in GpIb-IX, which is involved in platelet adhesion. It presents with increased bleeding time and normal clotting time but is also associated with macrothrombocytopenia (abnormally large platelets and a low platelet count), which is not seen in this patient.

 

Option C. Hemophilia: Hemophilia is a coagulation factor deficiency (typically factor VIII in Hemophilia A or factor IX in Hemophilia B). It presents with prolonged PT and/or aPTT, not with isolated increased bleeding time. The patient’s normal PT and aPTT exclude hemophilia.

 

Option D. Von Willebrand disease: Von Willebrand disease causes both quantitative and qualitative platelet defects and can present with increased bleeding time and sometimes prolonged aPTT. However, it does not specifically involve GpIIb-IIIa deficiency. The specific finding of GpIIb-IIIa deficiency makes Glanzmann thrombasthenia the correct diagnosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glanzmann thrombasthenia is characterized by GpIIb-IIIa deficiency, leading to increased bleeding time with normal platelet count, PT, and aPTT, indicative of a qualitative platelet defect.

choices.text: Maximum reabsorption in loop of Henle
Maximum water absorption take place in collecting duct
Amino acid is reabsorbed in proximal tubule

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about renal tubular transport? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Amino acid is reabsorbed in proximal tubule

 

Amino acids, along with glucose, are completely (100%) reabsorbed in the proximal convoluted tubule (PCT). This is a vital process in preventing the loss of essential nutrients.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maximum reabsorption in loop of Henle: Maximum reabsorption of all substances take place in the PCT, except Mg2+ which takes place in Ascending limb of LOH via paracellular transport

 

Option B. Urea is absorbed 100% in PCT: Complete Reabsorption of Urea never takes place, some amount (Approx. 52%) of urea absorption occur in PCT and secreted in the thin ascending loop of Henle.

 

Option C. Maximum water absorption take place in collecting duct: Maximum water reabsorption take place in the PCT (60- 70%); CD reabsorb only 8-10% of water under the influence of ADH

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Amino acids are completely reabsorbed in the proximal tubule along with glucose, highlighting the tubule's critical role in conserving essential nutrients. Most other substances also see significant reabsorption in the PCT, contrary to some options which suggest otherwise.

questions.text: In which condition is the reservoir sign seen along with mastoid tenderness?(FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Acute mastoiditis

 

Reservoir sign along with the tenderness of the mastoid is seen in acute mastoiditis.

 

  • Positive reservoir sign, is when meatus immediately fills with pus after it has been mopped out and it is seen in acute / coalescent mastoiditis
  • Clinical features of acute mastoiditis – Presents with pain behind the ear, fever, ear discharge which is pulsatile.
  • Signs – Mastoid tenderness, light house sign positive (pulsatile ear discharge), reservoir sign positive, sagging of posterosuperior canal wall, tympanic membrane perforation, swelling over the mastoid region.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Otosclerotic lesion: This is primarily a condition that affects the bones of the middle ear leading to hearing loss, not associated with infection or signs like the reservoir sign.

 

Option C. Intra-tympanic glomus tumor: A vascular tumor that might cause pulsatile tinnitus and hearing loss but is not associated with infection-related signs such as the reservoir sign or mastoid tenderness.

 

Option D. Chronic suppurative otitis media: While this condition involves persistent ear discharge, the specific combination of reservoir sign and mastoid tenderness is more characteristic of acute mastoiditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Acute mastoiditis is identified by symptoms like pain behind the ear, fever, and characteristics such as the reservoir sign and mastoid tenderness. It is critical to diagnose and treat acute mastoiditis promptly to prevent further complications such as intracranial spread of the infection.

questions.text: A one and half -year-old child presents with 1st episode of wheeze and breathing difficulty. Chest X-ray shows bilateral hyperinflation. Which of the following can be a causative organism for this case? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) RSV

 

Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is a common cause of respiratory infections in young children. The early phase of RSV in babies and young children often presents with mild symptoms similar to a cold. However, in children younger than age 3, the illness can progress to involve the lower respiratory tract, leading to coughing and wheezing. In some children, RSV infection can cause severe respiratory disease, including bronchiolitis and pneumonia, requiring hospitalization.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. S. pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of bacterial pneumonia and can lead to lobar consolidation on chest X-ray rather than bilateral hyperinflation.

 

Option C. H. influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae can cause pneumonia and other respiratory infections but typically does not present with bilateral hyperinflation.

 

Option D. COVID-19: While COVID-19 can cause respiratory symptoms in children, it is less commonly associated with the specific presentation of bilateral hyperinflation seen in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 RSV is a leading cause of wheezing and respiratory difficulty in young children, often presenting with bilateral hyperinflation on chest X-ray, indicating lower respiratory tract involvement

questions.text: Following appearance in IVP is caused by? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ureterocele

 

Adder head / cobra head appearance of ureterocele is seen in the IVP which is suggestive of cystic dilatation of distal ends of unilateral / bilateral ureter.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Horse shoe kidney – Hand-shake/Flower vase sign

 

 

Option C. Bladder tumor: Would typically appear as a filling defect within the bladder on IVP, often irregular appearance.

 

Option D. Posterior urethral valve: Found primarily in male infants, this condition would show a dilated posterior urethra and a thickened bladder wall.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The "adder head" or "cobra head" appearance on an IVP is diagnostic of a ureterocele, representing the cystic dilation of the distal ureter as it enters the bladder.

questions.text: Enzyme deficient in Tay Sachs disease is: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hexosaminidase A

 

This is the enzyme deficient in Tay-Sachs disease. It is responsible for breaking down gangliosides, a type of fat and protein complex found in nerve tissue. When Hexosaminidase A is deficient, gangliosides accumulate, particularly in neurons, leading to the neurological symptoms of Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glucocerebrosidase: Deficiency of this enzyme causes Gaucher's disease, not Tay-Sachs. In Gaucher's disease, glucocerebroside accumulates in cells, particularly macrophages, leading to symptoms such as anemia, bone pain, and enlargement of the spleen and liver.

 

Option C. G-6-PD (Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase): Deficiency in G-6-PD is associated with G-6-PD deficiency anemia, a condition that leads to the destruction of red blood cells (hemolysis) in response to certain medications, foods, or infections. It is not related to Tay-Sachs disease.

 

Option D. Hexosaminidase A & B: While Hexosaminidase A is deficient in Tay-Sachs disease, Hexosaminidase B is not. A combined deficiency of both Hexosaminidase A and B leads to a different disorder called Sandhoff disease, which is similar to but distinct from Tay-Sachs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tay-Sachs disease, is an autosomal recessive disorder involving neurodegeneration and early death. It is a sphingolipidoses or lipid storage disease, due to deficiency of the enzyme Hexosaminidase A. C/F: Mental retardation. Cherry red spot in the macula but No organomegaly.

 

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 245

choices.text: Refer the workers to a pulmonologist for further evaluation

questions.text: A medical officer is evaluating workers in mines suspected of having Silicosis. Considering their clinical presentation, what is the typical initial step for diagnosing tuberculosis, and what should be the subsequent step? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perform a sputum smear examination

 

When evaluating workers in mines suspected of having Silicosis, which is a chronic lung disease caused by exposure to silica dust, it is important to consider the possibility of tuberculosis as well. TB is a common respiratory infection that can occur alongside Silicosis, particularly in occupational settings.

 

The typical initial step for diagnosing tuberculosis is to Perform a sputum smear examination.

 

Sputum Smear Examination:

 

  • Purpose: To visualize acid-fast bacilli (AFB), specifically Mycobacterium tuberculosis, in sputum samples.
  • Stain Used: Ziehl-Neelsen stain is commonly used.
  • Appearance: Acid-fast bacilli appear as bright red rods under the microscope.

 

 

  • Limitations: Lower sensitivity compared to advanced tests, false negatives possible in low bacterial load or extrapulmonary TB.

 

TB Culture:

 

  • Purpose: To grow and isolate Mycobacterium tuberculosis from clinical specimens.
  • Culture Media: Lowenstein-Jensen (LJ) medium, Middlebrook 7H10, and 7H11 agar is commonly used.
  • Time Required: Several weeks of incubation for visible colony growth.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Order a chest X-ray: While a chest X-ray is useful for identifying lung abnormalities and the extent of disease, it is not the initial diagnostic step for TB. It is usually done after a positive sputum smear to assess the extent of lung involvement.

 

Option C. Conduct a Tuberculin skin test (TST): This test is used to identify TB infection but is not specific for active TB and cannot differentiate between latent and active disease. It is also less useful in individuals with previous BCG vaccination or in those with Silicosis.

 

Option D. Refer the workers to a pulmonologist for further evaluation: Referral is often necessary for comprehensive management but not the first step in the diagnostic process.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial step for diagnosing tuberculosis in workers with suspected Silicosis involves performing a sputum smear examination to detect the presence of acid-fast bacilli, which indicates active TB infection.

questions.text: A woman presented in her 8th week of pregnancy seeking MTP. The appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) would be: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 800 mcg

 

Explanation:

 

Medical MTP: Can be done Upto 9 weeks

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The appropriate dosage of Misoprostol (administered by mucosal route) is 800 mcg

questions.text: A patient has swelling in MCP joints. Serum uric acid levels were raised. Doctor will prescribe medicine against which enzyme: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Xanthine Oxidase

 

This is the key enzyme involved in the conversion of hypoxanthine to xanthine and xanthine to uric acid, which is the final step in purine metabolism. Inhibitors of xanthine oxidase, such as allopurinol, are commonly used in the treatment of gout to reduce uric acid production.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thymidylate Synthase: This enzyme is involved in the synthesis of thymidylate, a nucleotide necessary for DNA replication and repair. It is not directly related to uric acid metabolism. Inhibitors of thymidylate synthase are more commonly used in chemotherapy treatments.

 

Option C. ADA (Adenosine Deaminase): This enzyme is involved in purine metabolism, specifically in the deamination of adenosine to inosine. ADA deficiency is associated with severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID), not gout. Therefore, it is not a target for gout treatment.

 

Option D. HGPRT (Hypoxanthine-guanine phosphoribosyl transferase): This enzyme is involved in the salvage pathway of purine synthesis. Defects in HGPRT can lead to Lesch-Nyhan syndrome, which is characterized by overproduction of uric acid, but the enzyme itself is not a direct target for the treatment of gout.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Increased uric acid occur due to deficiency of xanthine oxidase which converts xanthine to uric acid during the catabolism of purine in our body.
