Allopurinol is an inhibitor of xanthine oxidase enzyme. The administration of allopurinol is an effective treatment of gout because it decreases the amount of uric acid produced, which in turn alleviates the formation of sodium urate crystals.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 334-335

questions.text: Rotten egg odor smell is seen with? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Hydrogen Sulphide

 

Hydrogen sulphide (H₂S) is a colourless gas known for its characteristic odor of rotten eggs. It is highly toxic and can be fatal if inhaled in high concentrations.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. HCN: Hydrogen cyanide (HCN) has a characteristic smell of bitter almonds. It is also highly toxic and can cause rapid death.

 

Option C. Arsenic: Arsenic does not have a distinct smell. When it is in the form of arsine gas, it has a mild garlic odor, but arsenic itself is odourless.

 

Option D. Phosphorous: Phosphorus can give off a garlic-like odor, particularly in the form of white phosphorus.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • HYDROGEN SULPHIDE – Rotten egg odor
  • HCN –Bitter almond odor
  • ARSENIC-, PHOSPHORUS - Garlicky odor

questions.text: A 64 years-old patient presented to the OPD with excruciating low backache not responding to NSAIDs. His PSA levels are 100 ng/ml and MRI spine shows lytic lesions at L5-S1. DRE shows asymmetrically enlarged stony hard prostate. Which of the following drug is indicated for the treatment? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Goserelin

 

Advanced Prostate Cancer and Treatment:

 

  • In advanced prostate cancer, Goserelin is the drug of choice. Goserelin is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist which causes inhibition of testosterone production. Prostate cancer is testosterone-dependent, and reducing testosterone levels helps control the growth of the cancer.
  • PSA Levels: Normal PSA levels are < 4.0 ng/mL, while in this case, the patient's PSA is significantly elevated at 100 ng/mL, indicating advanced disease.
  • Symptoms and Findings: The patient's excruciating low backache, not responding to NSAIDs, is explained by the metastasis to the spine (L5-S1) seen on MRI. The digital rectal examination (DRE) showing an asymmetrically enlarged stony hard prostate is indicative of prostate malignancy.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Somatostatin:
    • Somatostatin is not used for prostate cancer treatment. It is primarily used to treat conditions like acromegaly, carcinoid syndrome, and certain types of tumors.
  • Option C. Testosterone:
    • Testosterone is contraindicated in prostate cancer as it can fuel the growth of the cancer cells.
  • Option D. Terlipressin:
    • Terlipressin is a vasopressin analog used to manage variceal bleeding in liver cirrhosis, not for prostate cancer treatment.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Goserelin, a GnRH agonist, is indicated for the treatment of advanced prostate cancer due to its ability to inhibit testosterone production, which is essential for the growth of prostate cancer cells.

questions.text: Identify the following instrument used in anesthesia? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Double Lumen Endotracheal Tube

 

The depicted instrument is a Double Lumen Endotracheal Tube. This specialized tube is designed with two separate lumens or channels. Its unique design serves a critical purpose in specific medical scenarios:

 

1. One Lung Ventilation: The double lumen tube allows for selective ventilation of one lung while the other lung can be deflated. This is termed "one lung ventilation." By isolating ventilation to one lung, surgeons can operate on the other lung without interference from respiratory movements.

 

2. Airway Management during Thoracic Surgery: During certain thoracic surgeries, it becomes essential to collapse one lung to provide a clearer surgical field. The double lumen endotracheal tube permits this by allowing the anesthetist to selectively ventilate or deflate either lung.

 

3. Anatomical Lung Separation: In specific clinical situations where there's a need to segregate a healthy lung from a diseased one, the double lumen tube becomes instrumental. This separation prevents cross-contamination or spread of infection or secretions.

 

4. Differential Lung Protective Ventilation: In lung transplantation patients or situations where one lung is more compromised than the other, the double lumen tube can facilitate differential ventilation. This means each lung can receive individualized ventilatory support based on its health and condition.

 

In essence, the double lumen endotracheal tube is a vital tool in anesthetic and surgical practices, particularly in thoracic surgeries and specific pulmonary conditions.

 

Double lumen tube - They allow selective deflation of one lung whilst maintaining ventilation of the other lung. This is called as ‘One lung ventilation’

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Flexometallic tube:

 

 

Option B. Single Lumen Endotracheal Lumen:

 

 

Option D. Ryle’s tube:

 

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Double lumen tube  allows selective deflation of one lung whilst maintaining ventilation of the other lung. This is called as ‘One lung ventilation’

 

Ref: Miller’s Anesthesia, 9th Ed. Pgs 1392-1393

questions.text: Identify the human fingerprint shown below? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Arch

 

The fingerprint shown in the image is an arch pattern. Arch fingerprints have ridges that enter from one side of the finger, rise in the center forming an arc, and then exit on the opposite side.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Different types of human fingerprints are as below:

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman who recently received a kidney transplant 2 months ago developed a high-grade fever, dyspnea, and hacking cough. Chest X-ray reveals bilateral interstitial infiltrates. Urine examination shows “owl eye” appearance of cells. Which of the following agents is most likely responsible for her condition? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Cytomegalovirus

 

The patient developed high-grade fever, dyspnea, and a hacking cough 2 months after a kidney transplant, which places her in a period of high immunosuppression. The chest X-ray revealing bilateral interstitial infiltrates and the urine examination showing “owl eye” appearance of cells are indicative of Cytomegalovirus (CMV) infection. CMV is a common opportunistic infection in transplant recipients due to their immunocompromised state.

 

Clinical Presentation of CMV Infection:

 

  • CMV typically causes systemic symptoms such as fever and malaise.
  • Respiratory symptoms due to CMV pneumonitis include dyspnea and a non-productive cough.
  • Bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray are common findings.
  • The characteristic "owl eye" inclusion bodies seen in urine cytology are highly suggestive of CMV.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Influenza virus: While influenza can cause similar respiratory symptoms and interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray, it does not produce “owl eye” inclusions in cells.

 

Option B. Respiratory syncytial virus (RSV): RSV is a common cause of respiratory infections but does not cause “owl eye” inclusions.

 

Option D. Adenovirus: Adenovirus can cause respiratory infections and is associated with inclusions, but they are not described as “owl eye” inclusions, which are specific to CMV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Timeline and Infection Risk Post-Transplant:

 

 

This patient is in a period of immunosuppression where CMV/Opportunistic infection are most common. Owl eye inclusion are suggestive of CMV disease.

choices.text: Prescribe oral Antibiotics and follow up after 2 weeks
Give first dose Ampicillin and Gentamicin and refer urgently to hospital
Reassure mother that it’s just cough and cold
Do nothing and refer baby to tertiary care centre

questions.text: A 5-month-old baby has respiratory rate of 58/minute and chest indrawing. The baby has not been able to feed for last 10 hrs. What is the best management? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give first dose Ampicillin and Gentamicin and refer urgently to hospital

 

As per the MNCI-Integrated management of neonate and childhood illness guidelines, as there is a presence of danger sign of not able to feed, it will come as Severe pneumonia.

 

Then the next step in management is to give first dose Ampicillin and Gentamicin and referring urgently to hospital.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prescribe oral antibiotics and follow up after 2 weeks: This is inappropriate for severe pneumonia or very severe disease, as immediate intervention is needed.

 

Option C. Reassure mother that it’s just cough and cold: This is incorrect because the signs indicate a serious condition that requires urgent treatment.

 

Option D. Do nothing and refer baby to tertiary care center: While referral is necessary, immediate administration of antibiotics is crucial before referral.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In infants with severe pneumonia or very severe disease, characterized by chest indrawing and danger signs like inability to feed, the immediate administration of antibiotics followed by urgent hospital referral is essential.

questions.text: What type of antagonism is demonstrated when adrenaline causes bronchodilation through beta-2 receptors while histamine causes bronchoconstriction through H1 receptors? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Physiological antagonism

 

Physiological antagonism occurs when two drugs act on different receptors, resulting in opposite responses in the body. In this case, adrenaline acts on beta 2 receptors, leading to bronchodilation, while histamine acts on H1 receptors, causing bronchoconstriction.

 

Other types of Antagonism: -
 

  • Physical – Substances directly bind to and neutralize the effects of toxins or drugs E.g., Charcoal given in cases of poisoning.
  • Chemical – Substances react to neutralize each other’s effects - e.g., Heparin and protamine sulphate, antacids reducing the acidity of stomach
  • Pharmacological – A drug blocks the effects of another drug by interfering with its target or mechanism of action e.g., Aspirin inhibiting COX enzyme.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chemical antagonism: This involves a direct chemical interaction between two substances, which neutralizes their effects, such as between an acid and a base. It does not apply here as adrenaline and histamine do not chemically interact to neutralize each other.

 

Option C. Reversible antagonism: This term typically refers to the binding of an antagonist to a receptor that can be reversed by increasing the concentration of an agonist. It doesn't accurately describe the interaction between adrenaline and histamine, which act on different receptors.

 

Option D. Competitive antagonism: Occurs when two drugs compete for the same receptor site. Since adrenaline and histamine act on different receptors (beta-2 adrenergic vs. H1 histaminergic), this does not apply.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Physiological antagonism describes the situation where two drugs produce opposing effects through actions at different receptors or cellular mechanisms, as seen with adrenaline and histamine in the regulation of bronchial muscle tone.

questions.text: A 10-year-old girl lies frequently at home and school, misbehaves with her teachers, often fights with younger kids and has been caught stealing money on multiple occasions. What is the likely diagnosis?(FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Conduct disorder

 

The child described in the scenario exhibits a pattern of behavior that violates both societal norms and the rights of others. This pattern includes aggression, theft, and deceitfulness. Conduct disorder is a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior that violates the basic rights of others or societal norms and rules. Children with conduct disorder may be aggressive toward people or animals, destroy property, be deceitful or steal, or violate rules or laws.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antisocial personality disorder is reserved for individuals 18 years or older and often requires a history of conduct disorder before age 15.

 

Option B. Attention-deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is characterized by symptoms of inattention, hyperactivity, and impulsivity but not by the more severe violations of the rights of others.

 

Option D. Oppositional defiant disorder involves a pattern of angry/ irritable mood, argumentative/ defiant behavior, or vindictiveness, but does not include the severe aggressive or deceitful behavior seen in conduct disorder.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Conduct disorder is characterized by a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior in which the basic rights of others and societal norms or rules are violated. This can include aggression towards people or animals, destruction of property, deceitfulness or theft, or serious violations of rules. It differs from oppositional defiant disorder, which doesn't include more serious violations like theft or physical aggression.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 190

questions.text: A 26-year-old lactating female presented with complaints of pain in one breast. On examination, the affected breast was tender and engorged. Baby was not able to feed from the affected breast. What is the best management for this condition? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Incision and drainage with antibiotics

 

The clinical history is diagnostic of breast abscess which would require incision and drainage along with antibiotic coverage.

 

Breast Abscess is commonly seen in lactating mothers. It occurs due to infection with S. aureus which is found in the oropharynx of the newborns. Clinically, the patient presents with tender, red inflamed swollen breast.

 

The diagnosis is based on Ultrasonography.

 

 

Management involves –

 

Antibiotics: Augmentin (Amoxycillin + Clavulanic acid)

 

If pus is present, USG guided aspiration can be attempted twice. If that fails, go for Incision and Drainage.

 

Update: Nowadays, abscesses requiring drainage are managed by “suction catheter drainage”.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Steroid: Steroids, particularly corticosteroids, are anti-inflammatory agents that suppress the immune response and are typically used in inflammatory conditions like autoimmune diseases or allergic reactions. They are not the primary treatment for breast abscesses and might even be counterproductive, as suppression of the immune response could potentially allow an infection to worsen.

 

Option B. NSAIDs: Non-Steroidal Anti-Inflammatory Drugs (NSAIDs) like ibuprofen or naproxen can be used to manage pain and reduce inflammation. While they can be helpful in managing symptoms, they don't address the underlying infection that causes a breast abscess.

 

Option C. Warm compresses: Warm compresses can help to reduce pain and may facilitate the drainage of the abscess to some extent. It is a supportive measure and is often used in conjunction with other treatments to provide symptom relief. While warm compresses can be useful, they alone would not be sufficient to treat a breast abscess.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The best management for a breast abscess includes incision and drainage along with antibiotic coverage to address the underlying infection and prevent further complications.

questions.text: Identify the given non spore forming bacteria? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Corynebacterium diphtheriae

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is the leading causing agent of diphtheria. It is a non-motile, non-encapsulated, non-sporulating gram-positive rod-shaped bacterium with a high GC-content and occurs in four biovars: gravis, mitis, Intermedius, and belfanti, based on colonial morphology and biochemical profiles. It shows Chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement and are termed as metachromatic granules.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thiobacillus Novellus: A non-pathogenic, sulfur-oxidizing bacterium, not typically associated with human disease.

 

Option B. Clostridium Perfringens: A spore-forming, Gram-positive bacterium known for causing gas gangrene and food poisoning.

 

Option C. Escherichia Coli: A Gram-negative, rod-shaped bacterium that is a common cause of urinary tract infections and other infections, but it is not a non-spore-forming Gram-positive rod.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Corynebacterium diphtheriae is a non-spore-forming, Gram-positive rod-shaped bacterium known for its characteristic "Chinese letter" arrangement and the cause of diphtheria.

questions.text: Which of the following nerves get compromised in a lesion at the arrow marked area: (FMGE August 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Radial nerve

 

The radial groove (shown on the posterior view of the humerus) is indicated by the arrow. The radial nerve in the radial groove may be compromised in a mid-shaft humerus fracture, resulting in wrist drop (loss of dorsiflexion) and a few other clinical features such as pain, swelling and bruising, tenderness, crepitus and limited range of motion.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Axillary nerve:  It is a branch of the posterior cord of the brachial plexus. It winds posteriorly around the neck of the humerus together with the circumflex humeral vessels, and supplies deltoid and teres minor and an area of skin over the deltoid region

 

Option C. Median Nerve:  The median nerve enters the arm lateral to the brachial artery. Near the insertion of coracobrachialis it crosses in front of the artery, descending medial to it to the cubital fossa where it is posterior to the bicipital aponeurosis and anterior to brachialis, separated by the latter from the elbow joint.

 

Option D. Ulnar nerve:  The ulnar nerve gives no branches in the arm. It runs distally through the axilla medial to the axillary artery and between it and the vein, continuing distally medial to the brachial artery as far as the midarm. Here it pierces the medial intermuscular septum, inclining medially as it descends anterior to the medial head of triceps to the interval between the medial epicondyle and the olecranon, with the superior ulnar collateral artery.

choices.text: Target of infant mortality to double digit by 2030

questions.text: Dr. Ravi, an aspiring public health official, is reviewing the components of the National Health Mission (NHM) for his upcoming examination. He is aware that NHM focuses on various health strategies and services to improve maternal and child health in India. He comes across a list detailing the key elements under NHM. Which of the following is NOT a standard component mentioned within the official National Health Mission framework? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Target of infant mortality to double digit by 2030

 

The National Health Mission (NHM) in India encompasses a wide range of health strategies aimed at improving maternal and child health among other healthcare objectives. However, the specific target of reducing infant mortality to double digits by 2030 is not explicitly mentioned within the NHM framework.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Antenatal care: Regular check-ups and screenings during pregnancy to monitor the health of the mother and fetus.

 

Option C. Postnatal visits: Follow-up visits after childbirth to ensure the health and well-being of the mother and newborn.

 

Option D. Care during labor: Monitoring and support during childbirth to ensure safe delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

NHM Components 

 

 

Additional Information

 

Goals of NHM: (According to XII FYP 2012-17)

 

  • Reduce MMR to 1/1000 live births
  • Reduce IMR to 25/1000 live births
  • Reduce TFR to 2.1
  • Prevention and reduction of anaemia in women aged 15–49 years
  • Prevent and reduce mortality & morbidity from communicable, non-communicable; injuries and emerging diseases
  • Reduce household out-of-pocket expenditure on total health care expenditure
  • Reduce annual incidence and mortality from Tuberculosis by half
  • Reduce prevalence of Leprosy to <1/10000 population and incidence to zero in all districts
  • Annual Malaria Incidence to be <1/1000
  • Less than 1 per cent microfilaria prevalence in all districts
  • Kala-azar Elimination by 2015, <1 case per 10000 population in all blocks

choices.text: Ischiocavernosus contraction – external urethral sphincter relaxation – Bulbospongiosus contraction
Ischiocavernosus contraction – Bulbospongiosus contraction- external urethral sphincter relaxation
Bulbospongiosus contraction - external urethral sphincter relaxation – Ischiocavernosus contraction
Bulbospongiosus contraction - Ischiocavernosus contraction -external urethral sphincter relaxation

questions.text: Choose the correct sequence of events in the process of ejaculation? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Ischiocavernosus contraction – Bulbospongiosus contraction- external urethral sphincter relaxation

Explanation:

 

 

The sequences of events:

Ejaculation involves a series of muscle contractions that expel seminal fluid from the prostatic urethra to the exterior, encompassing both autonomic and somatic control components. The correct sequence begins with the contraction of the ischiocavernosus muscle, which aids in the erection of the penis by compressing the base of the penile shaft and obstructing blood flow out of the erect penis, thereby maintaining its rigidity. Following this, the bulbospongiosus muscle contracts, which propels the seminal fluid along the urethra. The final step is the relaxation of the external urethral sphincter, which allows the semen to exit the urethra.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct sequence of muscular contractions during ejaculation: first, the ischiocavernosus muscle contracts to maintain erection, followed by the contraction of the bulbospongiosus muscle to propel seminal fluid, and finally, the relaxation of the external urethral sphincter allows the ejaculate to exit.

 

Reference - Gray’s Anatomy- the Anatomical basis of clinical practice – 42nd edition- page no. 1304

questions.text: After overhead weight-lifting exercises, a patient developed the following deformity. Which specific muscle or muscle group is likely to be involved in causing this deformity? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Serratus anterior

 

The condition shown in the figure is the winged scapula. Dysfunction or weakness of the serratus anterior muscle can lead to a condition known as "winged scapula." This condition is characterized by the medial border of the scapula sticking out from the rib cage, rather than lying flat against it. It can result in pain, limited shoulder movement, and functional impairment.

 

Serratus anterior muscle (boxer’s muscle) receives innervation from long thoracic nerve, which when damaged results in paralysis of muscle, the phenomenon known as winged scapula

 

Repetitive overhead movements presented with scapular dyskinesis (which is an abnormal scapulohumeral interaction during kinetic motion) and medial scapular winging caused by overhead weight-lifting exercises.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Lattissimus dorsi: Latissimus dorsi is supplied by the thoracodorsal nerve, from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus, C6, 7 and 8. It is active in adduction, extension and especially in medial rotation of the humerus.

 

Option B. Trapezius: Trapezius is innervated by the spinal part of the accessory nerve. Sensory (proprioceptive) branches are derived from the ventral rami of C3 and C4. Acting with levator scapulae, the upper fibres elevate the scapula and with it the point of the shoulder; acting with serratus anterior, trapezius rotates the scapula forward (upwards) so that the arm can be raised above the head; and acting with the rhomboids, it retracts the scapula, bracing back the shoulder. With the shoulder fixed, trapezius may bend the head and neck backwards and laterally.

 

Option D. Supraspinatus: Supraspinatus is innervated by the suprascapular nerve, C5 and 6. supraspinatus initiates abduction of the shoulder and assists deltoid in abduction. As part of the rotator cuff, supraspinatus helps to stabilize the head of the humerus in the glenoid fossa during movements of the glenohumeral joint.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The serratus anterior muscle is critical for stabilizing the scapula against the thoracic wall. Damage or weakness in this muscle, particularly through repetitive or strenuous overhead motions such as weight-lifting, can lead to a winged scapula, characterized by the outward protrusion of the medial border of the scapula.

questions.text: Dr. Kapoor, a pediatrician, is discussing the treatment of acute gastroenteritis in children with medical students, focusing on the role of Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS). He explains why ORS includes both sodium and glucose. What physiological mechanism do these components leverage to enhance water and electrolyte absorption in the intestines? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Co-transport

 

ORS utilizes a combination of sodium and glucose based on the principle of co-transport, specifically via the SGLT-1 (sodium-glucose linked transporter-1) mechanism. This process is a type of secondary active transport where the simultaneous uptake of sodium and glucose from the intestinal lumen into the cells enhances the absorption of water and electrolytes. This synergy is crucial for effectively treating dehydration caused by diarrhea.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Reducing secretions: This option is incorrect because ORS does not function by reducing intestinal secretions but rather enhances absorption.

 

Option B. Osmosis: While osmosis is a mechanism for water movement, the specific action of glucose and sodium in ORS is not solely based on osmotic gradients but on active transport mechanisms.

 

Option C. Facilitative diffusion: This term refers to the passive transport of substances across a membrane without energy expenditure, which is not how glucose and sodium are absorbed in the presence of ORS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The inclusion of sodium and glucose in ORS capitalizes on the co-transport mechanism to enhance the absorption of water and electrolytes in the intestines, critical for treating dehydration in acute gastroenteritis.

choices.text: Minimum area 5 sq. ft. per student
Light coming from front of the expressed glass

questions.text: A school is undergoing renovations to optimize the learning environment for its students. The school board, in consultation with the health department, is evaluating various recommendations for the best health and ergonomic practices in classrooms. Which of the following is a recognized guideline related to the school health environment? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Minus type desk

 

The correct guideline related to the school health environment is the use of Minus type desks. These desks are designed to be ergonomically suitable for students, helping to maintain proper posture and reduce the risk of musculoskeletal issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Minimum area 5 sq. ft. per student: The recommended minimum area per student for sitting is 10 sq. ft.

 

Option C. Can allot 60 students per classroom: The guideline is to have a maximum of 40 students per classroom, ensuring a conducive learning environment.

 

Option D. Light coming from front of the expressed glass: The recommended practice is to have natural light coming from the left side of the students to avoid shadows and glare, which can strain the eyes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

School health service guidelines recommendations are:

 

  • One class room for maximum 40 students
  • Minus type desk
  • Doors and windows ≥ 25% of floor area
  • 1 urinal /60 student, 1 latrine/100 student.
  • Natural light from left side
  • Minimum area 10 sq. ft. per student for sitting.
  • school health examination every 6 months.
  • Walls should be white in colour.
  • Canteen should be present if number of students are more than 250.

questions.text: An elderly male patient was brought by his son because he was not using his left arm for day-to-day functioning. He has an unkempt appearance on the left side of his body and has a history of bumping into door frames while walking through them. The evaluation performed is shown below. Where does a lesion in the brain cause this presentation? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Right parietal

 

Image shows left sided spatial neglect which is a functioning of the non-dominant hemisphere.

 

 

Hemineglect is tested by Double-simultaneous stimulation - tactile or visual stimulus given on one side alone is perceived but when stimulus simultaneously presented on both sides, the affected side is ignored, and the unaffected side is perceived. This is called Extinction.

 

Reference: Neuroanatomy through clinical cases by Halblumenfeld, Page 44

choices.text: Foley catheter at internal os of cervix

questions.text: Which of the following methods of cervical ripening is a type of hygroscopic dilator? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Intracervical laminaria tent

 

  • Among the given options, intracervical laminaria tent is a type of hygroscopic dilator.
  • Hygroscopic dilators are devices that draw water from cervical tissues and expand to gradually dilate the cervix.
  • Laminaria tent is derived from various species of Laminaria algae that are harvested from the ocean floor.
  • Another which is composed of an acrylic-based gel is called Dilapan-S.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Intracervical Dinoprostone gel: This is Prostaglandin E2 gel which is used in cervical ripening and induction of labor. It acts by softening the cervix and inducing uterine contractions.

 

Option C. Foley catheter: Intra-uterine foleys catheter is another way to induce labor. The foleys catheter is introduced just beyond the cervix and in the extra-amniotic space. When the bulb is inflated, it releases prostaglandins and leads to induction of labor.

 

Option D. Misoprostol: This is Prostaglandin E1. It is available as a tablet and is used for many purposes including induction of labor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intracervical laminaria tent is a type of hygroscopic dilator used for cervical ripening by absorbing water and expanding to dilate the cervix.

 

Ref: Page 1250, Williams Obstetrics 26th edition

questions.text: Alcoholic patient presents with neurological symptoms. There is the deficiency of which vitamin: (FMGE DECEMBER 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) B1

 

Chronic alcohol consumption can lead to thiamine deficiency. Thiamine is crucial for carbohydrate metabolism and neural function. Deficiency can lead to Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome, characterized by neurological symptoms such as confusion, ataxia, and eye movement abnormalities. Thiamine supplementation is often necessary in alcohol-dependent individuals to prevent or treat these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin A

  • 3 biologically active forms:
    1. Retinol (having Alcohol (-OH) gp): role in reproduction
    2. Retinal (having Aldehyde (-CHO) gp): role in vision
    3. Retinoic acid (having Carboxyl (-COOH) gp): role in cell growth and differentiation
  • Also have antioxidant activity
  • Vitamin A def lead to Night blindness as dark adaptation time gets prolonged

 

Option C. Vitamin B9 (Folate): Folate deficiency is also common in alcoholics due to poor diet and impaired absorption. While folate deficiency can lead to neurological symptoms like neuropathy and psychiatric symptoms, it is more famously associated with megaloblastic anemia, where it causes large, immature red blood cells.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12 (Cobalamin): Deficiency of vitamin B12 can lead to neurological symptoms, including neuropathy and cognitive disturbances. However, B12 deficiency is less directly associated with alcoholism compared to thiamine deficiency. B12 deficiency is also known to cause megaloblastic anemia, similar to folate deficiency.

 

Educational Objective:

 

As vitamin B1 is mainly involved in oxidative decarboxylation reactions, so in B1 deficiency, highly aerobic tissues e.g. Heart and Brain fail first causing neurological symptoms which is also known as Wernicke’s Korsakoff’s syndrome. It is common in alcoholics due to thiamine deficiency as Alcohol interferes with the absorption of Thiamine.

 

Deficiency of Vitamin B is  known as  Beri-Beri

 

  1. Dry Beriberi  
    • Affect CNS
    • No oedema
  2. Wet Beriberi 
    • Affect CVS
    • Oedema present
    • There is also lactic acidosis in B1 def
    • RBC Transketolase activity is used as a marker for B1 deficiency.
    • Richest source of B1 - Rice Polishing (outer Aleurone layer of grains is rich in Vit B1)

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 536, 542

questions.text: Person with dyspnea has slight limitation in physical activity and doing ordinary activity causes symptoms but he is asymptomatic at rest. Which class of New York Heart Association (NYHA) does he belong to? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Right parietal

 

The patient presents with symptoms suggestive of left-sided spatial neglect, which is a characteristic of a lesion in the right parietal lobe. Spatial neglect, also known as hemispatial neglect, often results from damage to the non-dominant hemisphere, which for most individuals is the right hemisphere. This condition leads to a lack of awareness and attention to one side of the body and space, typically the left side.

 

The right parietal lobe is responsible for spatial orientation and constructional skills. Damage to this area can result in the inability to perceive and interact with the environment on the left side, a condition known as left-sided spatial neglect. This explains the patient's unkempt appearance on the left side of his body, failure to use his left arm, and his tendency to bump into objects on his left.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Class I: Class I patients have no symptoms with ordinary physical activity, meaning they can perform everyday tasks without experiencing any limitations or symptoms. The described patient's symptoms during ordinary activity exclude Class I.

 

Option C. Class III: Class III patients experience symptoms with less than ordinary physical activity, indicating marked limitation in physical activity. They may also experience paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea (PND), although it is not a formal part of the NYHA classification. The patient described does not have such severe limitations.

 

Option D. Class IV: Class IV patients have symptoms even at rest, including orthopnea. This is the most severe class with the highest risk of sudden cardiac death and pump failure. The patient described is asymptomatic at rest, which rules out Class IV.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Risk of Sudden Cardiac Death (SCD) ↑ from NYHA IV →NYHA 1

 

Risk of pump failure from NYHA 1→NYHA IV

questions.text: A man often gets repetitive thoughts of washing his hands repeatedly. This is a feature of which of the following disorders? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Obsessive-compulsive disorder

 

The man's repetitive thoughts about washing his hands is indicative of an obsession, and if he acts on these thoughts by repeatedly washing his hands, that would be a compulsion. These features are characteristic of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Panic attacks are characterized by sudden episodes of intense fear or anxiety with physical symptoms.

 

Option B. Agoraphobia involves fear of being in situations where escape might be difficult or help might not be available.

 

Option D . Generalized anxiety disorder involves chronic, excessive, and uncontrollable worry about everyday events but doesn't involve specific obsessions or compulsions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

OCD is characterised by obsessions and compulsions. Life time prevalence is around 2-3% and is more common among females. Most common presentation is obsessive contamination with compulsive washing followed by pathological doubt with repeated checking. Most common comorbidity is depression. First line treatment includes SSRIs and chlomipramine. Atypical antipsychotics are used as adjunctive treatment.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 415

questions.text: During a lecture on epidemiology and biostatistics at a medical college, Dr. Shyam, an Assistant Professor in Community Medicine, displayed a particular statistical diagram. He emphasized its relevance in illustrating specific types of data. Intrigued by its representation, a student later approached Dr. Shyam seeking clarity about the exact nature of data the diagram was tailored to depict. Which among the following best describes the type of data this diagram represents? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Continuous

 

The given diagram is a histogram, represents continuous quantitative data.

 

Histogram

 

  • Is graphical presentation for ‘continuous quantitative data’
  • Continuous groups are marked on x-axis (abscissa) while frequencies are marked on y-axis (ordinate).

 

Bar Diagram:

 

 

Frequency Polygon:

 

  • Is an area diagram of frequency distribution developed over a histogram: Made by joining mid-points of class intervals at the heights of frequencies.

 

 

Scatter Diagram:

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Nominal:

 

  • Nominal data is categorical and labels or names the categories without any order. Examples include gender, race, or blood type.
  • Bar diagrams are typically used to represent nominal data.

 

Option B. Discrete:

 

  • Discrete data is countable and often represented by integers (e.g., the number of children in a family).
  • Bar charts are more appropriate for representing discrete data.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A histogram is used to represent continuous quantitative data, where continuous groups are marked on the x-axis and frequencies are marked on the y-axis.

questions.text: A young male presents with a history of high-grade fever for 5 days. His hands show the following lesions which are painless, and he has a new regurgitant murmur. 2D ECHO shows a mass on the mitral valve. Which of the following abdomen findings is expected in this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Splenomegaly

 

The patient's presentation of high-grade fever, painless lesions on the hands (likely Janeway lesions), a new regurgitant murmur, and a mass on the mitral valve seen on 2D ECHO is highly suggestive of infective endocarditis (IE). Splenomegaly is a common finding in infective endocarditis due to the immune response and embolic phenomena associated with the disease. The presence of splenic abscesses should also raise suspicion for infective endocarditis.

 

Janeway lesions are non-tender, papular lesions on the palm, sole. Previously it was thought janeway lesions are an embolic phenomenon and Osler nodes are Immunologic phenomenon. Currently both are considered to be micro-emboli affecting different parts of the dermis.

 

Diagnosis = Modified Duke Criteria

 

MAJOR

 

  1. Blood culture: persistently positive
    1. ≥3/4 culture 10ml each drawn from different site ,30-60 mins apart.
    2. ≥ 2 positives taken 24-48 hrs apart.
  2. Coxiella burnetii titres > 1:800
  3. ECHO: findings - Endocardial involvement: Vegetation, abscess, New regurgitation, New valve dehiscence

 

MINOR

 

  1. Predisposing conditions/Risk factors
  2. Fever
  3. Immune phenomenon (Osler nodes, Roth spots, glomerulonephritis.)
  4. Vascular phenomenon (Janeway lesions, emboli, mycotic aneurysm.)

  5. Positive Blood cultures not meeting major criteria.

     

  • Definitive IE: ≥2 major (or) 1 major + 3 minor (or) 5 minor
  • Probable IE: 1 major + 1 minor(or) 3 minor

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatomegaly: While hepatomegaly can occur in various conditions, it is less specifically associated with infective endocarditis compared to splenomegaly.

 

Option B. Portal hypertension: This is typically associated with chronic liver disease and is not a direct consequence of infective endocarditis.

 

Option D. Ascites: Ascites is generally associated with liver disease, heart failure, or other conditions leading to fluid accumulation in the peritoneal cavity. It is not a common finding in infective endocarditis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Splenomegaly is a common abdominal finding in infective endocarditis due to embolic phenomena and the body's immune response.

 

Ref: Harrison 21E/Infective endocarditis/Chapter 128

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman comes with chronic vulval itching and pain. On examination, there is a vulval lesion suspicious of vulval cancer. Which of the following lymph nodes should be considered for sentinel node biopsy to look for the metastatic spread?(FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Superficial inguinal lymph nodes

 

Explanation:

 

The vulva primarily drains into the superficial inguinal lymph nodes. These nodes are the first group of lymph nodes to receive lymphatic drainage from the vulva. Therefore, they are the most likely site for metastatic spread in cases of vulval cancer. Sentinel lymph node biopsy aims to identify the first lymph node or group of nodes where cancer cells are most likely to spread from a primary tumor. For vulval cancer, this is typically the superficial inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Pelvic lymph nodes: The pelvic lymph nodes are secondary sites for drainage and would be involved after the superficial and deep inguinal lymph nodes.

 

Option B. Cloquet node: Also known as the node of Rosenmüller, this is a deep inguinal lymph node located in the femoral canal, representing a more advanced stage of lymphatic spread.

 

Option D: Deep inguinal lymph nodes: These nodes receive drainage from the superficial inguinal lymph nodes and would be a secondary site for cancer spread from the vulva.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In vulval cancer, the first lymph nodes to which cancer is most likely to spread are the superficial inguinal lymph nodes, making them the primary site for sentinel node biopsy.

 

Ref: Page no 686, Williams Gynecology 3rd edition

questions.text: Deep inguinal ring is a defect in? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Fascia transversalis

 

Deep inguinal ring is a defect in fascia transversalis. It is situated in the transversalis fascia, midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the symphysis pubis approximately 1.25 cm above the inguinal ligament. It lies lateral to inferior epigastric vessels.

 

 

 

The deep inguinal ring is formed during fetal development as part of the process of the testes descending from the abdomen into the scrotum

 

Inguinal canal is a - 4cm long oblique passage lying between deep inguinal ring (laterally) and superficial inguinal ring (medially).

 

It is related above to the arched lower margin of transversus abdominis, and medially to the inferior epigastric vessels and the interfoveolar ligament, when that is present.

 

It serves as the starting point for the inguinal canal, which is a passage that extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial inguinal ring. Structures such as the spermatic cord in males and the round ligament of the uterus in females pass through the deep inguinal ring during their descent from the abdomen into the inguinal canal and ultimately into the scrotum or labia majora

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. External oblique aponeurosis:  lies in the anterior wall and inferior wall (floor) of inguinal canal (in lateral to medial extent of inguinal canal). Superficial inguinal ring is a defect in the external oblique aponeurosis, at the medial extent. The inguinal ligament is formed by the margin of the aponeurosis of external oblique extending between the anterior superior iliac spine and the pubic tubercle.

 

Option B. Internal oblique muscle:  has arching fibres and lies anterior, superior (roof) and posterior wall of inguinal canal (in lateral to medial extent of inguinal canal). It contributes to conjoint tendon in the posterior wall of inguinal canal, at the medial extent. Internal oblique lies deep to external oblique for the majority of its course. Its fibres arise from the lateral two-thirds of the grooved upper surface of the inguinal ligament, where they form a common attachment with the iliac fascia to the inguinal ligament.

 

Option D. Rectus sheath:  Rectus abdominis on each side is enclosed by a fibrous sheath. The anterior portion of this sheath extends the entire length of the muscle and fuses with the periosteum of the muscle attachments. Posteriorly, the sheath is complete in the upper two-thirds of the muscle. In the lower one-third, the posterior layer of the sheath stops approximately midway between the umbilicus and the pubis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The deep inguinal ring is a defect in the fascia transversalis, located specifically midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and the symphysis pubis, just above the inguinal ligament.

questions.text: Dr. Aravind, a diligent researcher from Hyderabad, embarks on a longitudinal study evaluating the emergence of a novel infectious disease in a specific region. Over the course of the study, he notices that more people in the community start manifesting symptoms of the disease as time progresses. During a discussion with his team, he uses a term to describe the increased risk of the disease in the population over a specified time frame. Which of the following terms most accurately captures the essence of his observation? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Cumulative incidence

 

The Cumulative incidence is calculated as the number of new events or cases of disease divided by the total number of individuals in the population at risk for a specific time interval. Researchers can use cumulative incidence to predict risk of a disease or event over periods of time.

 

Cumulative incidence measures denominator ‘only at the beginning of the study’

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. Incidence: Is defined as the ‘no. of new cases’ occurring in a defined population during a specified period of time. Incidence is a RATE, expressed per 1000. Incidence is the best measure of disease frequency in etiological studies. Incidence can be determined from Cohort study. 

 

Option C. Prevalence: Prevalence: Is total current (Old + New) cases in a given population over a point or period of time. PREVALENCE IS A PROPORTION (Prevalence IS NOT A RATIO). Prevalence can be determined from Cross-Sectional Study. 

 

Option D. Relative risk: Strength of association in a cohort study is evaluated by Relative risk (RR), Attributable risk (AR), Population attributable risk (PAR). 

 

Relative risk (RR) = Incidence among exposed/Incidence among non-exposed

 

RR = Iexposed/Inon-exposed

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cumulative incidence is the most accurate term to describe the increased risk of a disease in a population over a specified time frame, measuring the number of new cases in a population at risk during a given period.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presented with chronic pain in his hand, knees, hips aggravated on climbing stairs, while pain in his hands increases when he writes or types. He also complaints of stiffness in his joints in the morning, which lasts for around half an hour. On examination of the hands, herbedens and bouchard nodes are visible. Xray of the knee showed narrowed joint space with osteophytes. Which among the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Osteoarthritis

 

The patient is an elderly man presenting with chronic joint pain in the hands, knees, and hips, which worsens with activity (e.g., climbing stairs, writing, or typing). The presence of morning stiffness lasting around half an hour and visible Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes strongly suggests osteoarthritis. These nodes are characteristic of osteoarthritis, with Heberden's nodes affecting the distal interphalangeal joints and Bouchard's nodes affecting the proximal interphalangeal joints. The X-ray finding of narrowed joint space with osteophytes further supports the diagnosis of osteoarthritis, a degenerative joint disease characterized by the breakdown of joint cartilage and underlying bone.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bone tumor: Bone tumors typically present with localized bone pain that may be constant and not necessarily related to activity. They are often associated with a palpable mass and other systemic symptoms, none of which are described in this patient.

 

Option C. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis that usually causes prolonged morning stiffness (>60 minutes) and primarily affects the small joints of the hands and feet symmetrically. It is less likely to present with osteophytes and joint space narrowing on X-ray.

 

Option D. Osteoporosis: Osteoporosis is characterized by decreased bone density and increased risk of fractures. It does not typically present with joint pain or stiffness and is not associated with Heberden's or Bouchard's nodes or X-ray findings of narrowed joint space and osteophytes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Osteoarthritis is characterized by joint pain that worsens with activity, morning stiffness lasting less than 60 minutes, and the presence of Heberden's and Bouchard's nodes. X-ray findings typically show narrowed joint space and osteophytes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female, married for the past 5 years, presents with complaints of inability to conceive despite regular intercourse. Physical examination is unremarkable. Semen analysis of the husband revealed no abnormalities. Hysterosalpingography reveals the following picture. The anomaly shown in the image below falls under which category of the American fertility society classification of mullerian duct anomalies? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Class II

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows a hysterosalpingogram of a unicornuate uterus, which falls under Class II of Mullerian duct anomalies
  • AFS Classification of Mullerian Anomalies is as follows
    • Class 1: Hypoplasia/ aplasia
    • Class 2: Unicornuate
    • Class 3: Didelphys
    • Class 4: Bicornuate
    • Class 5: Septate
    • Class 6: Arcuate
    • Class 7: DES related

 

Educational objective:

 

Unicornuate uterus falls under Class II of Mullerian duct anomalies.

 

Ref: Page no 44, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Which of the following structure related to 6th pharyngeal arch? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ductus arteriosus

 

Explanation:

 

The left sixth aortic arch artery contributes to the ductus arteriosus, a fetal vascular structure connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta, which shunts blood away from the non-functional fetal lungs. After birth, it typically constricts and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum.

 

The arteries of body develop from two main sources: pharyngeal (aortic) arch arteries and dorsal aorta.

 

  • The aortic arches give rise to the arteries of head and neck region.
  • The dorsal aorta gives rise to the arteries of rest of the body. the pharyngeal arch artery derived from the aortic sac gives rise to six pairs of aortic arch arteries (fifth pair disappears.) Hence, the five aortic arch arteries are numbered as I, II, III, IV, and VI
  • Sixth arch artery on each side gives off an artery to the developing lung bud.
    1. On the right side, ‘portion of the sixth arch artery beyond the artery to lung bud disappears.
    2. On the left side, portion of the sixth arch artery beyond the artery to lung bud remains patent and forms the ductus arteriosus

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial pterygoid:  It is the muscle of mastication developing from the first pharyngeal arch and supplied by mandibular nerve.

 

Option B. Tensor veli palatini:  It is the muscle arising from first pharyngeal arch.

 

Option D. Lateral pterygoid:  It is the muscle of mastication which develops from the first pharyngeal arch.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ductus arteriosus is a key fetal cardiovascular structure arising from the sixth pharyngeal arch. It is essential for directing blood flow away from the fetal lungs, which are not yet functional, and towards the body.

questions.text: Mother side uncle has disease... Her son has disease. Which type of inheritance is this?(FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) X-linked recessive

 

  • In X-linked recessive inheritance, the gene causing the disease is located on the X chromosome.
  • Males (XY) are more frequently affected because they have only one X chromosome. A single copy of the mutated gene on their X chromosome will cause the disease.
  • Females (XX) are typically carriers if they have one mutated gene; they are affected only if they have mutated genes on both X chromosomes, which is rare.
  • In this scenario, if the uncle (mother's brother) has the disease, the mother could be a carrier. Her son could inherit the affected X chromosome from her, thus exhibiting the disease. This pattern fits well with X-linked recessive inheritance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. X-linked Dominant:

 

  • In X-linked dominant inheritance, having just one copy of the mutated gene on the X chromosome causes the disease.
  • Both males and females can be affected, but the disease is more severe in males.
  • However, if the disease were X-linked dominant, it would likely have affected the mother as well since she would have inherited the gene from her affected father (the patient's grandfather), making this scenario less likely.

 

Option C. Autosomal Dominant:

 

  • In autosomal dominant inheritance, the gene causing the disease is located on one of the autosomes (non-sex chromosomes). One mutated copy of the gene is sufficient to cause the disease.
  • If the disease were autosomal dominant, the mother would likely be affected since she would have a 50% chance of inheriting the gene from her affected parent. Since the mother is not mentioned as being affected, this makes autosomal dominant inheritance less likely in this scenario.

 

Option D. Autosomal Recessive:

 

  • In autosomal recessive inheritance, both copies of the gene on the autosomes must be mutated for the individual to be affected.
  • If the uncle is affected, both of his parents (the patient's grandparents) were likely carriers. However, the mother would have a 50% chance of being a carrier and not necessarily affected. For her son to be affected, the father would also have to be a carrier, and the son would have to inherit the mutated gene from both parents. This is less likely given the information provided.

 

Educational Objective:

 

There is no male to male transmission here, so, it is most probably a X-linked inheritance. In X-linked recessive disorders, 50% of sons will have disease but daughter will be either carrier or normal.

 

 

Important pointers to determine inheritance patterns

questions.text: Which of the statements is correct about Ranula? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Characteristic Transillumination

 

Correct. A ranula often appears as a bluish, transilluminant swelling in the floor of the mouth. This translucent appearance is due to the mucous collection from the sublingual gland, which gives it a characteristic "blue dome" appearance.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mainly a retention cyst: This is incorrect. A retention cyst arises when a duct becomes blocked, leading to a buildup of secretion. A ranula, on the other hand, is primarily an extravasation cyst. This means that the mucus has leaked into surrounding tissues due to a rupture in the duct rather than accumulating due to blockage.

 

Option C. Related to submandibular gland: Incorrect. A ranula arises from the sublingual gland, not the submandibular gland. It is a type of mucocele that specifically occurs in the floor of the mouth due to mucus extravasation from the sublingual gland.

 

Option D. Diagnosed by FNAC: This option is not typically accurate. While Fine Needle Aspiration Cytology (FNAC) can be used to confirm the diagnosis, a ranula is primarily a clinical diagnosis based on its appearance and location. FNAC is not routinely required for its diagnosis. Additionally, FNAC might not always provide conclusive results for a ranula, and there's a risk of causing further mucus extravasation during the aspiration.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ranula often appears as a bluish, transilluminant swelling in the floor of the mouth due to mucus collection from the sublingual gland, which gives it a characteristic "blue dome" appearance.

choices.text: Optic nerve
Optic tract
Optic radiation
Occipital cortex

questions.text: Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing occurs due to lesion at the level of: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Occipital cortex

 

Explanation

 

Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing is a specific type of visual field loss that usually occurs due to a lesion in the occipital cortex.

 

The occipital cortex, located at the back of the brain, is responsible for processing visual input from the eyes. When this area is damaged, particularly if the lesion affects the visual cortex but spares the macula's cortical representation, it can lead to loss of vision in the same half of each visual field (hemianopia) across both eyes, while sparing the central vision (macula). The macula has a more robust blood supply, often provided by both the middle and posterior cerebral arteries, which may protect it from damage during vascular events affecting the occipital region.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A) Optic nerve: (e.g., optic neuritis) – lesion of optic nerve causes complete blindness in the affected side of eye, Homonymous Hemianopia, Central Scotoma (A blind spot in the center of the visual field) and Color Vision Deficits. Injury to optic chiasma can lead to bitemporal hemianopia (loss of peripheral vision in both eyes.Top of Form

 

Option B) Optic tract:   injury to optic tract can lead to contralateral homonymous hemianopia (contralateral nasal and ipsilateral temporal retinal projections).

 

Option C) Optic radiation:  injury to the optic radiation leads to contralateral homonymous hemianopia (loss of right nasal and left temporal vision).

 

Educational objective

 

Contralateral homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing occurs due to lesion at the level of occipital cortex, as may be seen in posterior cerebral artery block.

choices.text: A-Right LMN facial nerve palsy B-Left UMN facial nerve palsy
A-Right UMN facial nerve palsy B-Right LMN facial nerve palsy
A-Left UMN facial nerve palsy B-Right LMN facial nerve palsy
A-Left LMN facial nerve palsy B-Right UMN facial nerve palsy

questions.text:
Patient A is having deviation of angle of mouth to left, right eyelids completely closed, and wrinkling of the forehead on the right side.

 

Patient B is having deviation of angle of mouth to left, the right eyelid is not closed, and no wrinkling of the forehead on the right side. Identify the correct type of facial palsy in both patients: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A-Left UMN facial nerve palsy B-Right LMN facial nerve palsy

 

 

Patient A shows - Left UMN facial nerve palsy and Patient B shows - Right LMN facial nerve palsy.

 

Patient A. Left upper motor neuron lesion:

 

In upper motor neuron lesion, the contralateral side of the face is affected.

 

in this case, the right side of the face is affected patient is having deviation of the angle of the mouth is to the left that means upper motor neuron lesion on the left side.

 

Patient B. Right lower motor neuron lesion:

 

In lower motor neuron lesions, the ipsilateral side of the face is affected.

 

in this case, the right side of the face is affected patient is having deviation of the angle of the mouth is to the left that means lower motor neuron lesion is on the right side.

 

(Deviation of the angle of mouth should not be confused with drooping of the angle of mouth. Deviation of the angle of the mouth occurs on the normal side while drooping occurs on the affected side)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Distinguish between UMN and LMN facial palsies based on symptoms such as forehead wrinkling and eyelid closure. UMN lesions often spare the forehead while LMN lesions affect the entire ipsilateral face.

questions.text: Dr. Sunita, a prominent researcher in Bengaluru, is evaluating the impact of yoga on reducing the risk of infections among healthcare professionals. Her study cohort comprises staff members, nurses, and junior resident doctors, and she further stratifies the participants based on gender. Preliminary findings suggest a 25% decreased risk of infections in those practicing yoga regularly. Given the categorical nature of her variables (job roles and gender) and the outcome of interest (reduced infection risk), Dr. Sunita aims to test the significance of these results. What statistical test would be most appropriate for her to determine the significance of the observed differences in infection rates among the various groups? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Chi square test

 

The Chi square test is used to test relationships between categorical variables. In this scenario, both the groups (staff members, nurses, and junior resident doctors, further stratified by gender) and the outcomes (presence or absence of decreased risk of infection) are categorical. Therefore, the Chi square test would be appropriate to test the significance of observed differences. For a small sample size, we can use Fisher exact test.

 

Other options: 

 

Option A. ANOVA: Is used to analyze the differences among group means in a sample. It's typically used when there are more than two groups, and the dependent variable is continuous. For Numerical variables to be compared between 2 groups we can use Paired- or Unpaired-t Test. 

 

Option C. Z test: Is used to compare the means of two groups, especially when the sample sizes are large, and data meets the criteria of a normal distribution.

 

Option D. Correlation: Refers to a statistical measure that indicates the extent to which two or more variables fluctuate in relation to each other. It does not provide information on causality or significance of differences between groups.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Mr. Raghav, a 52-year-old factory worker from Andhra Pradesh who has worked with groundnuts for several years, visits a hospital with abdominal discomfort and unintentional weight loss. Dr. Agarwal, suspecting a link between his symptoms and occupational exposure, considers the possibility of hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) due to an environmental toxin. Which toxin associated with groundnut processing is most likely responsible for the development of HCC? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Aflatoxin

 

Aflatoxicosis is a fungal toxicosis that may affect all species of animals. The fungus grows on carbohydrate-rich feeds such as peanuts, cottonseed, corn, sorghum and cereal grains when they are stored in hot conditions without adequate drying and aeration. 

 

Aflatoxin toxicity may result in nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, convulsions, and other signs of acute liver injury. Long-term exposure also leads to various complications like growth retardation, cirrhosis, and hepatocellular carcinoma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ergot toxin: Ergot toxins are derived from Claviceps fungi, primarily affecting rye and other cereals, not typically associated with groundnuts.

 

Option C. Sanguinarine: Found in Argemone Mexicana, sanguinarine causes epidemic dropsy and is unrelated to groundnut processing.

 

Option D. Pyrrolizidine alkaloids: These toxins are associated with plants like Crotalaria and do not commonly contaminate groundnuts. They cause endemic ascites, not hepatocellular carcinoma from groundnut exposure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Food adulteration diseases

choices.text: Right testis is undescended and left testis is ectopic
Left testis is undescended and right testis is ectopic

questions.text: A mother while bathing her newborn found the left sided scrotum to be empty. On examination by the pediatrician, left testis is in inguinal region and right testis is in perineum. Which of the following is correct? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Left testis is undescended and right testis is ectopic

 

The left testis in the inguinal region is in the normal path of descent and hence is considered an undescended testis. The right testis is at an abnormal site in the perineum, hence it is considered ectopic.

 

Undescended Testis (Cryptorchidism):

 

  • Cryptorchidism is the failure of descent of one or both testes. The most common site for an undescended testis is the inguinal canal (more common on the right side than the left). Most cases resolve spontaneously. Complications include seminoma and infertility. Patients may have normal testosterone levels, though levels may be reduced if bilateral cryptorchidism is present. There is an increased risk of germ cell tumors. The investigation of choice for intra-abdominal testis is diagnostic laparoscopy.

 

Ectopic Testis:

 

  • An ectopic testis deviates from the normal path of descent. The most common site for an ectopic testis is the superficial inguinal pouch. Management typically involves orchidopexy within 6-12 months.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A (Right testis is undescended and left testis is ectopic):
    • Incorrect because the left testis is in the inguinal region (normal path of descent), making it undescended, while the right testis is in the perineum (abnormal site), making it ectopic.
  • Option C (Both testes are absent):
    • Incorrect as both testes are present but not in the scrotum.
  • Option D (Both testes are ectopic):
    • Incorrect because only the right testis is ectopic, while the left testis is undescended.

 

Educational Objective:

 

An undescended testis is in the normal path of descent but has not reached the scrotum, while an ectopic testis deviates from this path and is found in an abnormal location. Proper identification and management are crucial for preventing complications.

questions.text: A 22-year-old gentleman presented with high-grade fever and a purpuric rash. CSF showed gram-negative diplococci. Which of the following is the most likely etiology? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Neisseria meningitidis

 

The patient presents with high-grade fever and a purpuric rash, and the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis reveals gram-negative diplococci. This presentation is highly suggestive of Neisseria meningitidis, a common cause of bacterial meningitis that can lead to fulminant meningococcemia, which is characterized by a purpuric rash.

 

Neisseria meningitidis typically enters through the oropharynx and spreads hematogenously to the brain. The associated severe complication, Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome, involves adrenal hemorrhage leading to shock.

 

Management and Prophylaxis:

 

  • Immediate antibiotic treatment with ceftriaxone or penicillin is crucial.
  • Chemoprophylaxis for close contacts is recommended using rifampicin, ceftriaxone, or ciprofloxacin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Streptococcus pneumonia: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a gram-positive cocci, not gram-negative diplococci. It is another common cause of bacterial meningitis but would not fit the described gram stain results.

 

Option B. Escherichia coli: E. coli is a gram-negative bacillus, not diplococci. It is more commonly associated with neonatal meningitis rather than in young adults.

 

Option C. Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a gram-negative bacillus and is not typically associated with meningitis in immunocompetent individuals.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Neisseria meningitidis should be strongly suspected in cases of bacterial meningitis with a purpuric rash and the presence of gram-negative diplococci in the CSF. Prompt treatment and prophylaxis for contacts are essential.

questions.text: What is the diagnosis based on the given image of barium enema? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Intussusception

 

The barium meal follow-through shows claw sign which is diagnostic of ileo-colic Intussusception. In CT, intussusception shows a target or sausage shaped soft tissue mass.

 

Intussusception is a form of bowel obstruction in which one segment of intestine telescopes inside of another. Although it can occur anywhere in the gastrointestinal tract, most common site is ileocolic intussusception in a child.

 

In children the most common etiology is thought to be hypertrophied lymphoid mass in the distal ileum following an infection that acts as lead point for intussusception.

 

In adults, the most common lead point is carcinoma (Colorectal Carcinoma).

 

Clinical Features: Intermittent abdominal pain with red currant jelly stools & vomiting. On clinical examination, empty right iliac fossa (Sign de Dance) and sausage like mass in the right upper quadrant

 

 

USG showing Target Sign

 

In children, treatment and diagnosis is done by Enema using water-soluble enema or Air Enema. If this fails then surgical reduction is done.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Carcinoid tumor is a neuroendocrine tumor. It arises from APUD cells or Enterochromaffin cells (Kulchitsky cells) in Lieberkuhn and is a benign, encapsulated & slow growing tumor. These tumor release serotonins. The most common site of Carcinoid is GIT (Small bowel) followed by Lungs. Its tumor markers are 5-HIAA and Chromogranin A (neuroendocrine origin)

 

Option B. Mucoviscidosis is also called cystic fibrosis. It occurs due to deletion of Phenylalanine gene at 508th position (F508 mutation). It is an AR disorder occurring due to defect in CFTR gene on long arm of Chromosome 7. It is characterized by defect in Chloride transport channels which leads to increase sweat chloride levels and reduced water. This causes increased viscosity of bodily secretions, most commonly affecting the Pancreas. It may lead to intestinal obstruction. In neonates, it presents with meconium ileus. Contrast studies reveal filling defects throughout the entire small intestine.

 

Option C. Carcinoma colon arises commonly in the elderly male and is characterized by spurious diarrhea or bleeding, weight loss. It most commonly arises in rectum.

 

 

Note the segmental stricture with shouldering denoting infiltration at right ascending colon and hepatic flexure of the colon.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intussusception is a condition where one segment of the intestine telescopes into another, most commonly seen in children, and is diagnosed by imaging showing a claw sign on barium meal or target sign on CT.

questions.text: Which of the following is confirmatory to ensure central line is in the jugular vein: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Chest Xray

 

The correct placement of a central line in the jugular vein can be confirmed by a chest X-ray. This imaging modality is used to verify the position of the catheter tip and ensure it is correctly located in the intended vein. After insertion of a central line, a chest X-ray is typically performed to confirm proper placement and to check for potential complications such as pneumothorax.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ETCO2: End-tidal carbon dioxide (ETCO2) monitoring is used to assess the adequacy of intubation and ventilation but is not used to confirm the placement of a central line in the jugular vein.

 

Option B. Blood pH: While blood pH can provide information about the patient's acid-base status, it is neither sensitive nor specific for confirming the placement of a central line in the internal jugular vein.

 

Option C. Blood color: The color of blood obtained from the central line can be a subjective assessment and does not provide a definitive confirmation of the line's placement. The appearance of blood alone is not reliable for ensuring the correct positioning of a central line.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A chest X-ray is the confirmatory test used to ensure the correct placement of a central line in the jugular vein, verifying both the position of the catheter tip and the absence of complications.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man in an inebriated state fell in the bathroom and was taken to the casualty. He complained of intense pain in the suprapubic region. On examination, abdominal distention was present without suprapubic bulge. Heart rate and blood pressure was normal. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Intraperitoneal bladder rupture

 

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture commonly occurs when there is trauma/direct blow to the urinary bladder when the bladder is full.  Urine drains into the abdominal cavity and thus suprapubic bulge is not seen. As the urine gets resorbed into the systemic circulation, major electrolyte and metabolic abnormalities may become apparent.

 

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture is less common and occurs commonly at the dome of the bladder.

 

 

Note the leakage of urine into the peritoneal cavity

 

Option D. Extraperitoneal bladder rupture: Extraperitoneal bladder injuries generally occur with pelvic fractures, while intraperitoneal bladder injuries occur with high-energy impact to an overdistended bladder.

 

Extraperitoneal bladder rupture occurs at the base of bladder. It is more common (80%).

 

 

Note the contrast all around the bladder outside the peritoneum
(Molar Tooth appearance)

 

Management:

 

Extraperitoneal bladder injury is managed with an indwelling catheter

 

Intraperitoneal and complex bladder injuries are definitively repaired.
 

Option A. Membranous urethral injury presents with blood at the meatus and inability to pass urine.

 

Option B. Acute urinary retention:

 

  • Acute urinary retention would present with an inability to void, often with a palpable bladder, but not with urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Intraperitoneal bladder rupture results from trauma to a full bladder, leading to urine leakage into the peritoneal cavity, and requires surgical repair. It is important to differentiate from extraperitoneal rupture, which is managed conservatively with catheterization.

choices.text: Curdy white discharge

questions.text: A 29-year-old female complains of foul-smelling vaginal discharge. A Giemsa-stained smear of the discharge is shown below. Which of the following is not seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Curdy white discharge

 

Explanation:

 

  • The image shows Trichomonas vaginalis and infection causes a frothy, greenish-yellow discharge. Curdy white discharge is seen in vaginal candidiasis.

 

 

Other options:

 

Option A. Strawberry cervix: This is seen in trichomoniasis due to the characteristic punctate hemorrhages on the cervix.

 

Option C. Burning micturition: This is a common symptom in trichomoniasis due to the irritation and inflammation of the urethra and vaginal tissues.

 

Option D. Vulval pruritus: Itching is a common symptom of trichomoniasis due to the irritation caused by the infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trichomoniasis typically presents with frothy, greenish-yellow discharge, a strawberry cervix, burning micturition, and vulval pruritus, but not with curdy white discharge which is indicative of candidiasis.

 

Ref: Page no 127, Dc Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: Cofactor for Mitochondrial SOD: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Mn

 

Mn (Manganese): There are several types of SOD, each requiring different metal cofactors. The mitochondrial SOD, uses manganese as its cofactor. This enzyme is crucial in converting superoxide radicals (a type of reactive oxygen species) into hydrogen peroxide and oxygen, thus protecting cells from oxidative damage.

 

Other Options:

 

 Option B. Cu (Copper): Copper is not the cofactor for mitochondrial SOD, but it is important for another type of SOD which is primarily found in the cytoplasm. This form of SOD uses both copper and zinc as cofactors.

 

Option C. Zn (Zinc): Similar to copper, zinc is a cofactor for Cu/Zn SOD (SOD1), but not for the mitochondrial form. Zinc plays a structural role in stabilizing the Cu/Zn SOD enzyme.

 

Option D. Mo (Molybdenum): Molybdenum is not a cofactor for any of the SOD enzymes. It is, however, a cofactor for other enzymes like xanthine oxidase and sulfite oxidase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Cytoplasmic SOD requires Copper (Cu) as cofator
  • But Mitochondrial SOD requires Manganese (Mn) as cofactor

 

Extra Information:

 

  • All Oxidases need Copper Cu2+ (except Xanthine Oxidase and Sulfite Oxidase which requires molybdenum)
  • All Kinases need Mg2+ (But Pyruvate Kinase need K+>> Mg2+)
  • All Carboxylases need Mg2+

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 102

questions.text: A young lady was taken for upper elective LSCS. The drug given during spinal anesthesia was more than planned and this leads to breathlessness in the patient. What is most probably reason for that? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) High Spinal Anesthesia

 

High spinal anesthesia:

 

  • Definition: This occurs when the local anesthetic spreads too high in the spinal column, affecting the spinal nerves above the intended level.
  • Mechanism:
    1. T1-T4 Spinal Nerve Blockade: The blockade of cardio-accelerator fibers in these segments can result in a slowing of the heart rate (bradycardia) and a drop in blood pressure (hypotension).
    2. C3-C5 Blockade: This is particularly critical because the phrenic nerve, which innervates the diaphragm (the primary muscle for breathing), originates from the C3-C5 spinal nerves. When these nerves are affected, it can lead to difficulty in breathing or breathlessness.
    3. C1-C3 Blockade: Blocking these higher cervical spinal nerves can result in sensations like tingling and numbness in the upper limbs.
  • Treatment: Management of high spinal anesthesia typically involves reassurance and oxygen therapy to ensure adequate oxygenation until the effects of the anesthetic wear off.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Septic Shock: While septic shock can lead to breathlessness, it's more associated with infections and would present with other symptoms, such as fever.

 

Option C. Hypoxic Encephalopathy: While hypoxia can lead to breathlessness, it would also present with other neurological symptoms. It's less likely to be the immediate cause of breathlessness in the context of spinal anesthesia.

 

Option D. Cranial Nerve Palsy: Cranial nerve issues wouldn't be a direct result of spinal anesthesia. While some cranial nerves are involved in respiration, the described scenario more directly points to complications from the spinal anesthesia itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

High spinal anesthesia can lead to breathlessness due to the spread of the anesthetic to the cervical and thoracic spinal nerves, affecting the phrenic nerve and cardio-accelerator fibers. Prompt management includes reassurance and oxygen therapy.
