questions.text: Ductus arteriosus develops from which pharyngeal arch artery: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 6

 

Ductus arteriosus develops from the 6th pharyngeal arch, embryologically. The pharyngeal arches give rise to a series of arteries that play important roles in the circulatory system. These pharyngeal arch arteries are temporary structures that undergo significant remodeling and transformation as the embryo develops.  

 

Pulmonary Arteries: The sixth aortic arch arteries initially connect to the pulmonary arteries, but these arteries undergo extensive remodeling during development.

 

Ductus Arteriosus: The left sixth aortic arch artery contributes to the ductus arteriosus, a fetal vascular structure connecting the pulmonary artery to the aorta, which shunts blood away from the non-functional fetal lungs. After birth, it typically constricts and becomes the ligamentum arteriosum

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 3 - Third Pharyngeal Arch Arteries:

 

Common Carotid Artery: The third aortic arch artery contributes to the formation of the common carotid artery, which later divides into the internal carotid artery (supplying the brain) and the external carotid artery (supplying the face and neck).

 

Internal Carotid Artery: The proximal portion of the internal carotid artery is derived from the third aortic arch artery.

 

Option B. 4- Fourth Pharyngeal Arch Arteries:

 

Aortic Arch: The fourth aortic arch artery contributes to the formation of the arch of the aorta and the proximal part of the right subclavian artery.

 

Option C. 5 – This arch does not develop into any major arteries as it typically regresses during embryonic development.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The ductus arteriosus, which is essential for fetal circulation by allowing blood to bypass the lungs, develops from the sixth pharyngeal arch artery. Understanding the embryological origin of this structure highlights its role and transformation post-birth into the ligamentum arteriosum.

choices.text: Klebsiella pneumonia
Miliary TB

questions.text: A 38-year-old patient with HIV, presented to the casualty with shortness of breath, and fever with chills. The chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Miliary TB

 

  • The history and chest X-Ray findings showing bilateral randomly distributed multifocal nodules are suggestive of a diagnosis of miliary tuberculosis.
  • There is widespread dissemination of M. tuberculosis, via the hematogenous route in miliary TB.
  • The term "miliary" refers to the appearance of the small, millet-like TB lesions that form in multiple organs, including the lungs, liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • The symptoms of miliary tuberculosis can be non-specific and can include fever, night sweats.  

 

Other Options:

 

Option A & B. Staphylococcus pneumonia & Klebsiella pneumonia: Typically present with lobar consolidation, pneumatoceles, or abscess formation, rather than the fine, diffuse nodular pattern seen in this X-ray.

 

 

Option D. Histoplasmosis: Can mimic the radiographic appearance of miliary TB, as it can also produce a miliary pattern on chest X-ray, but the patient's clinical history and regional epidemiology would play a critical role in differentiating these.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In patients with HIV presenting with systemic symptoms and a diffuse nodular pattern on chest X-ray, miliary TB should be considered a leading differential, particularly due to their immunocompromised status which predisposes them to disseminated infections. Diagnosis often requires confirmation via microbiological and histological studies to initiate appropriate antimicrobial therapy.

 

Differential diagnosis for miliary nodules:

 

  1. Healed varicella
  2. Tropical pulmonary eosinophilia/Loeffler’s syndrome
  3. Hemosiderosis
  4. Histoplasmosis

choices.text: It is reversible once we remove the cause
It takes 6-10 years to develop
Fibrotic changes in the lungs of the patient can be reversed
TB screening should be done at regular intervals

questions.text: Dr. Aman, a medical officer, conducts health examinations in a Rajasthan mining area and observes several miners with symptoms suggestive of silicosis. He discusses the condition with the mine's supervisor, emphasizing a critical aspect of managing the disease. Which statement about silicosis is accurate? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. TB screening should be done at regular intervals

 

Silicosis, caused by inhalation of silica dust, is an irreversible lung disease often seen in miners. Due to the damage it causes to lung tissue, individuals with silicosis have a significantly increased risk of developing tuberculosis (TB). Therefore, regular TB screening is essential to detect and treat TB early in these high-risk individuals, potentially preventing severe complications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is reversible once we remove the cause: Silicosis is irreversible; removing the cause can halt progression but does not reverse the damage.

 

Option B. It takes 6-10 years to develop: While prolonged exposure increases risk, silicosis can develop within a few months to years depending on the intensity of exposure.

 

Option C. Fibrotic changes in the lungs of the patient can be reversed: The fibrotic changes in the lungs due to silicosis are permanent and cannot be reversed, only managed to prevent further deterioration.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Silicosis: Caused by the inhalation of fine silica dust, often from quartz mining. And there's an increased risk of tuberculosis and certain lung malignancies in miners.

 

  • The particles of the size 0.5 – 3 microns are most dangerous for causation of silicosis.
  • Among the occupational diseases, silicosis is the major cause of permanent disability and mortality.  
  • IP - Few months to 6 years
  • X ray Chest shows ‘snow storm appearance'. 
  • No effective treatment is available
  • Silicosis is a notifiable disease under Factories Act, 1948 and Mines Act 1952.

questions.text: Around 9 to 10 months of age, what type of vertebral spinal curvature typically starts to develop in a baby? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Secondary curvature at lumbar spine

 

At 9 to 10 months, a baby develops a secondary curvature of the vertebral spine in the lumbar region. It happens because the baby is trying to learn to sit and stand at this age.

 

When a baby is born, the vertebral spine has a single C-shaped curve, called a primary curvature, which is present in the thoracic and sacral regions. The thoracic curvature is convex posteriorly, while the sacral curvature is convex anteriorly. These primary curves are present at birth and accommodate the shape of the fetal body within the uterus. In adults, the vertebral column has four curvatures: cervical, thoracic, lumbar, and sacral.

 

The secondary curvature at lumbar spine include the lumbar lordosis, help in distributing the load of the upper body more effectively and contribute to the development of proper posture and facilitate the transition from crawling to standing and walking.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Secondary curvature at cervical spine: The first secondary curvature to develop is the cervical lordosis, which begins during the first few months of life as the baby gains head control. This allows the baby to lift and hold the head upright.

 

Option B. Secondary curvature at thoracic spine: The secondary curvature at the thoracic spine, known as thoracic kyphosis, starts to become more pronounced as the child begins to sit, crawl, and eventually stand upright. This development typically occurs during the first few years of life, usually around the time the child starts to sit independently.

 

Option D. Secondary curvature at sacral spine: The secondary curvature at the sacral spine, sacral kyphosis, is already present at birth as a primary curvature. It remains relatively constant throughout childhood and adulthood. Unlike the cervical, thoracic, and lumbar secondary curvatures, sacral kyphosis does not undergo significant changes as a child grows.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The development of a secondary curvature in the lumbar spine around 9 to 10 months of age is a critical adaptation to the infant’s growing ability to sit and stand. This lumbar lordosis plays a crucial role in enabling upright posture, which is key for further motor development such as walking.

questions.text: Dr. Raghav, an epidemiologist at NCDC, Delhi, is deeply concerned about the rising incidence of malaria over the past decade. With the aim to present his findings in a seminar with states representatives, he is looking for the most appropriate graph to visually represent the secular trend, showcasing the progression and frequency variations of the disease over several years. Given the continuous nature of the data and its long duration, which type of graph would Dr. Raghav most likely choose for a clear and comprehensive representation? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Line diagram

 

A line diagram (or line graph) is most suitable for representing continuous data over a period of time, making it an ideal choice for showcasing secular trends. It effectively illustrates the progression and frequency variations of a disease, such as malaria, over several years by plotting data points on the graph and connecting them with lines to show trends clearly.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Bar graph: A bar graph is used to display categorical data and can show comparisons among discrete categories. It is not the best choice for illustrating continuous data over a long duration as it does not show trends as effectively as a line graph.

 

 

Option C. Box and whiskers plot: This plot is used to display the distribution of a data set and its variability. It shows the minimum, first quartile, median, third quartile, and maximum, but it is not ideal for showing trends over time.

 

 

 

Option D. Stem and Leaf Plot: A stem and leaf plot is used to display quantitative data in a semi-tabular format. It is useful for small data sets and for identifying the shape of the data distribution but not for visualizing trends over a prolonged period.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A line diagram is the best choice for representing secular trends, illustrating the progression and frequency variations of continuous data over an extended period.

questions.text: An HIV-positive patient presents with the following finding. What is the diagnosis & WHO staging of the HIV? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Oral candidiasis & WHO Stage 3

 

The image shows the characteristic appearance of oral thrush, which is due to a Candida infection. This is a common opportunistic infection in immunocompromised individuals, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. According to the WHO staging system for HIV/AIDS, the presence of oral candidiasis indicates Stage 3 disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Oral candidiasis & WHO Stage 2: Oral candidiasis is not a Stage 2 indicator; it is a Stage 3 indicator.

 

Option C. Hairy leukoplakia & WHO Stage 2: Hairy leukoplakia is also a Stage 3 indicator and not shown in the image.

 

Option D. Hairy leukoplakia & WHO Stage 3: Hairy leukoplakia is a Stage 3 indicator, but the image shows oral candidiasis, not hairy leukoplakia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

WHO Staging for HIV/AIDS:

questions.text: Identify the diagnosis from the ECG strip provided. (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ventricular tachycardia

 

The ECG strip shows a regular, wide QRS complex tachycardia with similar morphology for each complex, which is suggestive of ventricular tachycardia (VT). VT is a rapid heart rhythm originating from the ventricles and is characterized by a wide QRS complex (>120 ms), typically without identifiable P waves, and a regular rhythm.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Sinus rhythm: Sinus rhythm typically has a narrow QRS complex with identifiable P waves preceding each QRS complex, which are absent in this ECG strip.

 

Option B. Lead misplacement: Lead misplacement can cause unusual ECG appearances, but it does not typically result in the regular wide QRS tachycardia seen here. Moreover, the question presents only a rhythm strip, which limits the possibility of lead misplacement affecting the diagnosis.

 

Option D. Ventricular fibrillation: Ventricular fibrillation (VF) is characterized by chaotic, irregular, and disorganized electrical activity without discernible QRS complexes. The ECG strip shown is regular and organized, which is inconsistent with VF.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Ventricular tachycardia is identified on an ECG by the presence of a regular, wide QRS complex tachycardia, typically without discernible P waves, indicating rapid electrical activity originating from the ventricles.

questions.text: Dr. Kumar, a newly appointed Medical Officer in Nashik, Maharashtra, is under the guidance of the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP). As part of his responsibilities, he has been tasked with overseeing the malaria control measures in the region. Given the ecological conditions and understanding the life cycle of the malaria vector, he is considering the usage of Malathion as a prophylactic measure. Based on NVBDCP guidelines and the behavior of the vector, how frequently should Dr. Kumar ideally decide to spray Malathion to effectively control the malaria spread? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Once every 3 months

 

Malathion is the least toxic organophosphate among insecticide in India. Because of its low toxicity, it is recommended as ‘an alternative to DDT’

 

  • Dosage: 100-200 mg per sq. ft. every 3 months
  • ULV spray: Used to kill adult mosquitoes
  • Mechanism of action: Interfere with transmission of nerve impulses
  • Act by ‘inhibiting Acetyl-cholinesterase’

 

Educational Objective:

 

Malathion should be sprayed at a dosage of 100-200 mg per square foot every three months as a prophylactic measure against malaria, according to NVBDCP guidelines, due to its effectiveness and low toxicity compared to other insecticides. This schedule optimizes both efficacy and safety in controlling the vector population.

questions.text: A 72-year-old pilot presented to a neurologist with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and visual disturbances. FLAIR MRI scan shown below. EEG showed periodic complexes. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Variant CJD

 

Rapidly progressive myoclonus, dementia suggestive of prior/autoimmune encephalitis syndromes

 

MRI shows hyperintense pulvinar and dorsomedial thalamic nuclei bilaterally suggestive of Variant CJD

 

Sporadic CJD = Cortical ribbon sign which is a sensitive finding on MRI
 

CJD are prior diseases occurring due to misfolded protein that is resistant to natural degradation and on chronic accumulation produces symptoms. vCJD typically presents with psychiatric symptoms, sensory disturbances, and ataxia early in the disease course, followed by rapidly progressive dementia and myoclonus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Alzheimer's disease is a slowly progressive Cortical dementia characterized by memory disturbances and LATE decline in executive functions.

 

Option C. Whipple disease is a chronic multisystem infectious disease caused by Tropheryma whipplei. It can present with dementia and myoclonus, but it is characterized by oculomasticatory myorhythmia, which is pathognomonic. The MRI findings and rapid progression described are not typical for Whipple disease.

 

Option D. Vascular dementia is a subcortical dementia caused by cerebrovascular disease and characterized by early executive function loss and neurological deficits on examination.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob Disease (vCJD) presents with rapidly progressive dementia, myoclonus, ataxia, and characteristic MRI findings of hyperintense pulvinar and dorsomedial thalamic nuclei. EEG often shows periodic complexes, supporting the diagnosis.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has come to you with primary amenorrhea; on examination, thelarche is absent; she has a normal stature; her karyotype is 46XX. Suggest an investigation useful for further treatment planning for the girl: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) LH, FSH levels

 

Explanation:

 

  • Primary amenorrhea in the presence of absent secondary sexual characteristics (thelarche) suggests an issue at either the ovarian or hypothalamic-pituitary level.
  • The patient has normal stature and a 46XX karyotype, which helps rule out Turner syndrome (which often presents with short stature and a 45X karyotype).
  • To differentiate between pure gonadal dysgenesis and a hypothalamic-pituitary cause, measuring LH and FSH levels is crucial:
    • In gonadal dysgenesis, LH and FSH levels will be high due to the lack of negative feedback from the ovaries.
    • In hypothalamic-pituitary causes, LH and FSH levels will be low due to an issue with the release or production of these hormones.

 

Evaluation of primary amenorrhoea

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Diagnostic laparoscopy:

 

  • Explanation: Diagnostic laparoscopy is an invasive procedure and not the first-line investigation for primary amenorrhea without secondary sexual characteristics. It is more appropriate when structural abnormalities are suspected after initial non-invasive tests.

 

Option B. USG pelvis:

 

  • Explanation: While pelvic ultrasound can help identify structural abnormalities, it will not help differentiate between gonadal dysgenesis and hypothalamic-pituitary causes. It is useful if a structural cause of amenorrhea is suspected.

 

Option D. CT Brain:

 

  • Explanation: CT brain may be considered if there is suspicion of a hypothalamic or pituitary tumor. However, initial hormonal assays (LH, FSH) are more appropriate first steps in the workup of primary amenorrhea with absent secondary sexual characteristics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

To differentiate between ovarian and hypothalamic-pituitary causes of primary amenorrhea, measure LH and FSH levels.

 

Ref: Page no 451, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Post mastectomy of right side
Post mastectomy of left side

questions.text: A 45-year-old female presents to the OPD following a surgery. The chest X-ray is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Post mastectomy of left side

 

Explanation  

 

The chest x-ray shows a hyperlucent left hemithorax suggestive of post-left-sided mastectomy image as the breast shadow is missing on the left side.

 

Differentials for unilateral hyperlucent hemithorax:

 

  1. Rotation of patient
  2. Absent soft tissue - Mastectomy, Poland syndrome
  3. More air-Intrabronchial obstruction due to FB, granuloma, tumor
  4. Less vascularity - Pulmonary embolism (Westermark sign)

 

Other Options:

 

A. Right pneumothorax and B. Left pneumothorax: Pneumothorax typically shows as a sharp line demarcating the collapsed lung from the air-filled space, with no lung markings visible beyond this line.

 

C. Post mastectomy of right side: The right side shows normal soft tissue density consistent with intact breast tissue.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The absence of the left breast shadow on a chest X-ray in a patient known to have undergone surgery is highly suggestive of a mastectomy, specifically on the left side. This observation helps differentiate from other causes of unilateral hyperlucency, supporting a surgical rather than pathological cause for the radiographic findings.

questions.text: A heart patient suddenly has chest pain. Which isoenzyme of LDH enzyme is elevated: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LDH-1

 

This isoenzyme is found in the highest concentration in heart tissue and red blood cells. In cases of myocardial infarction (heart attack), LDH-1 levels in the blood can rise significantly, often exceeding the levels of LDH-2. The ratio of LDH-1 to LDH-2 (the "flipped ratio") is sometimes used as a diagnostic marker for myocardial infarction, especially a day or two after the onset of symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. LDH-5: LDH-5 is an isoenzyme of lactate dehydrogenase primarily found in the liver and skeletal muscle. Its elevation is not specific to cardiac-related conditions.

 

Option C. LDH -2: This isoenzyme is primarily found in the heart, but it is also present in white blood cells and the kidneys. In the blood, LDH-2 is normally present in higher amounts than LDH-1. However, after a heart attack, the increase in LDH-1 can surpass LDH-2.

 

Option D. LDH-4: LDH-4 is an isoenzyme of lactate dehydrogenase found in various tissues, including the heart, skeletal muscle, and liver. However, LDH-4 elevation alone is not specific to cardiac-related conditions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

LDH-1 is an isoenzyme of lactate dehydrogenase predominantly found in cardiac muscle. During a heart-related event such as myocardial infarction (heart attack), the damage to cardiac cells can lead to the release of LDH-1 into the bloodstream, causing an elevation in its levels.

 

In normal person, LDH-2 is more than LDH-1 in serum. BUT in myocardial infarction, LDH-1>>LDH-2. This is known as Flipped ratio of LDH in Myocardial Infarction.

 

Ref: Harper’s Illustrated Biochemistry 32nd edition Page no. 67

choices.text: Pox virus
Coxsackie virus
Adeno virus
Ebstein Barr virus

questions.text: What is the organism responsible for this rash seen in an otherwise well child, who also had oral ulcers? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Coxsackie virus

 

The clinical scenario described, along with the image showing a rash on the hands and feet, and the presence of oral ulcers, is indicative of Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD). HFMD is typically caused by Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus A71. This condition commonly affects young children and is characterized by fever, painful sores in the mouth, and a characteristic rash on the hands, feet, and sometimes the buttocks and legs.

 

Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD)

 

  • Etiology: Caused by Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus A71.
  • Clinical Features:
    • Fever
    • Painful oral ulcers
    • Vesicular rash on hands, feet, and sometimes buttocks
       
  • Diagnosis: Clinical diagnosis based on characteristic symptoms and physical examination.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pox virus: Poxviruses are responsible for diseases like smallpox and molluscum contagiosum, which do not present with the characteristic symptoms of HFMD.

 

Option C. Adeno virus: Adenoviruses are a common cause of pharyngitis, conjunctivitis, and respiratory infections. They do not typically cause the vesicular rash seen in HFMD.

 

Option D. Ebstein Barr virus: Epstein-Barr Virus (EBV) is associated with infectious mononucleosis, which presents with fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, and sometimes a generalized rash, but not the specific hand-foot-mouth distribution and oral ulcers seen in HFMD.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is caused by Coxsackievirus A16 and Enterovirus A71, characterized by a vesicular rash on the hands and feet and oral ulcers.

questions.text: Identify the marked arrow? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Portal vein

 

The pointer is at portal vein bifurcation, shown in a transverse CT of abdomen region.

 

 

The portal vein begins at the level of the second lumbar vertebra and is formed from the convergence of the superior mesenteric and splenic veins. It lies obliquely to the right and ascends behind the first part of the duodenum, the common bile duct and gastroduodenal artery. At this point it is directly anterior to the inferior vena cava. The main extrahepatic tributaries of the portal vein are the coronary or the left gastric vein, which ends in the left margin of the portal vein, and the posterior superior pancreatoduodenal vein nearer to the head of the pancreas. The portal vein divides into right and left branches at the hilum

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hepatic artery: The hepatic artery is intermediate in size between the left gastric and splenic arteries. The hepatic artery gives off right gastric, gastroduodenal and cystic branches as well as direct branches to the bile duct from the right hepatic and sometimes the supraduodenal artery. It passes anterior to the portal vein and ascends anterior to the epiploic foramen between the layers of the lesser omentum. At the porta hepatis it divides into right and left branches.

 

Option B. Hepatic vein: The liver is drained by three major hepatic veins into the suprahepatic part of the inferior vena cava and a multitude of minor hepatic veins that drain into the intrahepatic inferior vena cava. The three major veins are located between the four major sectors of the liver

 

Option C. Inferior vena cava: It is formed by the junction of the common iliac veins anterior to the fifth lumbar vertebral body, a little to its right. It ascends anterior to the vertebral column, to the right of the aorta, and is contained in a deep groove on the posterior surface of the liver, or sometimes in a tunnel completed by a band of liver tissue. It next crosses the tendinous part of the diaphragm between its median and right ‘leaves', inclines slightly anteromedially and passes through the fibrous pericardium and a posterior inflexion of the serous pericardium to open into the inferoposterior part of the right atrium.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The portal vein is characterized by its bifurcation into right and left branches at the liver's hilum, and it is formed by the convergence of the superior mesenteric and splenic veins.

questions.text: A patient presented with carcinoma in pyriform Fossa. On laryngoscopy, the lesion is around 5cm and the right vocal folds are not mobile. There is no Lymph Node involvement and no distant metastasis. What is the TNM staging for the malignancy? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. T3N0M0

 

The patient has carcinoma hypopharynx as it is a tumor in the pyriform fossa and TNM staging of the disease is T3N0M0 as he has no nodal metastasis or involvement of vocal cords.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The TNM classification of T3N0M0 for hypopharyngeal carcinoma indicates a significant local invasion with a tumor size larger than 4 cm, involving clinical fixation of the hemilarynx, with no regional lymph node involvement or distant metastasis, necessitating a focused approach on local disease control.

choices.text: Total laryngectomy
Conservative laryngectomy

questions.text: A patient presented with hoarseness of voice. On examination, an ulceroproliferative mass is seen on right vocal cord, cord was however mobile. There is no lymph node involvement and no metastasis. Which of the following is the best treatment modality for this patient? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Radiotherapy

 

The patient with superficial exophytic lesions suggests a diagnosis of Glottic Cancer and since lesion is on 1 subsite with mobile vocal cords, patient will be advised for radiotherapy.

 

If cord is mobile and anterior commissure and arytenoid are not involved, radiotherapy gives good results. Such patients are kept under regular follow-up. If disease recurs, total laryngectomy is performed.

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Total laryngectomy: This would be considered too aggressive for a patient whose disease is localized and involves mobile vocal cords. Total laryngectomy is usually reserved for more advanced cases where the cancer is extensive or has recurred after other treatments.
  • Option C. Conservative laryngectomy: While less radical than total laryngectomy, this option might still be more invasive than necessary for the stage of cancer described.
  • Option D. Chemotherapy: Typically used in conjunction with radiotherapy or surgery for more advanced stages of cancer or when the cancer has spread. It is not usually the primary treatment for early-stage glottic cancer.

 

Educational objective:

 

In cases of glottic cancer where the lesion is localized and the vocal cords remain mobile, radiotherapy is a highly effective treatment that offers good results in terms of both controlling the disease and preserving laryngeal function. Patients treated with radiotherapy should be kept under regular follow-up to monitor for any signs of recurrence, at which point more invasive treatments may be considered.

questions.text: A mother of a 5-day-year-old baby presents with the complaint that her baby is "unable to latch on" for breastfeeding. She also says there is some leakage of milk at times and on examination, there is bilateral tenderness and swelling. What is the most likely cause of this? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Breast engorgement

 

The most likely diagnosis is breast engorgement. Breast engorgement occurs when there is an excessive accumulation of milk, leading to heavy, swollen, and painful breasts. This condition is common in the early days postpartum as milk supply is being established and the baby's feeding patterns are not yet well established. The leakage of milk, tenderness, and swelling described are classic signs of engorgement. Treatment typically involves expressing milk at regular intervals, applying warm compresses, and ensuring the baby is feeding effectively to relieve the engorgement.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bacterial mastitis: In mastitis, the breasts will be tender and inflamed, often with symptoms of infection such as redness, warmth, fever, and systemic illness. The condition described in the question lacks these signs of infection.

 

Option B. Breast abscess: A breast abscess presents with a localized, tender, and fluctuant swelling, often accompanied by systemic signs of infection. The condition described in the question does not mention such localized fluctuant swelling or systemic symptoms.

 

Option C. Lactational mastitis: Lactational mastitis involves infection and inflammation of the breast tissue during breastfeeding. It typically presents with similar symptoms to bacterial mastitis, including fever, chills, and localized pain and redness, which are not mentioned in the question.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Breast engorgement is a common postpartum condition characterized by the excessive accumulation of milk, leading to swollen, tender, and heavy breasts.

 

Ref: Page no 173, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8th edition

questions.text: Rabies virus uses which molecular motor to cause involvement of the central nervous system from the site of the host? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Dynein

 

Explanation:

 

Rabies virus uses dynein for transport from site of inoculation to the central Nervous system.

 

Dynein is the molecular motor responsible for retrograde axonal transport, which is the movement of substances from the axon terminal back to the neuron's cell body (soma). Rabies virus utilizes this mechanism to travel from the site of inoculation to the central nervous system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Kinesin: Incorrect because kinesin is involved in anterograde transport, moving substances from the neuron's cell body towards the axon terminal, not the direction taken by rabies virus.

 

Option C. Actin: Incorrect as actin is involved in providing structural support and muscle contraction, not intracellular transport of viruses.

 

Option D. Myosin: Incorrect because myosin is primarily involved in muscle contraction and cellular movement, not neural transport.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Types of axonal transport -

 

1. Anterograde axonal transport also known as Orthograde transport – vesicles, neurotransmitters, growth factors, mitochondria move from cell body of neuron to nerve ending (Axon terminal)

 

Molecular motor involved Anterograde axonal transport -Kinesin 

 

2. Retrograde transport also known as Reverse axonal transport – empty vesicles, toxins, viruses move from nerve ending to the cell body of neuron (Soma)

 

Molecular motor involved retrograde axonal transport - Dynein

 

NOTE: Sometime pathologically some viruses (E.g., herpes simplex, rabies, and polio) get transported back to cell body.

questions.text: Oxytocin plays a role in? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Milk ejection

 

Explanation:

 

Oxytocin is specifically involved in the milk ejection (or let-down) reflex in breastfeeding women. It is released in response to nipple stimulation when a baby suckles, triggering contractions of the myoepithelial cells around the milk-producing alveoli, leads to compression of lobules, which results in the ejection of milk.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Milk production: Incorrect because prolactin, not oxytocin, is responsible for milk production.

 

Option C. Milk storage: Incorrect as milk storage is not directly influenced by oxytocin; it is a function of the glandular tissue of the breast.

 

Option D. None of the above: Incorrect as oxytocin indeed plays a crucial role in milk ejection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Oxytocin is vital for the milk let-down reflex, facilitating milk ejection during breastfeeding. This is distinct from milk production, which is governed by prolactin.

choices.text: Food Standards and Safety Authority of India (FSSAI)

questions.text: Given a specific logo displayed during a workshop on quality assurance and standards, participants were asked to determine its affiliation. The emblem, notable in its design, represents which of the following organizations? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bureau of Indian standards (BIS)

 

BIS is the National Standard Body of India established under the BIS Act 2016.

 

One of its major functions is standard formulation and promotion. Apart from this it also helps in marking and quality certification of goods and for matters connected there with or incidental there to.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. AGMARK: Certification mark employed on agricultural products in India, ensuring that they conform to a set of standards approved by the Directorate of Marketing and Inspection, an agency of the Government of India.

 

 

Option B. ISI: ISI was the earlier name for the Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS). The ISI mark is a certification mark for industrial products in India.

 

 

Option C. FSSAI: FSSAI is responsible for protecting and promoting public health through the regulation and supervision of food safety.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS) is the National Standard Body of India, responsible for the standardization, marking, and quality certification of goods.

questions.text: What is the most commonly observed emotional state? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Fear

 

Fear is the most common emotion of man. It may produce excitement or depression; flight or fight." Fear is a fundamental emotion that has various manifestations in humans. Common fears include fear of the dark, dogs, snakes, ghosts, sickness, and death. When fear becomes exaggerated or unnecessary, it can develop into phobia, which is commonly seen in patients with mental disorders.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Love is a complex emotion that, while prevalent, is not just a daily fleeting experience for many but rather a deeper, sustained emotion tied to relationships and connections.

 

Option B. Hate is a strong emotion, but it's not as commonly or constantly felt by the average individual in their daily life.
 

Option C. Joy is an important and desirable emotion, it is not among the most basic survival-related emotions. It is also situation-dependent and does not have the same frequency or intensity as fear.

 

Educational Objective: 


Fear is the most common basic human emotion that can manifest as either excitement or depression and can lead to fight or flight responses when triggered.

 

 

Reference: Park K. Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 26th Edition, Chapter 4 - Psychology in Health and Disease, Page 804.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man suffers from sudden financial loss. After the event, he starts feeling fearful that someone is about to harm him because of which he develops reduced sleep and appetite. He begins to hear voices that say that he is useless and that he should kill himself. However, all his symptoms stop after one week. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Brief psychotic disorder

 

This patient's presentation of delusions (fear that someone is about to harm him), auditory hallucinations (hearing voices telling him to harm himself), and their sudden onset following a stressful event (financial loss) suggests a psychotic disorder. However, the duration of his symptoms is key to the diagnosis. Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that last for at least 1 day but remit by 1 month.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Schizophreniform disorder is similar to schizophrenia in terms of symptoms but lasts from 1 to 6 months.

 

Option C. Depression can sometimes present with psychotic features, but the primary symptoms are a pervasive sad mood and anhedonia.

 

Option D. Schizophrenia involves continuous symptoms of psychosis for 6 months or longer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Brief psychotic disorder is characterized by the sudden onset of psychotic symptoms that last for at least 1 day but less than 1 month, after which the individual returns to their baseline level of functioning. The duration of symptoms is crucial in differentiating it from other psychotic disorders.  It can be triggered by stressors, but this is not a requirement for the diagnosis.

 

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Synopsis of Psychiatry, 12th edition, Page No 344

questions.text: Which artery can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers between the medial malleolus and the calcaneal (Achilles) tendon? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Posterior tibial artery

 

The posterior tibial artery pulse can be felt against the heel bone calcaneum about 2 cm below and behind (postero-inferior) the medial malleolus. The artery is felt in front (anterior) of the medial border of the tendocalcaneus, between the tendons of flexor hallucis longus and flexor digitorum longus.

 

 

Note: Posterior tibial artery lies deep to the flexor retinaculum, hence, the patient is asked to 'invert' (turn the sole inside) his foot to relax the flexor retinaculum, before palpating the artery.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anterior tibial artery: The anterior tibial artery terminates at the level of the ankle joint, where it gives off its terminal branch, the dorsalis pedis artery. The anterior tibial artery pulse can be palpated near the origin of the dorsalis pedis artery on the dorsum of the foot lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon.

 

Option C. Dorsalis pedis artery: The dorsalis pedis artery is a major artery that supplies blood to the dorsum of the foot. It can be palpated by gently pressing your fingers along the midline of the foot, usually just lateral to the extensor hallucis longus tendon, between the first and second metatarsal bones.

 

Option D. Popliteal artery:  The popliteal artery is a major blood vessel located in the popliteal fossa, which is the hollow area at the back of the knee joint. This artery is a continuation of the femoral artery, which runs down the thigh, and it plays a crucial role in supplying blood to the lower leg and foot. Most difficult of the peripheral pulses to feel because the artery lies deep in the popliteal fossa. Felt over the midline of the fossa by deep pressure against the popliteal surface of the femur.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The posterior tibial artery can be palpated just below and behind the medial malleolus, anterior to the medial border of the Achilles tendon. This is an important palpation site for assessing circulatory health in the lower extremities, particularly in patients with peripheral vascular disease.

choices.text: X linked dominant
X linked recessive

questions.text: What is the inheritance pattern observed in patients suffering from color blindness? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) X-linked recessive

 

Examples of X-linked recessive conditions include red-green color blindness and hemophilia A: Red-green color Blindness.

 

Here are some examples of X-linked recessive diseases:

 

  1. Haemophilia: This is a bleeding disorder that affects the blood's ability to clot properly. It is caused by mutations in the genes that produce clotting factors VIII or IX, which are located on the X chromosome.
  2. Duchenne muscular dystrophy: This is a progressive muscle-wasting disease that primarily affects boys. It is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene on the X chromosome, which results in the loss of this protein and the gradual degeneration of muscle tissue.
  3. Color blindness: This is a condition in which a person has difficulty distinguishing certain colors. It is caused by mutations in the genes that produce photopigments in the retina of the eye. There are several types of color blindness, but the most common form is red-green color blindness.
  4. X-linked agammaglobulinemia: This is a rare immune disorder that affects the body's ability to produce antibodies. It is caused by mutations in the BTK gene on the X chromosome, which is necessary for the development and maturation of B cells that produce antibodies.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Autosomal Dominant: Conditions inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern require only one copy of the altered gene to be present for the condition to manifest. Examples include Huntington's disease and Marfan syndrome.

 

Option B. Autosomal Recessive: Conditions inherited in an autosomal recessive pattern require two copies of the altered gene (one from each parent) for the condition to manifest. Examples include cystic fibrosis and sickle cell anemia.

 

Option C. X-linked Dominant: Conditions inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern occur when a single altered gene on the X chromosome can cause the disorder in both males and females. Examples include Rett syndrome and X-linked hypophosphatemia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Red-green color blindness is an example of an X-linked recessive condition, primarily affecting males due to the presence of the gene mutation on the X chromosome.

questions.text: A 59-year-old man underwent a bone marrow examination which revealed the presence of the finding shown in the image. What is the likely diagnosis of the affected individual? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Multiple myeloma

 

The histological findings seen in MM

 

  1. Sheets of Plasma Cells:
  2. Abnormal Plasma Cell Morphology: They may have enlarged nuclei, irregular nuclear contours, and increased chromatin clumping.
  3. Increased Plasma Cell Proliferation:
  4. Monoclonal Protein Deposits: In multiple myeloma, the abnormal plasma cells produce excessive amounts of a monoclonal immunoglobulin (M protein).
  5. Bone Marrow Infiltration: Histologically, the bone marrow may show replacement of normal hematopoietic cells by abnormal plasma cells.

 

People with smoldering myeloma have some signs of multiple myeloma, such as any of the following: Plasma cells in the bone marrow between 10% and 60% High level of monoclonal immunoglobulin (M protein) in the blood. High Level of light chains in the urine (also called Bence Jones protein).

 

CRAB CRITERIA for MM

 

Hypercalcemia – serum calcium >11 mg/dL

 

Renal insufficiency: serum creatinine >2 mg/dL or creatinine clearance <40 mL/min

 

Anemia: Hgb <10 g/dL

 

Lytic bone lesions

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. ALL (Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia): Characterized by the proliferation of immature lymphoblasts in the bone marrow, not by plasma cells.

 

Option C. Tuberculosis: Shows granulomatous inflammation with caseating necrosis, not plasma cell proliferation.

 

Option D. Sickle Cell Disease: Identified by the presence of sickle-shaped red blood cells on peripheral smear and not by plasma cell infiltration in the bone marrow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The presence of sheets of plasma cells with abnormal morphology and bone marrow infiltration seen in the image confirms the diagnosis of multiple myeloma.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presented with hematemesis. On further examination patient had splenomegaly. He had history of exchange transfusion for neonatal jaundice. What is the probable diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Portal Vein thrombosis

 

In a child presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly, which suggests portal hypertension, along with a history of exchange transfusion for neonatal jaundice, the most likely diagnosis is Portal Vein Thrombosis.

 

Key points supporting this diagnosis:

 

  • Hematemeis and Splenomegaly: These symptoms indicate portal hypertension, which can result from obstruction in the portal venous system.
  • History of Exchange Transfusion: This procedure, along with umbilical vein catheterization often used in neonatal intensive care, can predispose to portal vein thrombosis due to vessel injury or infection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Budd Chiari syndrome: This condition involves thrombosis of the hepatic veins, leading to liver congestion and hepatomegaly, but it typically does not present with a history of neonatal jaundice treatment or splenomegaly as prominently as seen with portal vein thrombosis.

 

Option B. Portal hypertension: While portal hypertension is a feature of portal vein thrombosis, it is a consequence rather than a diagnosis. The underlying cause here is portal vein thrombosis.

 

Option C. Liver cirrhosis: Cirrhosis can cause portal hypertension and splenomegaly, but it is less likely in a child with the given history, especially without additional signs of chronic liver disease.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Portal vein thrombosis should be considered in children presenting with hematemesis and splenomegaly, particularly if there is a history of neonatal exchange transfusion or umbilical vein catheterization.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presented with an unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and mood fluctuation. The neurologist noticed a multicolored iris with concentric rings around the periphery as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Wilson's disease

 

Wilson's disease is a genetic disorder characterized by excessive deposition of copper in various tissues, including the liver, brain, and eyes, due to a mutation in the ATP7B gene on chromosome 13. This condition leads to significant organ damage through oxidative stress mechanisms like the Fenton reaction. The clinical presentation often includes neurological and psychiatric symptoms such as unsteady gait, forgetfulness, and mood fluctuations.

 

The image shows a Kayser-Fleischer (KF) ring, which is a pathognomonic finding in Wilson's disease. The KF ring is a result of copper deposition in the Descemet's membrane of the cornea, creating multicolored, concentric rings around the iris.

 

Clinical Features:

 

  • Hematologic: Coombs-negative hemolysis
  • Neurological: Movement disorders (dystonia, tremors), psychiatric disturbances, basal ganglia degeneration
  • Renal: Proximal renal tubular acidosis (type II)
  • Liver: Elevated liver enzymes, which can be significantly high (>1000 U/L in fulminant hepatic failure), and associated hemolysis
  • Ocular: Kayser-Fleischer rings and sometimes sunflower cataracts

 

Diagnosis:

 

  • Low serum ceruloplasmin (<20 mg/dL)
  • High urinary copper excretion (>100 µg/24 hours)
  • Liver biopsy showing dry copper >250 µg/g
  • Leipzig criteria

 

Treatment:

 

  • D-penicillamine
  • Zinc
  • Tetrathiomolybdate (especially in neurological Wilson's disease)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neurofibromatosis 1: This condition is characterized by multiple café-au-lait spots, neurofibromas, Lisch nodules (iris hamartomas), but not by Kayser-Fleischer rings or the described neuropsychiatric symptoms in this context.

 

Option C. Cataract: Cataracts are opacities in the lens of the eye that impair vision, but they do not cause the described neuropsychiatric symptoms or the specific ocular finding of KF rings.

 

Option D. Neurofibromatosis 2: This disorder is marked by bilateral vestibular schwannomas and other intracranial and spinal tumors, but not by KF rings or the described symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Wilson's disease can present with neuropsychiatric symptoms and is characterized by Kayser-Fleischer rings due to copper deposition in the eyes. Diagnosis involves confirming low serum ceruloplasmin and elevated urinary copper excretion, with treatment focusing on chelation and management of copper levels.

questions.text: A 23-year-old G3P1L1A1 at 37 weeks of gestation with a previous history of emergency cesarean section and a dilatation and curettage presents to the ER with labor pains. During abdominal examination it was difficult to palpate fetal parts. Per vaginal examination revealed a 5 cm dilated cervix and her vitals were: BP - 80/60 mm of Hg, RR - 20/ min, HR - 106/ min, Sp02 - 97% under room air. CTG showed a non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate pattern. The most likely diagnosis is: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Uterine rupture

 

Explanation:

 

The given clinical scenario suggests uterine rupture. The following points support this diagnosis:

 

  • History of previous uterine surgery: The patient has had an emergency cesarean section and a dilatation and curettage, both of which increase the risk of uterine rupture.
  • Difficult to palpate fetal parts: This can occur if the fetus has moved out of the uterine cavity.
  • Patient is in shock: The patient's blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg, and her heart rate is 106/min, indicating hypovolemic shock.
  • Fetal distress: The non-reassuring variable fetal heart rate pattern on CTG indicates fetal distress, which is often associated with uterine rupture.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amniotic fluid embolization: This condition typically presents with sudden cardiovascular collapse and disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC). The patient would show signs of respiratory distress, which is not mentioned in the scenario.

 

Option B. Placental abruption: This condition usually presents with painful vaginal bleeding and a tense or tender abdomen. There is no mention of vaginal bleeding or a tense abdomen in this case.

 

Option D. Placenta previa: Placenta previa typically presents with painless vaginal bleeding. It is less likely to be associated with shock or fetal distress without significant bleeding. The clinical scenario does not mention vaginal bleeding.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Uterine rupture should be suspected in a laboring patient with a history of uterine surgery, hypovolemic shock, difficulty in palpating fetal parts, and signs of fetal distress.

 

Ref: Page no 497, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8th edition

choices.text: Toll like receptor
G protein coupled receptor

questions.text: Which of the following is the molecule required for presentation of the antigens by the antigen presenting cell to the TH2 cell? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) MHC

 

An antigen-presenting cell or accessory cell is a cell that displays antigen bound by major histocompatibility complex (MHC) proteins on its surface; this process is known as antigen presentation. (APCs)

 

Process antigens and present them to T-cells.

 

When antigen attaches to MHC- 1, it activates CD8 T cell, whereas when it attaches to MHC-2, it activates CD4 T-cell.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Toll-like Receptor (TLR): These are a class of proteins that play a key role in the innate immune system. They recognize pathogen-associated molecular patterns (PAMPs) but do not present antigens.

 

Option C. G Protein-Coupled Receptor (GPCR): These receptors detect molecules outside the cell and activate internal signal transduction pathways and cellular responses, but are not involved in antigen presentation.

 

Option D. Lectin Receptor: These are carbohydrate-binding proteins involved in various cell-cell recognition processes but are not directly involved in antigen presentation to T cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MHC molecules, specifically MHC Class II, are essential for presenting processed exogenous antigens on APCs to CD4+ T cells, including TH2 cells, facilitating the adaptive immune response.

choices.text: Na-K-2CI symporter inhibitor in loop of Henle
Na-CI symporter inhibitor in DCT
Aldosterone blocker in DCT

questions.text: A 45-year-old male patient with heart disease has been brought to the emergency with breathlessness. He also has bipedal edema as shown in the image below. Which of the following is the best drug for the management of edema in this patient? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Na-K-2CI symporter inhibitor in loop of Henle

 

The clinical scenario of heart disease with bipedal edema is suggestive of Acute Decompensated Heart Failure.

 

Such patients should be treated with Loop Diuretics like Furosemide. They act by inhibiting the Na+-K+-2Cl symporter present in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle. They are high ceiling diuretics.

 

By reducing the salt and water retention, the Loop diuretics reduces the preload of the heart, thereby reducing the cardiac workload

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. ACE Inhibitors are not typically used in management of acute decompensated heart failure as they lead to significant hypotension, worsening the condition of the patient.

 

Option C. Na-Cl symporter inhibitor in DCT is the Thiazide diuretics which acts by this mechanism. These are used as first line treatment in essential hypertension. Thiazides, in contrast to Loop diuretics, may not provide sufficient diuresis to relieve the fluid overload in the patients with acute heart failure.

 

Option D. Aldosterone blocker in DCT is Spironolactone. It is not typically indicated in acute decompensated heart failure due to its potential risk of causing Hyperkalemia which may become life threatening in the setting of heart failure. Spironolactone can be used in chronic CHF due to its better long-term outcomes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In acute decompensated heart failure, especially presenting with significant edema, loop diuretics like Furosemide are the best choice due to their potent diuretic effects, which are essential for rapidly reducing fluid overload and easing cardiac workload.

questions.text: What is the primary location where a nasal polyp commonly obstructs the maxillary sinus? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Middle meatus

 

Nasal polyps are noncancerous growths that often develop in the lining of the nasal passages and sinuses. The middle meatus is a key anatomical location in the nasal cavity where the drainage of the maxillary, frontal, and anterior ethmoid sinuses converge. This area is known as the osteomeatal complex. When polyps arise or extend into this region, they can obstruct the natural drainage pathways of these sinuses, particularly the maxillary sinus, leading to symptoms such as nasal congestion, sinus pressure, and recurrent sinus infections. The middle meatus is thus the most likely site for a nasal polyp to obstruct the maxillary sinus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Inferior meatus: This area primarily receives drainage from the nasolacrimal duct, not the sinuses.

 

Option B. Superior meatus: This site is less commonly involved with obstructions from nasal polyps as it primarily drains the posterior ethmoid sinuses.

 

Option D. Sphenoethmoidal recess: This location is related to the drainage of the sphenoid sinus and some posterior ethmoid cells, not directly involved with maxillary sinus drainage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The middle meatus is the most common site for nasal polyps to obstruct the maxillary sinus, due to its role in the drainage of the sinus. Obstruction in this area can lead to symptoms of sinusitis and requires appropriate medical or surgical management to restore proper sinus ventilation and drainage.

questions.text: A patient presented with vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt. He underwent myringoplasty for the safe type of chronic suppurative otitis media (CSOM) 6 months back. What is your diagnosis? (INICET Nov 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Perilymphatic fistula

 

  • The clinical scenario with symptoms of vertigo, tinnitus, and head tilt and history of myringoplasty done for CSOM suggest that the diagnosis is perilymphatic fistula.
  • A peri-lymphatic fistula is an abnormal communication between the inner ear and the middle ear that can allow perilymph to leak from the cochlea or vestibule, most commonly through the round or oval window.
  • Precipitating causes include surgery, blunt trauma, penetrating trauma, barotrauma, infection, cholesteatoma, or sudden changes in CSF pressure as can occur with straining, sneezing, or Valsalva’s maneuver. Congenital ear abnormalities may predispose to perilymph leaks. Spontaneous perilymph fistulae are rare.
  • The clinical picture of perilymph fistulae is variable, with symptoms ranging from mild to incapacitating. Vertigo, or more often unsteadiness, is the most common symptom. Hearing loss, tinnitus, or aural fullness may be present. A thorough history inquiring about activities such as trauma, scuba diving, flying, and straining is critical in the diagnosis of this disorder as the symptoms are vague and coincident with other vestibular disorders. Fistula test is positive.

 

Investigations

 

  • HRCT temporal bone has high sensitivity in detecting peri lymphatic fistula.
  • A combination of CT and MRI diagnose almost 100% of cases.
  • Other tests include audiometry and electrocochleography.

 

Management of a peri-lymphatic fistula is either by conservative or surgical methods. Conservative therapy includes avoiding anything that can increase inner ear or intracranial pressure and the use of intratympanic steroids in acute decompensation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Labyrinthitis presents with vestibular symptoms like sudden onset of persistent vertigo with associated symptoms such as nausea, vomiting, sweating and pallor and sensorineural hearing loss.

 

Option C. Paget's disease of bone usually presents with hearing loss as a prominent feature, when the skull is involved. It is not associated with a history of surgery, trauma or vestibulocochlear symptoms.

 

Option D. Vestibular Schwannoma, also called as acoustic neuroma is a tumor that arises from the Schwann cells of the vestibular, but rarely from the cochlear division of vestibulocochlear nerve within the internal auditory canal.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Perilymphatic fistula should be suspected in patients presenting with vestibular symptoms following ear surgery, particularly when associated with activities that change intracranial or middle ear pressure. Diagnosis is largely based on clinical history, symptomatology, and specific imaging tests.

choices.text: Drugs are given at short intervals in the same dose
Drugs are given at short intervals in gradually increasing doses
This incident is not seen with drugs such as ephedrine
This action is rarely seen in clinical practice

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the phenomenon shown in the graph below, depicting the dose-response with multiple administrations of the drug, is correct? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Drugs are given at short intervals in the same dose

 

  • This diagram depicts the phenomenon of Tachyphylaxis.

  • Tachyphylaxis refers to the rapid development of tolerance when same dose of a drug is repeated in quick succession resulting in marked reduction in the response.

  • Tachyphylaxis is usually observed with indirectly acting drugs such as Ephedrine and Tyramine. These drugs act by releasing catecholamines in the body- synthesis of which is unable to match the rate of release, as a result of which the stores get depleted.

  • Following could be the possible reasons of Tachyphylaxis:

    1. Receptor Desensitization

    2. Downregulation of receptors

    3. Feedback mechanisms

    4. Enzyme Induction

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Drugs are given at short intervals in gradually increasing doses: This statement is incorrect as the graph shows the administration of the drug in consistent doses.

 

Option C. This incident is not seen with drugs such as ephedrine: This is incorrect; tachyphylaxis is often seen with indirectly acting drugs like ephedrine, which deplete neurotransmitter stores more quickly than they can be replenished.

 

Option D. This action is rarely seen in clinical practice: Tachyphylaxis is not rare; it is a well-documented and significant consideration in clinical settings, particularly with drugs that influence neurotransmitter levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tachyphylaxis is the rapid onset of drug tolerance due to repeated dosing at short intervals, necessitating careful management in clinical practice to maintain drug efficacy, particularly for drugs that operate by releasing or modifying neurotransmitter levels like ephedrine.

questions.text: Identify the marked structure in the USG of liver given below: (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Portal vein

 

  • The marked structure is the portal vein on this color doppler.
  • At the porta hepatis, hepatic artery, PV and CBD would be visualized. The largest is PV as shown in this image, showing red color indicating flow towards the liver.
  • Importance: Blue flow on color doppler indicated flow away from liver, that is, hepatofugal flow which is the earliest sign of portal hypertension.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The portal vein is a major vascular structure in the liver, visible on ultrasound with color Doppler, showing red to indicate blood flowing towards the liver. This imaging technique is essential for evaluating liver vascular anatomy and pathology, such as assessing for signs of portal hypertension.

questions.text: A 28-year-old term primigravida was admitted with complaints of draining per vaginum. She delivered a male baby by assisted vaginal delivery as face to pubis. What is the most probable type of pelvis in this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Anthropoid pelvis

 

  • Face to pubes delivery is seen in occipito-posterior (OP) positions
  • OP is seen commonly in anthropoid pelvises and also in android pelvises but more commonly in anthropoid pelvis

 

Other Options:

 

On the basis of the shape of inlet, female pelvis can be classified as: (Caldwell Molloy classification)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Face to pubis delivery is most commonly associated with the anthropoid pelvis due to the frequent occurrence of occipito-posterior positions in this pelvic type.

 

Ref: Page no 403, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 8thedition

choices.text: The blue line represents FSH hormone

questions.text: The following chart shows the hormonal variations in the menstrual cycle. Identify the true statement: (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) The blue line represents FSH hormone

 

Explanation:

 

In this image:

 

  • The purple line represents progesterone (low in the follicular phase and increases in the luteal phase)
  • The grey line is estrogen which is increased in the follicular phase
  • The pink line represents LH where we can see the LH surge happening just prior to ovulation
  • The blue line represents FSH

 

Educational Objective:

 

The blue line in the menstrual cycle chart represents Follicle Stimulating Hormone (FSH).

 

Ref: Page no 74, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: A 45-year-old man presented with flu-like symptoms and a palmoplantar rash as seen below. Examination showed epitrochlear lymphadenopathy. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Secondary syphilis

 

Clinical vignette shows rash involving palms and soles, with lymphadenopathy. Deep dermal tenderness on pressing the lesion with Pinhead is termed Buschke ollendorf sign.

 

Diseases with rash on palm and soles:

 

  • Rocky mountain spotted fever
  • Secondary syphilis
  • Hand foot mouth disease
  • Infective endocarditis
  • Kawasaki disease
  • Meningococcemia
  • Toxic shock syndrome

 

Syphilis Diagnostics

 

1.Non treponemal test: RPR(Serum), VDRL(Serum/csf)

 

  • False positive: old age, pregnancy, endemic treponematoses
  • False negative: prozone phenomenon
  • Fourfold change in titre decline after treatment= CURE (Irrespective of end titre)
  • Titres will decline with time and become non-reactive with/without Rx.

 

2.Treponemal test: MHA-TP, TPPA, FTA-Abs, EIAs, CIA

 

  • Once reactive = ALWAYS REACTIVE
  • False positive: old age, endemic treponematoses, autoimmune disease

 

If 1 type(treponemal/nontreponemal) is positive = confirm with other type for diagnosis

 

Single type is non confirmatory for diagnosis.

 

No single test can diagnose Neurosyphilis

 

Absence of CSF pleocytosis RULES out Neurosyphilis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Endemic disease: This term is too vague and does not describe a specific condition consistent with the patient's presentation.

 

Option B. Steven-Johnson syndrome: This severe mucocutaneous reaction involves skin detachment and mucous membrane involvement, but it does not typically present with a palmoplantar rash and lymphadenopathy as seen here.

 

Option D. Primary syphilis: This stage typically presents with a chancre at the site of infection and regional lymphadenopathy, not with a widespread rash involving the palms and soles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Syphilis types, diagnosis and management:

choices.text: Pharyngeal pouch

questions.text: A young male who is a professional trumpet blower presented with a swelling on the left side of the neck. On examination, there is a gurgling sound when compressing the swelling. As the X-ray neck was inconclusive a CT neck was taken which is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Laryngocele

 

The given CT image along with the examination finding of Bryce sign is suggestive of laryngocele.

 

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

  • Option A. Pharyngeal pouch: Also known as a Zenker's diverticulum, this typically presents with dysphagia and regurgitation of undigested food, not a gurgling sound upon compression.
  • Option C. Tracheoesophageal fistula: This condition usually presents with symptoms like coughing during feeding, recurrent lung infections, and is unlikely in an adult unless following trauma or cancer.
  • Option D. Tonsillar cyst: Typically presents as a localized swelling in the tonsillar region and would not produce a gurgling sound on compression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Laryngoceles are a significant occupational hazard for professionals like trumpet players due to repeated elevation of intralaryngeal pressure, presenting as a neck swelling that changes size with coughing and produces a characteristic gurgling sound on compression.

choices.text: IV fluids
Breast feeding
Orogastric tube feed
Paladai feeding

questions.text: What should be the best initial feeding method for a baby born at 33 weeks gestation, with no perinatal complications? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Paladai feeding

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

For preterm infants born between 32-34 weeks gestation, paladai feeding is recommended as the initial feeding method to ensure adequate nutrition and support the development of oral feeding skills.

questions.text: Identify the tachycardia depicted in the ECG image below? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Atrial flutter

 

The ECG shows a characteristic sawtooth pattern of P waves, particularly visible in the inferior leads (II, III, aVF), which is indicative of atrial flutter. The presence of positive P waves in V1 is suggestive of counterclockwise atrial flutter, the most common form, which typically involves a reentrant circuit around the cavotricuspid isthmus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Atrial fibrillation: Atrial fibrillation produces an irregularly irregular rhythm with no distinct P waves, which is not consistent with the sawtooth pattern seen here.

 

Option B. Ventricular tachycardia: Ventricular tachycardia produces a regular, wide complex tachycardia. The QRS complexes in this ECG are narrow, ruling out ventricular tachycardia.

 

Option D. Ventricular fibrillation: Ventricular fibrillation is characterized by chaotic, irregular, and disorganized electrical activity, this produces irregular III formed wide QRS complexes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Atrial flutter is characterized by a sawtooth pattern of P waves, especially prominent in the inferior leads, and involves a reentrant circuit most commonly around the cavotricuspid isthmus.

questions.text: A patient is seen in the OPD after her delivery which was 5 days ago. She presents with smelly greenish vaginal discharge. What is the initial step in the management of this patient? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Per vaginum examination  

 

Explanation:

 

  • The most likely diagnosis in this patient is postpartum endometritis
  • however, the next line of management in this patient is to undergo a per vaginal examination
  • A P/V examination will help determine the size of the uterus, look for tenderness (positive in PID), rule out adnexal lesions and also rule out the presence of a gauze/ foreign body in the vagina

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Antibiotics: Broad spectrum antibiotics need to be started in case of postpartum sepsis but that would be the 2nd step after doing a vaginal examination

 

Option B. Ultrasound: This is also indicated to look for the presence of retained products but again after doing a vaginal exam

 

Option C. Urinalysis: This is done if symptoms of UTI are there

 

Educational Objective:

 

The initial step in managing a postpartum woman presenting with smelly greenish vaginal discharge is to perform a per vaginum examination to guide further diagnostic and therapeutic steps.

 

Ref: Page no 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

questions.text: In a rural health clinic in the southern district of Tamil Nadu, a 5-year-old boy is brought in by his concerned parents. The boy has had a fever and runny nose for the past 3 days. Notably, he developed a rash that began on his face and subsequently spread to cover the trunk of his body. His vaccination history is uncertain due to missing records. The physician examining him is considering various viral etiologies. Based on these clinical findings, which diagnosis is most likely? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Measles

 

The clinical presentation of the 5-year-old boy suggests measles. Measles is a highly contagious viral disease with the following characteristics:

 

  • IP- 10-14 Days
  • Mode of Transmission- droplets or droplet nuclei.
  • Clinical features: Prodromal stage characterized by fever, coryza, running nose, Koplik spots(pathognomonic), followed by appearance of maculopapular rash after 4 days of onset of fever, starting behind the ear and spreading cephalocaudally. Takes 6 to 8 days to appear and disappear completely.

 

RASH IN MEASLES - Starts 12-24 hours after appearance of Koplik spots, Retro-auricular origin spreads to other parts of body (fades in opposite direction), takes 1-2 days to cover body, Fever highest and patient sickest on day of rash

 

  • Period of infectivity/ communicability of Measles: 4 days before to 5 days after rash appearance
  • Period of Isolation for Measles: Onset of Catarrhal stage through 3rd day of rash
  • Measles has no second attacks (lifelong immunity seen)
  • Secondary attack rate of Measles is 80% 
  • Measles shows a cyclical trend: Increase every 2-3 years
  • Most common complication- Otitis Media
  • Most common cause of death – Pneumonia
  • Most common late complication- Subacute Sclerosing Panencephalitis. (SSPE)

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Chicken Pox: Typically presents with a vesicular rash that starts on the trunk and spreads to the extremities and face, unlike the cephalocaudal spread in measles.

 

Option C. Mumps: Primarily characterized by parotitis (swelling of the parotid glands) rather than a widespread rash.

 

Option D. Rubella: Presents with a milder rash and often has mild or absent prodromal symptoms. The rash in rubella typically starts on the face and spreads downwards but is usually less intense than measles.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Measles is characterized by a fever, coryza, Koplik spots, and a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads cephalocaudally.

questions.text: The girl seen in the image has had history of severe sunburns after just a few minutes in the sun. She also has history of photosensitivity & severe freckling in the sun exposed areas. The most likely diagnosis is? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Xeroderma Pigmentosa

 

  • The image shows a girl with Xeroderma Pigmentosa.
  • It is characterised by defective Nucleotide Excision Repair.
  • A rare autosomal recessive genetic condition called Xeroderma pigmentosa causes clinical and cellular hypersensitivity to UV radiation and other carcinogens as a result of faulty DNA repair.

 

Important clinical features of Xeroderma Pigmentosa are:

 

1. First stage: Child is asymptomatic at birth. Diffuse erythema, scaling & freckle like lesions over the sun exposed regions of the body at around 6 months of age.

 

2. Second stage: Poikiloderma is a characteristic feature of the second stage of Xeroderma Pigmentosa.

 

Poikiloderma is a special skin lesion with a triad of features {ATP}

 

  • Atrophy of skin
  • Telangiectasia (Permanently dilated blood vessels)
  • Pigment abnormalities (Dyspigmentation, both hypo & hyper)

 

Poikiloderma may be congenital or acquired. It is associated with mycosis fungoides, dermatomyositis etc.

 

3. Third stage:

 

Increased incidence of Cutaneous malignancies like:

 

  • Squamous Cell Carcinoma
  • Malignant melanoma
  • Basal Cell Carcinoma
  • Fibrosarcoma.

 

  • The final diagnosis of Xeroderma Pigmentosa can be confirmed by special laboratory tests by the examining the DNA damage repair in cells from cultures exposed to UV radiation.
  • The most common tests are skin biopsy & culture of skin fibroblasts.

 

Treatment:

 

  • There is no cure for Xeroderma Pigmentosa.
  • Minimise exposure to sunlight
  • Regular dermatological care,
  • Surgery for recurrent tumours excision.
  • Follow up every 3 months.
  • Genetic counselling is important in a family that has an affected child & is considering having more children.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blooms Syndrome:

 

  • Description: A rare genetic disorder characterized by a heightened sensitivity to sunlight, resulting in an increased risk of skin cancers. Affected individuals are often shorter than average and have a facial rash that can develop after sun exposure as shown in the below image.

 

  • Symptoms: Small stature, rash on the face, increased susceptibility to infections, and an increased risk of developing various types of cancer.

 

 

Option C. Warts:

 

  • Description: Small, rough, and hard growths that are similar in color to the rest of the skin. They are caused by viruses, particularly one of several kinds of HPV (human papillomavirus).
  • Symptoms: Rough growths on the skin, commonly on hands or feet. They don't cause sunburn or photosensitivity.

 

Option D. Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE):

 

  • Description: An autoimmune disease in which the body's immune system attacks its own tissues.
  • Symptoms: Fatigue, joint pain, rash (often a "butterfly" rash on the face as shown in the below image), and fever.

 

  • Some people with SLE also have photosensitivity, but the other described symptoms don't typically align with SLE.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Xeroderma pigmentosum in patients who exhibit extreme photosensitivity, resulting in severe sunburns and pronounced freckling on sun-exposed areas, due to a genetic defect in DNA repair mechanisms.

 

Reference: -

Rook's Textbook of Dermatology - 9th Edition - Volume II Chapter 78 Page no 78.1

Harpers illustrated biochemistry 30th edition page number 390
