questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with the finding shown in the image. What is this physical finding called? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Clubbing

 

Clubbing refers to bulbous enlargement of distal segments of fingers and toes due to connective tissue proliferation and deposition.

 

Various theories have been proposed for clubbing, but none explain the mechanism completely. This finding is often associated with chronic hypoxic conditions, lung diseases, heart diseases, and gastrointestinal diseases.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pallor: Pallor is observed in the nail beds, conjunctiva, retina, palms, and tongue and indicates anemia or reduced blood flow.

 

Option B. Spoon-shaped nails: Also known as koilonychia, this condition is characterized by nails that are concave and is often associated with iron deficiency anemia.

 

Option D. Raynaud's phenomenon: This condition involves discoloration of the digits upon exposure to cold or stress and is associated with pain. It does not present with the bulbous appearance seen in clubbing.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Clubbing is characterized by a bulbous enlargement of the distal fingers and toes and is associated with various chronic diseases, particularly those involving hypoxia.

questions.text: Identify the condition shown in the Intravenous pyelogram (IVP) given below? (FMGE AUGUST 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ureterocele

 

  • The above image shows dilated distal orifice of both the ureters which is seen in ureterocele. A ureterocele shows adder-head / cobra head appearance on IVP.
  • A ureterocele is a ballooning at the end of the ureter inside the bladder.
  • Treatment of the ureterocele usually involves the placement of a stent to relieve the obstruction and/or surgical repair.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. PUJ obstruction is a condition where there is narrowing due to congenital narrowing or a mass etc., at the pelvi-ureteric junction. This obstructs the urine flow and lead to serious complications. The patient may present with flank pain, abdominal mass, recurrent UTI, hematuria and hydronephrosis. Delayed IVP of PUJ is shown below –

 

 

Note that the contrast in the right kidney has been excreted to the bladder but retained in the left kidney.

 

Option D. Posterior urethral valve is a congenital defect affecting primarily the male infants. It is characterized by formation of flap or valves in the posterior part of urethra leading to the obstruction to the flow of urine. It can be detected antenatally on USG and is seen as a ‘Keyhole Defect’.

 

 

 

Antenatal USG showing Keyhole deformity (Posterior Urethral Valve)

 

Educational Objective:

 

A ureterocele shows a characteristic "adder-head" or "cobra head" appearance on IVP and involves ballooning at the end of the ureter inside the bladder.

questions.text: Dr. Meera, a gynecologist from Chandigarh, India, is conducting a session on family planning methods for a group of medical interns. She showcases various contraceptive devices, emphasizing their specific designs and usage benefits. Holding up one particular intrauterine device (IUD), she quizzes the interns. Based on its specific features and design, which of the following contraceptives is she most likely displaying? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. CuT 380A

 

CuT 380A – It is a T shaped device with a polyethylene frame holding 380 mm2 of exposed surface area of copper. The arms also have copper, thus ‘A’ is added.

 

The IUD frame contains barium sulfate thus making it radio-opaque. It has a shelf life of 10 years and is the most commonly used IUD.

 

Other options: 

 

 

Additional Information –

 

Types of Intrauterine Devices (IUDs)

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Shelf-life of IUDs

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy presents with fever and a skin rash. The rashes are a mix of macules, papules, and vesicles located on the axilla and flexor surfaces of the limbs. The lesions are in various stages of development, with some emerging and others healing. What is the most likely diagnosis? (FMGE AUG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chickenpox

 

Chickenpox, caused by the varicella-zoster virus, presents with fever and a characteristic rash that includes macules, papules, vesicles, and scabs, all at different stages of development simultaneously. This pleomorphic rash is a key feature distinguishing chickenpox from other conditions.

 

Additional Information

 

Chickenpox:

 

Chickenpox is an infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus [Human (alpha) Herpes Virus–3]

 

IP- 14-16 days

 

Mode of transmission: Droplets

 

Period of communicability: 1-2 days before to 4-5 days after the onset of rash.

 

Secondary Attack rate: 90%

 

Clinical features: Fever, headache followed by eruption of rash- starting from the trunks (Centripetal in distribution), there will be different stages like macules, papules, vesicles etc. at the same point of time (Pleomorphism i.e. all stages of rashes present at same time in same area), ultimately developing into scab in about 4-5 days (Scab is not infective).

 

 

MC complication of Chicken pox is Bacterial infection of skin

 

MC late complication of chickenpox: Shingles (caused by reactivation of the virus decades after the initial episode of chickenpox)

 

Most rapid and sensitive means of diagnosis: Examination of vesicle fluid under electron microscope (shows round particles)

 

Live attenuated Chickenpox Monovalent Vaccine: 

 

  • Strain: OKA strain
  • Seroconversion: >90%
  • Schedule for 12 months–12 years age: 6 weeks or 3 month interval
  • Schedule for >13 years age: 4-6 weeks interval

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Smallpox: The rash tends to progress uniformly, with all lesions at the same stage of development.

 

Option C. Epstein Barr: Typically associated with infectious mononucleosis, presenting with fever, sore throat, and lymphadenopathy rather than a pleomorphic rash.

 

Option D. Measles: Characterized by a maculopapular rash that starts on the face and spreads downward, not pleomorphic like in chickenpox.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Chickenpox presents with a pleomorphic rash, where lesions are at different stages of development simultaneously. This distinguishing feature, along with fever and centripetal distribution, helps diagnose chickenpox.

questions.text: A young patient had blunt injury to his calf during a hit and run accident. On examination, there was pain on passive stretching and distal pulses were feeble. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Compartment syndrome

Acute Compartment Syndrome

Typically presents with a rapid progression of symptoms

Early presentation

  • Pain often not proportion to the extent of injury
  • Worse with passive stretching or extension of muscles
  • Very tight, wood -like muscles that are extremely tender
  • Initially, peripheral circulation and distal pulses are maintained.

Late presentation

  • Worsened pain and swelling
  • Muscle weakness to paralysis
  • Cold peripheries
  • Pallor or cyanosis
  • Absent (or weak) distal pulse

choices.text: Cerebral amyloid angiopathy
Diffuse axonal injury

questions.text: A 40-year-old man is brought to emergency with loss of consciousness following RTA. GCS is 8/15 and patient has decerebrate rigidity. CT brain was performed and the image is given below. Which of the following is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Diffuse axonal injury

The above CT brain looks normal

Diffuse axonal injury (DAI), also known as traumatic axonal injury (TAI), is a severe form of traumatic brain injury due to shearing forces. 

It is a potentially difficult diagnosis to make on CT as the finding can be subtle, but it has the potential to result in severe neurological impairment. 

The diagnosis is best made on MRI where it is characterised by several small regions of susceptibility artifact at the grey-white matter junction, in the corpus callosum, and in more severe cases in the brainstem, surrounded by FLAIR hyperintensity. 

Typically, patients who are shown to have diffuse axonal injury have loss of consciousness at the time of the accident. Post-traumatic coma may last a considerable time and is often attributed to coexistent more visible injury (e.g. cerebral contusions). As such the diagnosis is often not suspected until later when patients fail to recover neurologically as expected

questions.text: Which is the Specific tumor marker for carcinoma pancreas?
questions.solution: Ans. A. CA19-9

choices.text: Hyperplasia of goblet cells
Intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells

questions.text: Which of the following features is associated with Barrett’s esophagus?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Intestinal metaplasia with goblet cells

Reflux esophagitis leads to irritation of esophageal mucosa and change of epithelium from squamous to columnar with goblet cells. This replacement is called as Intestinal metaplasia.

Intestinal metaplasia of the esophagus, is the diagnostic feature of Barrett’s esophagus.

choices.text: Internal oblique muscle aponeurosis

questions.text: An indirect inguinal hernia occurs due to a defect (Deep inguinal ring) which is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fascia transversalis

Deep inguinal ring lies in fascia transversalis just deep to abdominal muscles. The ring lies midway between the anterior superior iliac spine and pubic tubercle approximately 2-3 cm above femoral artery pulse in the groin.

choices.text: Basal cell carcinoma
Squamous cell carcinoma

questions.text: Cutaneous horn as shown in the image below is associated with which of the following skin cancer?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Squamous cell carcinoma

The image given in the question shows a cutaneous horn which can in the future evolve into cutaneous Squamous cell carcinoma. When the height of lesion is more than its breadth, it is called as cutaneous horn. It can evolve into SCC which is a malignant tumor of keratinizing cells of epidermis or its appendages. It arises from stratum basalis of epidermis and it expresses cytokeratin 1 and 10.

Cutaneous horn is a manifestation of Actinic keratosis which occurs in area of sun exposure and shows dyskeratosis, cellular atypia and dermal inflammation.

choices.text: Cervical lymphadenopathy with occult primary

questions.text: Identify the skin condition as shown in the image shown below of a patient from rural India?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Scrofuloderma

The image shows multiple fistulous tracts with local scarring/inflammation in posterior triangle of neck encroaching to sub occipital area. This is a feature of Tuberculous lymphadenitis which has caused direct skin infiltration and is called as Scrofuloderma.

Scrofuloderma results from the direct extension of the infection from a deep structure (e.g., lymph node or bone) into the overlying skin. Coexistence with an active pulmonary process is relatively common.
